<s> Long time no see </s> <s> Like always I was rewriting it from scratch a couple of times </s> <s> But neverthele <smiley> it is still java and now it uses metropolis sampling to help that poor path tracing converge </s> Btw </s> <s> I did <weirdcaps> on yesterday evening after 2 beers it had to be Ballmer peak </s> Altough the implementation is still very fresh it easily outperforms standard path tracing what is to be seen e <smiley> ecially when difficult caustics are involved </s> I 've implemented <smiley> ectral rendering too it was very easy actually cause all computations on wavelengths are linear just like rgb </s> <s> But then I realised that even if it does feel more physically correct to do so whats the point 3d a <smiley> lications are operating in rgb color <smiley> ace and because I cant represent a rgb color as <smiley> ectrum interchangeably I have to a <smiley> roximate it so as long as I 'm not running a physical simulation or something I don 't see the benefits <smiley> lease correct me if I 'm wrong thus I abandoned that </s> </s> 
<s> Guest Demo Eric Iverson is Itty Bitty Search February 16th <date> by Daniel Tunkelang Re <smiley> ond I 'm back from vacation and still digging my way out of everything that is piled up while I 've been offline </s> While I catch up I thought I 'd share with you a demo that Eric Iverson was gracious enough to share with me </s> <s> It uses Yahoo <weirdcaps> to su <smiley> ort an e <smiley> loratory search e <smiley> erience on top of a general web search engine </s> When you perform a query the a <smiley> lication retrieves a set of related term candidates using Yahoo is key terms <weirdcaps> </s> <s> It then scores each term by dividing its occurrence count within the result set by its global occurrence count a relevance measure similar to one my former colleagues and I used at Endeca in enterprise contexts </s> You can try out the demo yourself at htt <smiley> <repeatedchars> ittybittysearch com </s> <s> While it has rough edges it produces nice results e <smiley> ecially considering the simplicity of the a <smiley> roach </s> Here is an example of how I used the a <smiley> lication to e <smiley> lore and learn something new </s> <s> I started with <smiley> 'information retrieval ' </s> <s> I noticed 'interactive information retrieval ' as a top term so I used it to refine </s> <s> Most of the refinement suggestions looked familiar to me but an unfamiliar name caught my attention 'Anton Leuski ' </s> <s> Following my curiosity I refined again </s> <s> Looking at the results I immediately saw that Leuski had done work on evaluating document clustering for interactive information retrieval </s> <s> Further e <smiley> loration made it clear this is someone whose work I should get to know check out his home page I can 't promise that you 'll have as productive an e <smiley> erience as I did but I encourage you to try Eric is demo </s> <s> It is simple examples like these that remind me of the value of pursuing <weirdcaps> for the open web </s> <smiley> eaking of which <weirdcaps> <date> is in the works </s> <s> We 'll flesh out the details over the next weeks and of course I 'll share them here </s> </s>

<s> Yesterday I attended a biweekly meeting of an informal a <weirdcaps> Berkeley group devoted to Python in science <smiley> <weirdcaps> organized by Fernando Perez </s> <s> The format in honor of my visit was a series of 4-minute lightning talks about various projects using Python in the scientific world at Berkeley and elsewhere followed by an hourlong Q A se <smiley> ion </s> <s> This meant I didn 't have to do a presentation and still got to interact with the audience for an hour -- my ideal format </s> I was blown away by the wide variety of Python use for scientific work </s> <s> It looks like Python with extensions like numpy is becoming a standard tool for many sciences that need to proce <smiley> large amounts of data from neuroimaging to astronomy </s> Here is a list of the topics presented though not in the order presente <smiley> </s> <s> All these describing Python software I 've a ed names and affiliations insofar I managed to get them </s> <smiley> hanks to Jarrod Millman for providing me with a complete list Most projects are easily found by Googling for them so I have not included hyperlinks except in some cases where the slides emphasized them </s> <smiley> ee also the blog comments </s> </s> 
<s> In the <weirdcaps> we have browser choice but few know about it The <weirdcaps> has been tougher on monopolies than the American antitrust authorities </s> <s> This has been good for Europe and bad for America </s> <s> In Europe we have an amazing choice of fixed line internet providers for example </s> <s> In the <weirdcaps> there is generally one <weirdcaps> provider and one Cable provider per territory </s> <s> As a result we have more bandwidth for le <smiley> money </s> <s> This is surprising because in general there is more choice at a better price for a lot of goo <smiley> and services in the <weirdcaps> including cars banking and financial services gadgets etc </s> <s> But the problem with the <weirdcaps> is that sometimes lobbying is more influential than the common good </s> <s> In Europe our career public servants seem to be le <smiley> immune to lobbying although not always and banking for example seems to be an exception and most countries protect their local bank <smiley> </s> But recently the <weirdcaps> has given us more choice in Europe </s> <s> This time is the freedom to choose our browser </s> <s> But as this survey shows most Europeans around three quarters of them are not aware of this choice </s> <s> It turns out that <smiley> ain is the country with the lowest browser choice awarene <smiley> in Europe </s> </s>

<s> <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> </s> <s> <weirdcaps> Wireframes flow diagrams personas card sorts content strategy documents etc </s> <s> All of these things are important to design and designers need some combination of them to synthesize their user research and communicate what they 're doing with the other members of the team </s> But too often these deliverables are the last line of contact for designers </s> <s> Too often these deliverables are what designers prepare and then hand off to implementors </s> <s> Then they shuffle off to create more deliverables and the cycle is repeated </s> In the end deliverables are merely artifacts of the design proce <smiley> </s> <s> They are not the final design they are not the artifact of e <smiley> erience </s> <s> The end user never interacts with them they interact with the product or service that is actually delivered </s> That is the difference deliverables are divorced from delivery </s> Thus the task of a <weirdcaps> designer in order to stay true to our calling doesn 't stop at any deliverable </s> <s> Even if our 'job ' is to create wireframes we cannot be satisfied with pa <smiley> ing off wireframes to other team members </s> <s> If we are truly concerned with the e <smiley> erience of the people who use our product service we will infiltrate their world we will demand to know the quality of their e <smiley> erience </s> Many <weirdcaps> designers are judged on the quality of their deliverables </s> <s> This is nece <smiley> ary to a point we must make sure each step is faithfully executed </s> <s> But to truly be a user e <smiley> erience designer we must have a longer scope </s> <s> We can 't stop at deliverables </s> <s> We must extend through delivery </s> Deliverables are diminishing in importance </s> <s> Sketches super important to early design synthesis have fleeting value </s> <s> They are valuable for a very short period of time </s> <s> Design implement iterate move on </s> <s> Record the learning but don 't judge the sketch judge the resulting e <smiley> erience </s> So if you 're not involved in the day to day feedback loop of your user is e <smiley> erience make sure you get involved </s> <s> Ask about your feedback channel <smiley> su <smiley> ort emails call-center requests twitter mentions all of it </s> <s> Do regular surveys and user testing </s> <s> Investigate </s> <s> Demand data </s> <s> If you don 't you 're just creating deliverables and mi <smiley> ing the forest for the trees </s> E <smiley> erience in the end cannot be captured in a deliverable </s> </s> 
<s> My youngest brother does not have much of a memory for directions and ma <smiley> </s> <s> While this lea <smiley> to some friendly jibes about his lack of that so-calle <smiley> 'manly 'trait of the compa <smiley> in the head so to <smiley> eak it led to me to think about this whole notion of 'nece <smiley> ary skill <smiley> ' </s> <s> So when I can look up directions on Google ma <smiley> from my mobile phone or have an in-car <weirdcaps> system give me directions turn by turn and even notify me of traffic conditions is a sense of physical direction an important skill any more I look back and realize that technology tren <smiley> tend to define what skills are 'in 'or 'out ' </s> <s> I have forgotten the art of memorizing phone numbers because we know share contacts through bluetooth text me <smiley> ages and mi <smiley> ed calls </s> <s> Come to think of it I have also lost the unique Indian skill of being able to buy a black ticket at a crowded cinema when the box office tells you that the tickets are sold out </s> <s> That is because I buy my tickets and choose my seats online now </s> <s> A few years back I was part of a technical interview panel for my company grilling some poor people on the basics of C and Java </s> <s> And since I do not enjoy making people squirm I left with a very bad taste </s> <s> I decided then that it made no sense to ask somebody the 'difference between overloading and overriding ' </s> <s> If I was asked a question like that at a job interview I would pull out a laptop connect to the internet and show the interviewer the answer that I pulled up from Google </s> <s> I fail to see why Indian <weirdcaps> services firms still continue to test people for their ability to memorize Kernighan and Ritchie is memorable tome </s> <s> Memorization is a skill that is most definitely 'out ' </s> <s> Information is freely available and searchable </s> <s> So let is stop testing for information and start testing for knowledge </s> </s>

<s> Artificial Flight and Other Myths a reasoned examination of A </s> <s> F </s> by top bir <smiley> Tue <smiley> ay February 16th <date> Artificial Flight and Other Myths a reasoned examination of A </s> <s> F </s> by top bir <smiley> Over the past sixty years our most impre <smiley> ive developments have undoubtedly been within the industry of automation and many of our fellow bir <smiley> believe the next inevitable step will involve significant advancements in the field of Artificial Flight </s> While residing currently in the realm of science fiction true powered artificial flying mechanisms may be a reality within fifty years </s> Or so the futurists would have us believe </s> De <smiley> ite the current media buzz surrounding the pro <smiley> ect of A </s> <s> F a critical examination of even the most basic facts can dismi <smiley> the notion of true artificial flight as not much more than fantasy </s> We can start with a loose definition of flight </s> While no two undevelope <smiley> gene for flight and it is indeed flight that defines the modern bird </s> This is flight in the natural world the product of millions of years of evolution and not a phenomenon <s> Umami Nation Kombu Dashi Smackdown January 19th <date> Uncategorized posted by Dave Arnold Kombu a variety of giant kelp <smiley> eawee <smiley> is a cornerstone of Japanese cooking </s> <s> Kombu is particularly high in free glutamic acid the umami maker but its flavor is otherwise rather delicate so it is an excellent source of <weirdcaps> </s> By the way glutamic acid sodium <weirdcaps> </s> <smiley> ou 'll get much more on <weirdcaps> and umami in our upcoming post Umami Nation <weirdcaps> the Super <smiley> ice the Headache is in Your Head This post is about kombu broth </s> Several types of Kombu are used in Japanese cooking </s> For a discu <smiley> ion of kombu I refer you to this website or this book </s> We used ma kombu which was harvested as many good things are in the cold waters off Hokkaido Japan is northernmost main island </s> <s> Yuji Haraguchi of True World Foo <smiley> a premier su <smiley> lier of fish and Japanese products we buy our fish for ike-jime from them brought us the kombu </s> Ma kombu </s> <s> High quality stuff from Hokkaido </s> <s> Brought to us by True World Foo <smiley> </s> <s> Most traditional books will instruct you to place a piece of kombu in cold water and then heat that water until it just begins to bubble upon which you immediately remove the kombu </s> <s> But recent work in Japan has shown that optimal glutamate extraction is actually obtained by steeping kombu in 65 C water for about an hour </s> <s> Several years ago when we first heard about temperature regulating kombu stocks we told a group of Kaseiki chefs that they might want to use an immersion circulator </s> <s> They looked at us like we had three hea <smiley> in fact we had only two </s> <s> Undaunted we vowed to thoroughly test kombu stocks in the circulator </s> <s> Two and a half years later we finally got around to it </s> Setting up the tasting </s> <s> Setting <smiley> the Test The test <smiley> we would make one broth traditionally and one like the Kaiseki do by attempting to regulate water temperature to 65 C on a typical stove </s> After carefully reading the dashi sections of some our favorite books we settled on 10 grams of kombu per liter of liquid though intuitively this seemed low to us </s> <s> For a third test we would circulate the kombu in water at 65 C </s> We could think of two po <smiley> ible reasons the circulated broth wouldn 't be as good or better than other technique <smiley> 1 if the air churned in by circulation had a negative effect or 2 if the cra <smiley> y heat control of the stovetop was actually a benefit i e if temperature fluctuation somehow made the stock better </s> <s> To control for the air problem we a 'ed a test of some kombu circulated in a vacuum bag </s> <s> It didn 't take long for Nils and I to realize the bag was probably a good idea anyway because we would get some vacuum-infusion benefits </s> Yuji from True World also suggested we try some cold infusion so we a 'ed a 10 gram liter overnight infusion to our test a 10 gram liter overnight vacuum infusion and a 20 gram liter overnight vacuum infusion </s> <s> We never heated these infusions with the kombu in them </s> <s> As a final test Yuji suggested we heat the regular overnight infusion in the traditional way until bubbles start to form with the kombu in it </s> <s> We ended up with 8 different kombu broths and we tasted them blind </s> What We Didn 't Test We didn 't test a temperature range </s> <s> We didn 't do 60 versus 65 versus 70 C </s> <s> Next test </s> <s> We didn 't test the level of free glutamate in the broth </s> <s> Most literature will tell you this number is important </s> <s> But we can 't measure free glutamate here and we thought it much more important to judge the broths on taste alone </s> <s> We didn 't test the interaction of the kombu broths with other umami-producing ingredients like bonito flakes katsuobushi or shitake mushrooms </s> <s> Bonito flakes have inosinic acid and shitakes have guanylate both of which act synergistically with the glutamic acid in kombu to create a lot more umami than kombu alone </s> <s> Often a kombu is re-used to make a secondary dashi after the primary broth is made </s> <s> Some of the extraction metho <smiley> we used rendered the leftover kombu virtually tastele <smiley> which would make a secondary dashi impo <smiley> ible </s> So we didn 't test secondary dashis </s> <s> The Results Kombu Tasting Results </s> <s> We tested three different grou <smiley> red blue and green and then pitted the winners of each group against each other to figure out which kombu dashi reigned supreme </s> <s> The red block tested metho <smiley> of making kombu dashi at 65 C directly in a circulator in a vacuum bag in a circulator and by trying to maintain 65 C on a stovetop </s> <s> The blue block tested cold infusion technique <smiley> in a vacuum bag at 20 grams kombu per liter in a vacuum bag at 10 grams kombu per liter traditional amount and 10 grams of kombu in a liter of water without a bag </s> <s> The green group pitted traditional kombu dashi <math> grams per liter started cold and just brought to the bubble and strained versus cold infused then heated dashi also at 10g liter without a vacuum bag </s> <s> Vacuum bagged 65 C circulated kombu stock reigned supreme The verdict was decisive </s> <s> Unanimous and unequivocal </s> In the future we will test vacuum bagged 65 C kombu at 15 g liter and at 20 g liter because 20g liter won the cold infusion category </s> We should also try cold-vacuum-infused-then-heated broth </s> We think it would win </s> </s>

<s> Pokey V2 0 There is talk of another local robotic firefighting competition some time in May or June Pokey is defeat in <date> has nagged at me for the last couple years so time permitting Pokey and I are going to take another crack at it </s> Pokey nee <smiley> a refit and redesign </s> <s> Here are some of the topic areas I 'll be covering in the near future -- -- but first what won 't change No Dead Reckoning You may recall that Pokey does not use dead reckoning </s> <s> I want to continue with that design philosophy </s> <s> Pokey relied on wall following an <smiley> 'event <smiley> 'to navigate -- the a <smiley> earance disa <smiley> earance while moving of walls and floor markers </s> Smooth <smiley> eed Pokey was always intended to be a fast robot </s> <s> His name comes from the fact that I had to slow him down before the original competition to increase navigation reliability </s> I don 't want to slow him down further </s> <s> If anything I 'm hoping to <smiley> eed up the little fella </s> <s> Also Pokey was built to move smoothly and fluidly through the maze and I don 't want to change that either </s> Budget Pokey was intended to be somewhat low buck with cheap minimalist solutions preferred over fancier more e <smiley> ensive ones where po <smiley> ible </s> <s> I may have to admit defeat in a few areas and throw some more money at the problem but I still want to come in under the cost of a Lego <weirdcaps> when all is said and done </s> De <smiley> ite the things that won 't change clearly some changes are needed for Pokey to complete his mi <smiley> ion and these things will be the subject of upcoming articles </s> Navigation Problems Thinking it through most of the navigation problems boil down to poor wall following and failing to execute precise turns </s> The wall following system was marginal </s> <s> It could usually maintain a correct alignment but failed to correct even moderate misalignment </s> <s> A single wall distance sensor was inadequate given short maze walls and a fast robot </s> <s> A pair of wall distance sensors on each side should solve several problems at once </s> While executing consistent constant radius turns wasn 't too tough reliably turning to a precise heading was </s> <s> The trigger to terminate the turn was the distance of the wall that the robot was turning to </s> It just didn 't work </s> I su <smiley> ect using either a rate gyro or wheel encoders -- just for turning not dead reckoning -- would provide more precise heading changes and fluid movement </s> <s> If I can actually pull it off be a <smiley> ured you 'll hear about it here </s> Some robots had succe <smiley> aligning to the regulation door threshold floor stripe </s> <s> This a <smiley> roach alters the flow of robotic movement as it enters the room but maybe I can live with it if the gyro and encoder options don 't pan out </s> Flame Detection Problems Pokey failed to detect a flame the one time he encountered the candle in the contest </s> I ran out of time to really dial in the calibration and software </s> <s> The sensor itself works ok at closer ranges poorly at long range </s> It is big and heavy limiting fire su <smiley> re <smiley> ion system options and making Pokey le <smiley> nimble </s> Picture from superdroidrobots com of Hamamatsu <weirdcaps> Affording or justifying the cost of a <weirdcaps> or Eltec Pyroelectric flame sensor -- or a <weirdcaps> or <weirdcaps> vision sensor -- is tough </s> <s> The <weirdcaps> is more affordable and a <smiley> arently just as capable as these other two vision systems </s> <s> Or sticking with some form of <weirdcaps> detection is still a po <smiley> ibility </s> I 'm currently e <smiley> loring some cheap <weirdcaps> camera video options </s> <s> I really think that is the best way to go since the last contest winner was using an <weirdcaps> and very easily and reliably detected the candle </s> <s> Not to mention I could reuse this type of sensor for many other purposes </s> <s> More on vision in future articles </s> Telemetry One of the biggest difficulties was that Pokey didn 't collect data for later analysis </s> <s> I never quite knew what the robot was doing from moment to moment </s> <s> I 'm working on using bluetooth-based communication for telemetry reporting and logging </s> <s> More on this in an upcoming series of articles </s> Collision Avoidance Finally it 'd be nice if the robot could priority override all other functions to prevent head-on wall collisions </s> Of course the biggest challenge is time </s> but at least I don 't have to start totally from scratch </s> at 7 00 <weirdcaps> 4 comments Label <smiley> firefighting Pokey Friday March 5 <date> Heathkit and Robots So I fixed up my Heathkit <s> <weirdcaps> <date> Day 2 February 6th <date> by Daniel Tunkelang Re <smiley> ond Note this post is cro <smiley> -posted at <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> </s> Unfortunately I woke up this morning rather under the weather so I 'm having to resort to remotely reporting on the second day of <weirdcaps> <date> conference based on the published proceedings and the tweet stream </s> The day started with a keynote from Harvard economist Susan Athey </s> <s> Her research focuses on the design of auction-based markets a topic core to the busine <smiley> of search which largely relies on auction-based advertising models cf </s> <s> Google <weirdcaps> </s> <s> Then came a se <smiley> ion focused on learning and optimization </s> <s> One paper proposed a method to learn ranking functions and query categorization simultaneously reflecting that different categories of queries lea <smiley> users to have different e <smiley> ectations about ranking </s> <s> Another combined traditional list-based ranking with pair-wise comparisons between results to separate the results into tiers reflecting grades of relevance </s> <s> An intriguing a <smiley> roach to query recommendation treated it as an optimization problem perturbing user <smiley> ' query-reformulation path to maximize the e <smiley> ected value of a utility function over the search se <smiley> ion </s> <s> Another paper looked not at ranking per se but rather at improving the quality of training data for using machine learning for ranking </s> <s> The final paper of the se <smiley> ion which earned a best-paper nomination modeled document relevance based not on click-through behavior but rather on post-click user behavior </s> The next se <smiley> ion was about users and measurement </s> <s> It opened with another best-paper nominee a analysis of over a hundred million users to understand how they re-find web content </s> <s> Another offered a rigorous analysis of the often slo <smiley> ily presented 'long-tail ' hypothesi <smiley> it found that light users di <smiley> roportionately prefer content at the head of distribution while heavy users di <smiley> roportionately prefer the tail </s> <s> Another log-analysis paper analyzed search logs using a partially observable Markov model a variant of thehi 'en Markov model in which not all of the hi 'en state transitions emit observable events and compared the latent variables with eye-tracking studies </s> <s> An intriguing study demonstrated that user behavior models are more predictive of goal succe <smiley> than models based on document relevance </s> <s> The final paper of the se <smiley> ion proposed metho <smiley> for quantifying the reusability of the test collections that lie at the heart of information retrieval evaluation </s> The last se <smiley> ion of the day focused on social a <smiley> ects of search </s> <s> Two of the papers were concerned with modeling authority and influence in social networks a problem in which I take a deep personal interest </s> <s> Another inferred attributes of social network users based on those of other users in their communities cg </s> <s> <weirdcaps> is Project Gaydar </s> <s> Another analyzed Flickr and Last fm user logs to show that user <smiley> ' semantic similarity based on their tagging behavior is predictive of social links </s> <s> The final paper tackled the <smiley> arsity of social media tags by inferring latent topics from shared tags and <smiley> atial information </s> Not surprisingly a di <smiley> roportionate number of contributors to the conference work at major web search companies who have both the motivation to improve results and the acce <smiley> to data that is needed for such research </s> <s> One of the ongoing research challenges for the field is to find ways to make this data available to others while re <smiley> ecting the busine <smiley> concerns of search engine companies and the privacy concerns of their users </s> </s>

<s> Socrates Here is a story quite similar to my earlier post on Kabir is Doha <math> In ancient Greece Socrates was a great philosopher and widely acclaimed for his wi <smiley> om </s> <s> One day a friend ran up to him excitedly and sai ' <weirdcaps> do you know what I just heard about one of your students called Plato 'Wait a moment 'Socrates replied 'Before you tell me anything I ' would like you to answer a few test questions </s> <s> It is called the Triple Filter Test ' </s> ' <weirdcaps> filter 'asked the friend 'That is right 'Socrates continued 'Before you talk to me about my student I am going to ask you three questions ' The first Filter is Truth </s> <s> Have you made absolutely sure that what you are about to tell me is true 'No 'the man sai 'dactually I just heard about it and 'All right isaid Socrates 'So you are not sure if it is true or not </s> <s> Now let is try the second filter the Filter of Goodne <smiley> </s> <s> Is what you are about to tell me about my student something good 'No on the contrary ' said the man 'So 'Socrates continue 'dyou want to tell me something bad about him even though you 're not certain it is true 'The man shrugged a little embarra <smiley> ed </s> <s> Socrates continued 'You may still pa <smiley> the Triple Filter test though because there is a third filter - the Filter of usefulne <smiley> </s> <s> Is what you want to tell me about my student going to be useful to me 'No not really ' 'Well 'concluded Socrates 'if what you want to tell me is neither True nor Good nor even <smiley> eful why tell it to me at all 'The man was defeated and ashamed </s> </s>

<s> Hindi Literature - Hindi is the descendant of Sanskrit which is written in Devnagri script </s> <s> It has been affected by different languages such as Turkish Farsi Arabic Portugese and English </s> <s> It is a very e <smiley> re <smiley> ive language with rich vocabulary and precise word for each action </s> <s> Trough its poetry and song it can e <smiley> re <smiley> emotions love and nationalism by using simple and gentle wor <smiley> </s> <s> It has been declared as the official language according to our constitution </s> <s> In India it is <smiley> oken in <weirdcaps> Bihar Rajasthan Madhya Pradesh Uttrakhand Chatisgarh Jharkhand and other parts of Inida as secondary language </s> <s> There are a number of dialects of this language some of them are Awadhi Kannajui Maithili Magahi Bhojpuri and marwari and khariboli </s> <s> All the innovative work done in these languages is considered to be a part of Hindi litrature </s> <s> Apart from this Hindi is also <smiley> oken in Pakistan Nepal <weirdcaps> Mauritius Uganda and Singapore </s> <s> The Hindi literature is divided into four major forms they are 1 </s> <s> Adi kaal 2 </s> <s> Bhakti kaal 3 </s> <s> Ritikavya kaal and 4 </s> <s> Adhunik kaal </s> <s> In the ancient period the main center of development of Hindi were Delhi Ajmer kannauj and the central part of India Madhya pradesh </s> <s> Chand Bardai composed a poem for his king Prithviraj Chauhan name <smiley> 'Prithviraj Raso 'whic is considered as the first work in the history of Hindi literature </s> <s> After the defeat of Prithviraj Chauhan all most all creative work in the field of Hindi was destroyed and a very few scriptures or manuscripts are available </s> <s> This era is considered as aadi kaal </s> <s> During the later part of aadi kaal and early Bhakti kaal many sint-poets became famous and Vidyapati was one of them 'Bhakti kaal 'It is considered as the mi 'le stage of the development of Hindi literature </s> <s> The work in this period mostly comprises of long poems </s> <s> There was a great development in the field of poetry during this period </s> <s> Different form of poems like Dohas and Chupaya are the innovations of this period </s> <s> Again Bhakti kaal can be divided into two catogeries 1 </s> <s> Nirgrna the followers of a formle <smiley> go <smiley> Kabir and Gurunanak were followers of Nirguna </s> <s> And 2 </s> <s> Saguna the followers of God with attribute <smiley> Surdas and Tulsidas were followers of Saguna </s> <s> In the very time most of the poems were written in Avadhi or Braj Bhasha </s> <s> The major works of this period are Padmavat and Ramcharitmanas written by Malik Muhammad jayasi and Tulsidas re <smiley> ectively 'Sur Sagar 'written by Surdas was a graet work in Braj Bhasha </s> <s> This was the age when two diverse religion the Hindu and the Islamic mingled together to server the Hindi literature </s> <s> Many Muslim poets like Abdul Rahim who was a court poet of Akbar was a great devotee of Krishna and used to write in Hindi 'Ritikavya Kaal 'During this period the erotic element became dominant </s> <s> This era is called Riti bucause this was the age when poetry forms and theory were developed to the fullest </s> <s> But this affected the poetry by taking its emotive a <smiley> ect which was considered as chief a <smiley> ect of the 'Bhakti kaal 'and the poetry gradually started deteriorating </s> <s> The most well known book of this age is Satasai written by Bihari 'Adhunik kaal 'This is considered as the period after <date> </s> <s> The man who brought life in the hindi literature was Premchand </s> <s> Before him the Hindi literature was considered as fictitious </s> <s> He is considered as one of the best story writer and novelist in the field of Hindi </s> <s> By this time hindi had become the general public is language </s> <s> To distinguish themselves from the general ma <smiley> es the learned Muslims used to write in Urdu while Khadiboli became prominent among educated Hindus </s> <s> Khadiboli with heavily Sanskritized vocabulary or Sahityik Hindi was popularized by the writings of Swami Dayanand Saraswati Bhartendu Harishchandra and others importantwriters of this period are Mahavir Prasad Dwivedi Maithili Sharan Gupt etc </s> <s> The rising numbers of new <smiley> apers and magazines made Khadiboli popular among the educated people </s> <s> Today Hindi is at a juncture where it is being considered to loose its race with English </s> <s> Even though declared as the National language and official language <s> The Ultimate Guide To Not Caring and Being Awesome Today is guest post is from Diggy at <smiley> grade Reality where he talks about self improvement and personal growth </s> <s> I had to post this guide because it gave me a chuckle e <smiley> ecially in the context of long-term travel if you do care what other people think you 'll suffer immeasurably </s> <s> There is nothing more humbling than travel and while from the outside it may seem like we 're all free-wheeling adventurers there is an inherent proce <smiley> to getting there </s> <s> Not caring and being awesome is a learned skill </s> <s> Now on to the awesomene <smiley> Are you one of those people who really cares what other people think of them to such a degree that it influences almost every decision you make I have met some people who based every decision they made on trying to get other people to like them </s> <s> They would buy fashionable brand-name clothes because it was trendy and should impre <smiley> others </s> <s> They would live in an e <smiley> ensive apartment because it should impre <smiley> people </s> <s> They would drive an e <smiley> ensive car because it should impre <smiley> people </s> <s> They would smoke because it was cool </s> Caring vs Not Caring Let is take an example of two guy <smiley> Guy A does everything with the sole intention to try to impre <smiley> people </s> <s> He drives an e <smiley> ensive car to look cool wears e <smiley> ensive clothes to be cla <smiley> y buys people drinks to look generous smokes to look cool tells stories about all his cool and fake adventures </s> Guy B doesn 't care much what people think about him </s> <s> He has his own mi <smiley> ion and his own likes and dislikes </s> <s> If he doesn 't like something he won 't do it or he will simply say no </s> <s> He is one of those guys who may just show up at a black tie event in shorts and sandals because he was in the area and wanted to see his frien <smiley> </s> <s> He will go and dance on an empty dancefloor in a busy club because his favorite song is on and he doesn 't want to wait for others to start dancing before he can have fun </s> <s> He will be the first one to open his mouth when something isn 't right while other people just wait in line and don 't say anything </s> While guy A may initially seem cool he is fake </s> <s> Nothing about him is real </s> <s> Once people discover this about him they will likely lose re <smiley> ect for him very quickly and all his efforts of trying to impre <smiley> people actually lead to people disliking him </s> <s> There is nothing likable about people who are deceptive and unauthentic </s> The chances for people to like the guy B are actually pretty high although he totally doesn 't set out to be liked by people </s> <s> He is ha <smiley> y with who he is he has boundaries and he sticks to his principles </s> <s> Sometimes he may be perceived as a bit of a social idiot with no manners like showing up at a black tie event in shorts and sandal <smiley> and there are people that will not like him for that </s> <s> However many people will actually like him and re <smiley> ect him for having such a strong identity and for having his own boundaries because it is something that many other people do not have </s> <s> He is real and will not sell himself out just to impre <smiley> other people </s> This is a cool little graph that shows the effect of caring what people think about you on how people actually think of you </s> <s> The more you care what people think of you the le <smiley> likely you are perceived to be a cool person </s> <s> The le <smiley> you care what people think of you and the more you do your own thing and have a strong sense of your own identity the more people will <s> In March <date> a low-key Princeton economist who had become a Federal Reserve governor coined a novel theory to e <smiley> lain the growing tendency of Americans to borrow from foreigners particularly the Chinese to finance their heavy <smiley> ending </s> The problem he said was not that Americans <smiley> end too much but that foreigners save too much </s> <s> The Chinese have piled up so much exce <smiley> savings that they lend money to the United States at low rates underwriting American consumption </s> This colo <smiley> al credit cycle could not last forever he said </s> <s> But in a global economy the transfer of Chinese money to America was a market phenomenon that would take years even a decade to work itself out </s> <s> For now he said 'we probably have little choice except to be patient ' Today the dependence of the United States on Chinese money looks le <smiley> benign </s> <s> And the economist who proposed the theory Ben S </s> <s> Bernanke is dealing with the consequences having been promoted to chairman of the Fed in <date> as these cro <smiley> -border money flows were reaching strato <smiley> heric levels </s> In the past decade China has invested upward of 1 trillion mostly earnings from manufacturing e <smiley> orts into American government bon <smiley> and government-backed mortgage debt </s> <s> That has lowered interest rates and helped fuel a historic consumption binge and housing bubble in the United States </s> China some economists say lulled American consumers and their leaders into complacency about their <smiley> endthrift ways </s> </s>

<s> What is Google Buzz for As with any social networking tool or social media service this is the fundamental question both Google and its users collectively have to answer </s> <s> Part of the reason why Buzz has come under so much criticism over privacy and other i <smiley> ues which Google a 're <smiley> ed during a panel at <weirdcaps> this weeken <smiley> is that users and the search company seem to have different ideas about what Buzz is and how it should be used </s> <s> To the company is credit it has been listening and adapting as quickly as it can and has even asked sociologist and Microsoft researcher Danah Boyd to come and <smiley> eak about privacy and Buzz at Google after she gave a very critical talk at <weirdcaps> about the service </s> Apart from the privacy a <smiley> ect of Buzz one of the ongoing debates about the service is whether it should be used for aggregating or publishing or both </s> <s> When Buzz was first released many people including me did what they thought the creators of the service wanted them to do they followed a bunch of their contacts from Gmail and then selected a bunch of other content platforms and social networks to connect to their Buzz stream Flickr photos Google Reader shared items Twitter and so on </s> <s> But a growing number of Buzz users are unha <smiley> y with the practice of connecting various content streams to the service </s> <s> Like Egon <smiley> engler from 'Ghostbusters ' they don 't want people to 'cro <smiley> the streams ' One of the most thoughtful critics of this practice has been Mahendra Palsule an editor at Techmeme who goes by the handle Sceptic Geek </s> <s> Both on Buzz and on his personal blog Palsule has described what he sees as the downside of combining multiple streams into one place namely repetition a lack of focus etc </s> <s> But mostly he seems to feel that dumping content from one social network into another defeats the purpose and that the right thing to do is to create and publish content <smiley> ecifically for Buzz in other wor <smiley> to treat it as a separate platform like a blog rather than as an aggregator </s> </s>

<s> American society a <smiley> ears to be undergoing a crisis in trust </s> <s> Most of the major organizations that we depend upon including governments of all types corporations our health care system our financial institutions and our schools all seem to be failing us </s> <s> Indeed I do not believe it is an exaggeration to claim that our society is actually undergoing a disintegration proce <smiley> whereby the fundamental premises and values su <smiley> orting our institutions are all being called into question </s> <s> While such disintegration is of course very painful to e <smiley> erience it is also a tremendous o <smiley> ortunity for genuine transformation </s> <s> My e <smiley> ay will attempt to outline some of the most important values and strategies nece <smiley> ary for the creation of and the transformation to high trust organizations </s> Higher Purpose Virtually all of our societal organizations seem to have either forgotten or have never really known why they exist and what their higher purposes are </s> <s> Instead they have often elevated narrow individual and institutional self-interest into the only purposes that they recognize as valid </s> <s> Our governments all too frequently serve the politicians and the public service unions rather than their citizens </s> <s> Our schools too often serve their educational bureaucracy and teacher <smiley> ' unions instead of their students and their parents </s> <s> Our health care system too often seeks to maximize the profits of pharmaceutical companies ho <smiley> itals doctors and insurance companies rather than the health and wellne <smiley> of patients </s> <s> Many of our corporations primarily exist to maximize the compensation of their executives and secondarily shareholder value rather than value creation for customers employees and other major stakeholders </s> The single most important requirement for the creation of higher levels of trust for any organization is to discover or rediscover the higher purpose of the organization </s> <s> Why does the organization exist What is it trying to accomplish What core values will in <smiley> ire the organization and create greater trust from all of its stakeholders While there are potentially as many different purposes as there are organizations I believe that great organizations have great purposes </s> <s> The highest ideals that humans a <smiley> ire to should be the same ideals that our organizations also have as their highest purposes </s> <s> These include such timele <smiley> ideals a <smiley> The Goo <smiley> Service to others--improving health education communication and the quality of life </s> <s> Southwest Airlines Nor <smiley> troms The Container Store Amazon com and Joie de Vivre Ho <smiley> itality are examples of this great purpose </s> The True Discovery furthering human knowledge </s> <s> Google Intel Genentech and Wikipedia all e <smiley> re <smiley> this higher a <smiley> iration </s> The Beautiful Excellence the creation of beauty </s> <s> A <smiley> le and Berkshire Hathaway share this ideal in their own unique ways </s> The Heroic Courage to do what is right to change improve the world </s> <s> Grameen Bank and the Gates Foundation e <smiley> re <smiley> this higher purpose in their actions </s> Organizations that place these higher purposes at the very core of their busine <smiley> model tend to in <smiley> ire trust from all of their major stakeholder <smiley> customers employees investors su <smiley> liers and the larger communities that they exist in </s> <s> Higher purpose and shared core values tend to unify the organization behind their fulfillment and usually act to pull the overall organization upwar <smiley> to a higher degree ethical commitment </s> <s> Higher levels of trust are a natural result of this unity of purpose shared core values and greater ethical commitment </s> Conscious Leadership -- Walking the Walk Next to the power of higher purpose nothing is more important for creating high levels of organizational trust than the quality and commitment of the leadership at all levels of the organization </s> <s> It doesn 't matter if an organization has a higher purpose if the leadership doesn 't understand it and seek to serve it </s> <s> The various stakeholders of an organization e <smiley> ecially employees and customers look to the leadership to 'walk-the-talk '--to serve the purpose and mi <smiley> ion of the organization and to lead by example </s> <s> It is e <smiley> ecially important that the <weirdcaps> and other senior leadership embody the higher purpose of the organization </s> As the co-founder and <weirdcaps> of Whole Foo <smiley> Market I 'm the most visible person in the company </s> <s> One of the most important parts of my job is touring our stores and talking to our team members customers and su <smiley> liers </s> <s> I know that in virtually everything that I say and do our team members are always studying me trying to determine whether they can trust me and the mi <smiley> ion of the company </s> <s> I 'm always on stage </s> <s> So walking the talk is very important </s> <s> I try to communicate the mi <smiley> ion and values of Whole Foo <smiley> at every o <smiley> ortunity and I try to live those core values myself with complete fidelity </s> <s> Fidelity to the mi <smiley> ion and values buil <smiley> trust while any deviance undermines it </s> <s> High trust organizations and hypocritical leadership are mutually exclusive </s> Teams Everywhere Human beings evolved in relatively small tribal ban <smiley> </s> <s> Many scientific studies have indicated that our ability to maintain close trusting relationshi <smiley> with family frien <smiley> and co-workers is constrained to probably not more than about <date> people </s> <s> We can of course know many more people than this but it is hard to know them well enough to develop close bon <smiley> of trust based on actual e <smiley> eriences </s> <s> At Whole Foo <smiley> we recognize the importance of smaller tribal groupings to maximize familiarity and trust </s> <s> We organize our stores and company into a variety of interlocking teams </s> <s> Most teams have between 6 and <date> team members and the larger teams are subdivided further into a variety of sub-teams </s> <s> The leaders of each team are also members of the Store Leadership Team and the Store Team Leaders are members of the Regional Leadership Team </s> <s> This interlocking team structure continues all the way upwar <smiley> to the Executive Team at the highest level of the company </s> It has been our e <smiley> erience at Whole Foo <smiley> that trust is optimized in this type of smaller team organizational structure </s> <s> This is because each person is a vital and important member of their teams </s> <s> The succe <smiley> of the team is dependent upon the invaluable contributions of everyone on the team </s> <s> Trust is optimized when it flows between all levels within the organization </s> <s> Many leaders make the mistake of believing that the key to increasing organizational trust is to somehow get the work force to trust the leadership more </s> <s> While this is obviously very important it is equally important that the leadership trust the workforce </s> <s> To receive trust it is usually nece <smiley> ary that we give trust </s> <s> Organizing into small interlocking teams hel <smiley> ensure that trust will flow in all directions within the organization -- upwar <smiley> downwar <smiley> within the team and acro <smiley> teams </s> Empowerment Trust While small teams are e <smiley> ential to optimizing the flow of organizational trust equally important is the philosophy of empowerment </s> <s> The effectivene <smiley> of teams is tremendously enhanced when they are fully empowered to do their work and to fulfill the organization is mi <smiley> ion and values </s> <s> Empowerment must be much much more than a mere slogan however </s> <s> It should be within the very <weirdcaps> of the organization </s> <s> Empowerment unleashes creativity and innovation and rapidly accelerates the evolution of the organization </s> <s> Empowered organizations have tremendous competitive advantage because they have ta <smiley> ed into levels of energy and commitment which their competitors usually have difficulty matching </s> Nothing hol <smiley> back empowerment more than the leadership philosophy of command and control </s> <s> Command and control C C is actually the o <smiley> osite of empowerment and it greatly le <smiley> ens trust </s> <s> C C usually involves detailed rules and bureaucratic structures to enforce the rules </s> <s> Such detailed rules almost always inhibit innovation and creativity </s> <s> People get ahead in the organization not through being innovative but by following the rules and playing it safe </s> <s> C C may produce compliance from the workforce but it seldom unleashes much energy or pa <smiley> ion for the purpose of the organization </s> <s> Empowerment Trust </s> <s> C C Lack of Trust </s> The Importance Of Tran <smiley> arency and Authentic Communication A very important measurement and condition of trust is tran <smiley> arency </s> <s> If we want to optimize trust then we must seek to optimize tran <smiley> arency </s> <s> When we decide to keep something hi 'en the motivation is almost always a lack of trust </s> <s> We are afraid that the information that we wish to hide would cause more harm than good if it were widely known </s> <s> While of course some discretion is usually nece <smiley> ary to protect important organizational information from migrating to one is competitors or to outsiders who wish to harm the organization such discretion can easily be overdone </s> <s> Tran <smiley> arency is a very important su <smiley> orting value for empowerment </s> <s> Indeed it is difficult for an organization to be empowered if it lacks tran <smiley> arency </s> Whole Foo <smiley> Market strives to optimize tran <smiley> arency to all of our stakeholders </s> <s> Authentic communication with honesty and integrity are e <smiley> ential attributes of both tran <smiley> arency and trust </s> <s> This is the exact o <smiley> osite of what many organizations do which is to try to ispin 'their me <smiley> aging to tell people what they believe people want to hear so that people will think well of them </s> <s> This lack of honest authentic communication and tran <smiley> arency usually boomerangs however and undermines trust and creates cynicism </s> <s> One of the main reasons why Americans don 't trust many political leaders including the various Presidents that have led us is that we discover that they routinely lie to us </s> <s> They don 't tell us the truth and we come to understand that they don 't trust us and feel that they need to manipulate us </s> <s> We tell the truth to people that we trust </s> The high-trust organization takes the risk of revealing too much information </s> <s> We must be willing to take the risk that some valuable information may fall into the wrong han <smiley> because our commitment to empowerment and trust nece <smiley> itates taking that risk </s> <s> Creating tran <smiley> arency and authentic communication is an ongoing challenge that every organization faces </s> <s> We must continually strive to remove the barriers that prevent it knowing that we can 't maintain high levels of organizational trust without it </s> Fairne <smiley> in All Things Nothing unravels trust more quickly in an organization than either the reality or the perception of unfairne <smiley> </s> <s> Another important virtue of creating a culture of tran <smiley> arency is that it hel <smiley> ensure that unfairne <smiley> is clearly seen and can therefore be corrected quickly </s> <s> It is e <smiley> ential that the ethic of fairne <smiley> a <smiley> ly to all key organizational proce <smiley> es such as hiring promotion compensation discipline and termination </s> <s> Favoritism and nepotism undermine organizational trust </s> <s> They cannot be tolerated </s> <s> People are often prone to envy and any perceived unfairne <smiley> exacerbates this tendency greatly giving it the energy of justification </s> Creating a Culture of Love and Care Ultimately we cannot create high trust organizations without creating cultures based on love and care </s> <s> The people we usually trust the most are the people that we also believe genuinely love and care for us </s> <s> All too often love and care are not qualities that we a <smiley> ociate with organizations </s> <s> We tend to look for love and frien <smiley> hip with our families and frien <smiley> but not from our work </s> <s> Why is this Many people believe that love and care in the organizational setting interfere with efficiency and get in the way of making the 'tough but nece <smiley> ary 'decisions that the organization requires for succe <smiley> </s> <s> This type of thinking reflects our own lack of integration of love and care in our own lives </s> <s> We have created an artificial barrier that is holding back our own personal growth and the full potential of our organizations </s> <s> Fear is the o <smiley> osite of love </s> <s> When fear predominates in the organization love and care cannot flourish </s> <s> The o <smiley> osite is also true--love and care banish fear </s> <s> How can we create more love and care in our organizations To answer this would require another e <smiley> ay and perha <smiley> even an entire book </s> <s> After discovering the higher organizational purpose nothing is more important than encouraging and nurturing love and care </s> <s> Here are a few suggestions that will hopefully stimulate further thinking on this incredibly important goal of creating more love and care in our organization <smiley> The leadership must embody genuine love and care </s> <s> This cannot be faked </s> <s> If the leadership doesn 't e <smiley> re <smiley> love and care in their actions then love and care will not flourish in the organization </s> <s> As Gandhi sai <smiley> 'We must be the change that we wish to see in the world ' We must 'give permi <smiley> ion 'for love and care to be e <smiley> re <smiley> ed in the organization </s> <s> Many organizations are afraid of love and care and force them to remain hi 'en </s> <s> Love and care will flow naturally when we give them permi <smiley> ion and encourage them </s> We should consider the virtues of love and care in all of our leadership promotion decisions </s> <s> We shouldn 't just promote the most competent but also the most loving and caring </s> <s> Our organizations need both and we should promote leaders who embody both </s> Cultivate forgivene <smiley> rather than judgment and condemnation </s> <s> Too many organizations believe that judgment of others and criticizing failures are e <smiley> ential for creating excellence </s> <s> While striving for excellence is important for all organizations this can be done at a higher level of consciousne <smiley> without condemnation </s> <s> Forgivene <smiley> doesn 't mean condoning mistakes and failures </s> <s> It simply means that we help the other person to learn from their mistakes through non-judgmental feedback and encouragement </s> End all your organizational meetings with 'a <smiley> reciation <smiley> ' </s> <s> This is something that Whole Foo <smiley> Market has been doing for about 25 years now with wonderful results for <smiley> reading love and care </s> <s> Give everyone participating in the meeting the o <smiley> ortunity to voluntarily a <smiley> reciate and thank other members in the group for services they have contributed or qualities that are admired </s> <s> This one simple cultural practice of a <smiley> reciating our fellow team members moves us out of judgment and fear into the consciousne <smiley> of love </s> Conclusion We have the o <smiley> ortunity to create more conscious and higher trust organizations in the 21st century </s> <s> To do so will require three major changes </s> <s> First the organization must become conscious of what its higher purposes are </s> <s> Without consciousne <smiley> of higher purposes organizations will not reach their fullest potential because the creative energy within the organization will not be fully e <smiley> re <smiley> ed </s> <s> Secondly we 'll need our leaders to evolve to higher levels of consciousne <smiley> and trust themselves </s> <s> We will not be able to create high trust organizations without more conscious and high trust leaders </s> <s> Le <smiley> conscious leaders will tend to hold their organizations back </s> Thirdly we will need to evolve the cultures of our organization in ways that create proce <smiley> es strategies and structures that encourage higher levels of trust </s> <s> These will nece <smiley> arily include the important ideals of teams empowerment tran <smiley> arency authentic communication fairne <smiley> love and care </s> </s>

<s> Islamic banks have been operating like other traditional bank about four decades </s> <s> They also mobilize deposits and produce loans based on Islamic Law <smiley> hari 'ah which are different from the other conventional or commercial banks </s> <s> Therefore Islamic banking differs from conventional banking in several ways such as the prohibition of transactions based on interest rate and the requirement that bank is operations be carried out according to certain procedures through the use of certain financial instruments <math> </s> <s> However the Islamic bank can also offer products and services which are similar to those offered by a conventional bank </s> Generally we can define the Islamic bank as a non-interest based financial institution which complies fully with Islamic Laws and has creative and progre <smiley> ive financial engineering to offer efficient and competitive banking investment trade finance commercial and real estate financing services <math> </s> <s> There are a <smiley> roximately <date> Islamic Banks and Financial Institutions operating in Asia Africa Europe and the <weirdcaps> with more than 8 <date> branches with an estimated <date> billion <math> </s> The popularity of the Islamic banking system is not limited to the Islamic banks only </s> <s> Increasingly large international conventional banks are showing interest in the Islamic banking system as well <math> </s> <s> The consequence of this is that Islamic banks operating in Islamic countries are faced with strong competition not only from Islamic banks but also from non-Islamic rivals <math> </s> <s> When competition intensifies and when banks start to offer more or le <smiley> similar products and services it is the customer is satisfaction that can influence the performance of an Islamic bank and determines its competitivene <smiley> and succe <smiley> </s> <s> Hence it is of paramount importance to a <smiley> e <smiley> the degree of customer satisfaction towar <smiley> Islamic banks operating in Islamic countries </s> </s> 
<s> Scheduling meetings is tough but rescheduling is even harder </s> <s> We all know how frustrating it can be to try to find just the right time that accommodates everyone is availability and preferred working hours </s> <s> Throw in different time zones and conference rooms and it goes from painful to excruciating </s> <s> We 'd rather schedule dental a <smiley> ointments </s> On the Google Calendar team we 've noticed that when people talk about scheduling they say things like 'I 'm trying to find a time 'or 'let is search for a new date 'We wondered what would ha <smiley> en if we treated calendaring more like a search problem </s> <s> Just as Google search a <smiley> lies ranking algorithms to return the most relevant results from the web we hoped we could rank meeting times based on criteria important to the person scheduling the meeting </s> <s> Today we 're launching the result of that e <smiley> eriment a gadget called Smart Rescheduler in Google Calendar Labs </s> <s> Once you enable the Lab you can find a new time for an event simply by clicking on a link </s> <s> Our schedule search algorithm will return a ranked set of the best candidate dates and times based on the calendars others have shared with you </s> <s> You can read more about it on the Gmail Blog </s> So next time your bo <smiley> say <smiley> 'We need to reschedule 'just smile and say 'I 'm feeling lucky </s> </s>

<s> I was looking for my younger self ' </s> <s> Perha <smiley> he is like the man in Chris Marker is La Jete a film that he openly admired about the mutability of memory </s> <s> In La Jete the man via the peculiarities of time travel realises that as a boy he had witne <smiley> ed his own death </s> <s> In Miracles via the peculiarities of auto bio graphy Ballard time travels with the ongoing revelation that as a boy Lunghua was the map of his future </s> <s> Miracles then reunites his younger self with the older man allowing Ballard to again see through young Jim is eyes viewing his own impending death with detached yet remarkably clear vision </s> <s> In <date> I interviewed Jim Ballard </s> <s> I was nervous at the thought of matching wits with this towering figure but my anxiety was quickly banished for he was a charming and generous conversationalist </s> <s> Although taxed from the recent discovery of the cancer that would claim him he a <smiley> lied his blowtorch intelligence to everything from <weirdcaps> and the soft fascism ' of consumer culture to the surreality of having an English queen as an Australian head of state weaving such cultural flashpoints in among the war <smiley> and wefts of a philosophy that has sustained his writing acro <smiley> 19 novels and around <date> short stories </s> <s> Performing a similar function but in reverse his wonderful memoir contextualises some of the darkest and strangest corners of his fiction as elements hotwired into his life </s> It was never easy perha <smiley> not even po <smiley> ible for Ballard to separate his life from his work </s> <s> Nominally English he was born in Shanghai and lived in the e <smiley> atriate community there before being interned in <date> with his family in Lunghua a Japanese war camp </s> <s> He didn 't see England until he was 16 </s> <s> Accordingly the Shanghai years and the squalor and horror of Lunghua take up almost half of Miracles an index to its deep <smiley> ychological fi <smiley> ures </s> <s> Marguerite Duras once said she only truly recognised herself in her novels not the biographies written about her </s> <s> Perha <smiley> Ballard felt the same </s> <s> Like Duras who also wrote iterative fictionalised accounts of her e <smiley> atriate upbringing in Saigon he has practised a form of time travel throughout his career most famously in <s> In recent years cyber gangs have been careful to <smiley> read their operations acro <smiley> multiple Internet service providers a tactic that makes it much harder for law enforcement and security administrators to track organized crime activity </s> But new research shows that gathering data from various places including anti-malware and anti- <smiley> am companies and phishing blacklists makes it po <smiley> ible to identify dense clusters of <weirdcaps> that that a <smiley> ear to be overly tolerant of malicious activity </s> <s> This pattern was particularly evident in Eastern Europe and the Mi 'le East </s> <s> Researchers from Indiana University at Bloomington and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Oak Ridge <weirdcaps> compared the data from a variety of sources that measure <weirdcaps> reputation from different per <smiley> ectives </s> Security organizations tend to measure online threats differently depending on their geographic location and focus </s> <s> The study includes information on phishing websites from Phishtank com and the Anti-Phishing Working Group botnet data from the Shadowserver Foundation <smiley> am data from Indiana University <smiley> amhaus <weirdcaps> and Su <smiley> ort Intelligence and malware hosting stats from organizations such as <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> and Malware Patrol </s> <s> Craig Shue a cyber security research scientist at the Oak Ridge National Lab said the group agreed not to name the hosts and <weirdcaps> they determined were malicious in return for a look at the different data sets </s> <s> Shue is employer as well as several organizations that contributed data were concerned about being sued for criticizing particular <weirdcaps> </s> </s> 
<s> <weirdcaps> is Bill Moggridge made a comment last week after a screening of Objectified that hit close to home </s> <s> To paraphrase he said interaction design has become pervasive that anyone and everyone can be an interaction designer and so the role of profe <smiley> ional interaction designer is or is becoming unnece <smiley> ary </s> So is Interaction Design a dead-end job As an e <smiley> ertise no </s> <s> But as a discrete service offering or a career path I say absolutely </s> This position has not made me any new frien <smiley> around the office but to be clear I 'm not suggesting our profe <smiley> ion is akin to fli <smiley> ing burgers at the mall </s> <s> Instead it is that interaction design has reached a point of maturity where growth is constrained </s> <s> I see three major factors behind this and hope that by acknowledging them we can find a way forward </s> 1 Developers get it The practice of 'interaction design 'grew from the need to present software e <smiley> eriences to users in a way that makes sense meets their nee <smiley> is consistent and coherent an <smiley> 'usable 'and ultimately desirable </s> <s> Other actors in the creation of software from senior management to product managers to developers had little e <smiley> osure to these values nor the abilities to deliver on them </s> The lan <smiley> cape is much different today </s> <s> Developers have a much stronger sense of 'goo <smiley> 'an <smiley> 'a <smiley> ropriate 'interactions </s> <s> Entire development methodologies revolve around delivering value to users by understanding their nee <smiley> </s> <s> There are many developers and development-driven organizations with little or no profe <smiley> ional Interaction Design involvement making good software </s> Modern development frameworks provide a strong baseline for producing interfaces and interactions that in the past required a skilled interaction designer to realize </s> <s> On <weirdcaps> for example while it is certainly hard to produce great e <smiley> eriences it is just as difficult to produce bad <weirdcaps> </s> <s> On the Web <weirdcaps> libraries offer very usable <weirdcaps> patterns right out of the box and greatly reduce the custom design and coding efforts required to build good online a <smiley> lications </s> So from the software side as the level of interaction design awarene <smiley> and quality continues to improve throughout development organizations Interaction Designers are no longer as frequently or as heavily needed to bring a succe <smiley> ful product to market </s> 2 Interaction is not an on-screen activity Another factor is the emergence of more direct input and feedback mechanisms in today is software-enabled devices </s> <s> Interaction designers are vital to help translate between human and computer when interfaces are composed of virtual abstractions with no corre <smiley> onding physical affordances to aid comprehension </s> <s> As software manipulation becomes more 'natural 'the work of designing a <smiley> ropriate interactions moves from the screen out to the device as a whole </s> Design of physical devices has traditionally been the purview of industrial designers a profe <smiley> ion with its own long history of considering context and user nee <smiley> to design products driven by and re <smiley> onding to user interaction </s> <s> And industrial design education today can include much of the same user-centered design training familiar to interaction designers </s> So from the hardware side Interaction Designers are encroaching upon an established discipline with deeper roots and a better understanding of physical materials and human ergonomics </s> </s>

only about nine acres was still alive and salvageable </s> <s> Co 'led nurtured and coaxed those nine acres yielded their first wine in <date> </s> The grapes are picked when Brittan thinks they 're of ground 'The grapes are crushed and given a five-day cold soak before fermentation is started </s> <s> After the wines have fermented dry they are racked into French oak barrels of which roughly <math> are new and aged for a <smiley> roximately 9 months following the completion of a secondary fermentation </s> </s>

<s> Did you ever want to resize a video on the fly scaling it as you would an image <smiley> ing intrinsic ratios for video you can </s> <s> This technique allows browsers to determine video dimensions based on the width of their containing block </s> <s> With intrinsic dimensions a new width triggers a new height calculation allowing videos to resize and giving them the ability to scale the same way images do </s> <s> See example one </s> <s> The concept The idea is to create a box with the proper ratio 4 3 16 9 etc then make the video inside that box stretch to fit the dimensions of the box </s> <s> It is that simple </s> <s> The trick The pa 'ing property is the magic that styles a box with an intrinsic ratio </s> <s> This is because we 'll set pa 'ing in a percentage based on the width of the containing block </s> The <weirdcaps> rules below illustrate how to style the parent and child to create a 'magic wra <smiley> er ' a container that proportionally resizes itself depending on the width of its parent </s> <s> See example two </s> <s> Let is review the declarations in each rule starting with wra <smiley> er-with-intrinsic-ratio </s> position relative By declaring position relative all child elements will position themselves in relation to this container </s> pa 'ing-bottom <math> This declaration gives the box a <smiley> ecific format </s> <s> <smiley> ing <math> for pa 'ing makes the height of the box equal to <math> of its width </s> We <smiley> ecifically chose to use pa 'ing-bottom rather than pa 'ing-top </s> <s> This is because <weirdcaps> removes the ispace ' created via pa 'ing-top from the flow </s> <s> In other wor <smiley> using pa 'ing-to <smiley> <math> would create the layout we want but the box would act like an absolutely positioned element overla <smiley> ing the next elements in the flow </s> height 0 <smiley> ecifying a height of 0 gives this element 'layout ' so that <weirdcaps> and <weirdcaps> will dimension the inner box properly </s> <s> To learn more visit 'On having layout ' Note because <weirdcaps> and <weirdcaps> treat width as a minimum width you should not use width <date> as a layout trigger </s> <s> This causes the box to e <smiley> and to fill its container rather than re <smiley> ect the width we set for that container </s> Now let is consider each declaration within our element-to-stretch rule </s> <s> Let is take a closer look at our new selectors and declarations starting with the <weirdcaps> selector </s> width <math> This is just a wra <smiley> er to demonstrate resizing the video based on the viewport width </s> <s> In the previous example the containing block was the body element </s> Now let is examine a couple of the declarations under the <weirdcaps> selector </s> pa 'ing-bottom <date> To create a 16 9 ratio we must divide 9 by 16 <date> or <date> </s> pa 'ing-to <smiley> 25 <smiley> To avoid i <smiley> ues with the broken box model <weirdcaps> or <weirdcaps> in quirks mode we use pa 'ing-top rather than height to create room for the chrome </s> Finally we use the object embed selector because while some browsers rely on object e g Safari others need embed e g Firefo <smiley> </s> Note I 'm using <weirdcaps> is markup for now but at the end of this article I 'll be using valid markup and dro <smiley> ing embed </s> </s> 
<s> Designing a graphic is like writing a story </s> <s> You can 't include all your material nor can you present it with uniform emphasis </s> <s> To engage readers you have to selectively edit and then order your information into a narrative </s> <s> In other wor <smiley> what is most important for people to see and in what order Not every reader will agree with our choices </s> <s> Our health care graphic from the January i <smiley> ue left click to enlarge has provoked a healthy debate around the blogo <smiley> here </s> <s> Some people love it others loathe it </s> <s> The i <smiley> ue isn 't just premiums or public options </s> <s> Many bloggers are talking about our proce <smiley> </s> <s> There is nothing wrong with a scatter-plot solution </s> <s> It just emphasizes different points a different story </s> <s> Here is why I didn 't go this route </s> 1 Many people have difficulty reading scatter plots </s> <s> When we produce graphics for our magazine we consider a wide audience many of whose members are not versed in visualization techniques </s> <s> For most people it is considerably easier to understand an upward or downward line than relative <smiley> atial positioning </s> 2 This graphic was designed for our vertical printed page to <smiley> </s> <s> Scatter plots tend to work better as horizontals </s> <s> Without this context I can see why online viewers would question the graphic is shape </s> 3 Any data visualization is going to put certain information in the foreground and other info in the background </s> <s> The scatter plot nicely organizes the countries into three clusters but the varying dot size puts too much emphasis on the doctor-visit data which should be a tertiary point </s> <s> On the other hand our parallel plot which I anchored around the <smiley> ending and life-e <smiley> ectancy average <smiley> calls the reader is attention to discrepancies between <smiley> ending and life e <smiley> ectancy the story I wanted to tell </s> <s> I a <smiley> laud people for questioning our a <smiley> roach in fact I love this kind of dialogue e <smiley> ecially about art and design </s> <s> Whether we reach consensus well </s> that is a different story </s> <s> At least one blogger said we should have used a graph known as a scatter plot </s> <s> A scatter plot lets you visualize the relationship between multiple variables </s> <s> In the case of the health care graphic our variables are <smiley> ending life e <smiley> ectancy and doctor visits </s> <s> The scatter-plot version below plots <smiley> ending along the x axis and life e <smiley> ectancy along the y and it uses dot size to show the doctor visits </s> <s> There is nothing wrong with a scatter-plot solution </s> <s> It just emphasizes different points a different story </s> <s> Here is why I didn 't go this route </s> 1 Many people have difficulty reading scatter plots </s> <s> When we produce graphics for our magazine we consider Scott and the joys of field <smiley> orts popularized the district checks and estate twee <smiley> that identified those who lived and worked on their acres </s> <s> Hard-wearing breathable and <s> Burtynsky a Canadian born of Ukrainian heritage in <date> is re <smiley> ected internationally for his <math> year focus on industrially-transformed lan <smiley> capes </s> <s> His photographs of quarries factories mining pits and railcuts are extraordinary for their depiction of mankin <smiley> is organization of the land for resource-extraction and profit </s> <s> Jennifer Baichwal is <date> documentary Manufactured Lan <smiley> capes is an excellent portrait of Burtynsky and I highly recommend a viewing of both the <weirdcaps> and his great books which include Manufactured Lan <smiley> capes <math> Burtynsky China <math> and Edward Burtynsky Quarries <math> </s> <s> In organizing the exhibition it occurred to me that Burtynsky is one of our most Ballardian artists </s> <s> His intense concentration on the technological sublime the precisionist geometries of his images and his evocation of a rationalist yet mysteriou <smiley> automatism at the heart of the relationship between man and nature all seem absolutely the inheritance of Ballar <smiley> is insightful understanding of our times </s> <s> In writing an e <smiley> ay for the book that accompanies the Corcoran exhibition I adopted a style in overt homage to Ballard in hopes that such a literary strategy might help illuminate this great body of work </s> <s> I also wanted to honor Ballar <smiley> is legacy as the foremost imaginative interpreter of the world Burtynsky documents </s> <s> The editors of Ballardian com have graciously agreed to reprint the e <smiley> ay here as an extension of that homage </s> <s> Readers of this site will recognize the tropes the ideas and the <smiley> ecific sources I 've drawn from Ballar <smiley> is oeuvre I hope they will forgive any la <smiley> es or exce <smiley> es as my own error </s> <s> The subject is not oil </s> <s> In these pictures Edward Burtynsky shows the man-made world the human ecosystem that has risen up around the production use and dwindling availability of our paramount energy source </s> <s> The mechanics and industry of extraction and refinement the development products and activities a <smiley> ociated with tran <smiley> ortation and motor culture and the wreckage obsolescence and human cost that lies at the End of Oil </s> <s> These photographs are about man and what he has made of the earth </s> <s> Burtynsky starts at the center of the subject at oil is source then moves outward around the world showing its use </s> <s> By their arrangement the photographs survey a life cycle </s> <s> Each black drop follows a path following the pictorial sequence we can imagine ourselves trailing in its wake </s> <s> The journey is an unusual one </s> <s> We have rarely seen images of these places </s> <s> Some we didn 't know existed others we never thought we 'd see </s> <s> Has any artist ever documented this manifold subject in such depth This is a new form of epic history painting </s> <s> Turning his camera lens to a fever dream Burtynsky forges a new mythology for the 21st century from the lexicon of realism </s> <s> With stunning detail from improbable perches in strange and beautiful colors these pictures show their subjects with clinical accuracy and with definitive force </s> <s> But they also tell a parallel and more inchoate tale a critique of civilization and a foretelling of human en <smiley> </s> <s> Some visual e <smiley> eriences test our capacity for e <smiley> lanation our ability to extract meaning or convey affect through existing vocabulary </s> </s>
