<s> I think one reason why such things don 't both us as <weirdcaps> as much as they bother the average machine learning person is that we are willing to invest some energy in intelligent initialization </s> <s> This already puts us in a good part of the optimization lan <smiley> cape and doing local hillclimbing from there is not such a big deal </s> <s> A cla <smiley> ic example is the 'Klein and Manning ismart initializer for unsupervised parsing where a small amount of human knowledge goes a long way above a random initializer </s> <s> Another style of initialization is the <weirdcaps> alignment model style </s> <s> <weirdcaps> model 4 is of course highly non-convex and ridiculously difficult to optimize the E step is intractable </s> <s> So they do a smart initialization using the output of model 3 </s> <s> Model 3 too is highly non-convex but not quite so much so so they initialize with model 2 </s> <s> And so on down to model 1 which is actually convex and fairly easy to optimize </s> <s> This sequencing of simple models to complex models also ha <smiley> ens in some statistical analysis where you first fit first order effects and then later fit higher order effects </s> <s> The danger of course is that you got to a bad hill to climb but this overall generally a <smiley> ears to be a bigger win than starting somewhere in the mi 'le of a random swamp </s> Of course later Bob Moore had this cute argument that even though model 1 is convex we don 't actually ever optimize it to the global optimum so doing clever initialization for model 1 is also a good idea These two idea <smiley> clever initialization and sequential initialization seem like powerful ideas that I would like to see make their way into more complex models </s> <s> For instance in the original <weirdcaps> paper Dave Blei used an initialization where they pick some random documents as see <smiley> for topics </s> <s> As far as I know no one really does this anymore <smiley> oes anyone know why does it really not matter but as we keep building more and more complex models and lose hope that our off the shelf optimizer or sampler is going to do anything reasonable we 're probably going to need to get back to this habit perha <smiley> trying to formalize it in the meantime </s> </s>

such as muscle <smiley> asticity can develop which may get better over time get worse or remain the same </s> <s> Cerebral palsy is not infectious </s> <s> It is not a disease and should not be referred to as such </s> <s> Although cerebral palsy is not 'curable ' in the accepted sense training and therapy can help improve function </s> <s> Ella and her twin brother Max were born extremely prematurely at just 26 weeks gestation 3 months early and I intend to talk about this in more detail as time progre <smiley> es </s> <s> Extreme prematurity and prematurity in general present an <s> Two recent shareposts 'The Depre <smiley> ion-Mania Two Ste <smiley> ' <smiley> art I and Part <weirdcaps> zeroed in on a crucial fact that ten <smiley> to be overlooked by clinicians namely De <smiley> ite the fact that depre <smiley> ion and mania present as polar o <smiley> osites the two can hardly be viewed as unrelated </s> <s> For our own health and safety they need to be seen together as part of the same cycling phenomenon </s> <s> Today is depre <smiley> ion is tomorrow is mania but there is another twist Too often depre <smiley> ion fails to clear the room </s> <s> Too often mania doesn 't wait to be invited in </s> <s> The two show up at once </s> <s> The dance is over </s> <s> A free-for-all breaks out </s> <s> The e <smiley> erts refer to the condition as a 'mixe <smiley> ' episode or state </s> <s> Sweet mania turns sour </s> <s> Vegetative depre <smiley> ion becomes animated </s> <s> Those who have been through either describe the e <smiley> erience as akin to wanting to crawl out of your skin of feeling the urge to grab the world by the throat and wring it </s> <s> I used to joke 'I get road rage a lot - and I don 't even drive ' Amazingly for a <smiley> ued last month </s> <s> The good news is that the <weirdcaps> is criteria for a mixed state will be far le <smiley> restrictive </s> <s> In light of the fact that in all other re <smiley> ects <weirdcaps> bipolar and <weirdcaps> bipolar are virtually identical this is a very significant development </s> <s> The current <weirdcaps> recognizes mixed states only when full-blown depre <smiley> ion is accompanied by full-blown mania </s> <s> Thu <smiley> at least five of nine depre <smiley> ion symptoms accompanied by at least four of seven mania symptoms </s> <s> Technically then only those with bipolar I qualify </s> <s> But in the real world individuals may e <smiley> erience depre <smiley> ion accompanied by only two or three mania hypomania symptoms </s> <s> Or mania with just two or three depre <smiley> ion symptoms </s> <s> Don 't these symptoms somehow count Yes says Ellen Frank <weirdcaps> of the University of Pittsburgh </s> <s> In an interview several years ago <weirdcaps> of the University of Pisa found that just one symptom of mania the symptom list in the study was much longer and more refined than the <weirdcaps> list in unipolar depre <smiley> ion increased risk for suicidal ideation 4 2 percent </s> <s> More symptoms kept u <smiley> ing the risk </s> <s> So what do we do with these so-called unipolars Treat them as if they had pure depre <smiley> ion According to Hagop Akiskal <weirdcaps> of <weirdcaps> in a journal article 'the nonrecognition of depre <smiley> ive mixed state is nothing short of a clinical tragedy because these are data points </s> <s> I can train any off the shelf cla <smiley> ifier based on pixel level features and get some reasonable performance maybe 80s <math> s depending </s> <s> Now I want to insert my <date> zeros and <date> ones and so on and just manipulate them a bit </s> <s> That is I 'll sample a random zero and a <smiley> ly some small random transformations to it and call it another labeled example also a zero </s> <s> Now I have <date> <date> training points </s> <s> I train my off the shelf cla <smiley> ifier based on pixel level features and get <math> accuracy or more </s> <s> In <weirdcaps> 15 Jon Kleinberg presented some impo <smiley> ibility results for clustering </s> <s> The idea is to <smiley> ecify three axioms that all clustering functions should obey and examine those axioms </s> <s> Let <smiley> <smiley> be a metric <smiley> ace <smiley> o X is a discrete set of points and d is a metric over the points of <smiley> </s> <s> A clustering function F takes d as input and produces a clustering of the data </s> <s> The three axioms Jon states that all clustering functions should satisfy are Scale invariance For all d for all a 0 F a <smiley> F <smiley> </s> <s> In other wor <smiley> if I transform all my distances by scaling them uniformly then the output of my clustering function should stay the same </s> <s> Richne <smiley> The range of F is the set of all partitions </s> <s> In other wor <smiley> there isn 't any bias that prohibits us from producing some particular partition </s> <s> Consistency Su <smiley> ose F <smiley> gives some clustering C </s> <s> Now modify d by shrinking distances within clusters of C and e <smiley> anding distances between clusters in C </s> <s> Call the new metric <smiley> ' </s> <s> Then F <smiley> ' C </s> <s> Kleinberg is result is that there is no function F that simultaneously satisfies all these requirements </s> <s> Functions can satisfy two but never all three </s> <s> There have been a bunch of follow on papers including one at <weirdcaps> last year and one that I just saw at <weirdcaps> </s> <s> If you think about these axioms a little bit they kind of make sense </s> <s> My problem is that if you think about them a lot of bit you or at least I realize that they 're broken </s> <s> The biggest broken one is consistency which becomes even more broken when combined with scale invariance </s> <s> What I 'm going to do to convince you that consistency is broken is start with some data in which there is what I consider a natural clustering into two clusters </s> <s> I 'll then a <smiley> ly consistency a few times to get something that I think should yield a different clustering </s> <s> Let is start with some data </s> <s> The colors are my opinion as to how the data should be clustere <smiley> </s> </s>

<s> So what I 'd like someone to do is to argue to my why consistency is actually a desirable property </s> <s> I can come up with lots of other examples </s> <s> One reason why this invariance is bad is because it renders the notion of 'reference size <smiley> 'irrelevant </s> <s> This is of course a problem if you have prior knowledge eg one thing measured in millimeters the other in kilometer <smiley> </s> <s> But even in the case where you don 't know knowledge what you can do is take the following </s> <s> Take data generated by thousan <smiley> of well separated Gau <smiley> ians so that the clearly right thing to do is have one cluster per Gau <smiley> ian </s> <s> Now for each of these clusters except for one shrink them down to single points </s> <s> This is po <smiley> ible by consistency </s> <s> Now your data basically looks like thousan <smiley> -1 of clusters with zero inter-cluster distances and then one cluster that is <smiley> read out </s> <s> But now it seems that the reasonable thing is to put each data point that was in this old cluster into its own cluster e <smiley> entially because I feel like the other data shows you what clusters should look like </s> <s> If you 're not ha <smiley> y with this a <smiley> ly scaling and push these points out super far from each other </s> I don 't think this example is as compelling as the one I drew in pictures but I still think it is reasonable </s> <s> Now in the <weirdcaps> paper this year they show that if you fix the number of clusters these axioms are now consistent </s> <smiley> erha <smiley> this has to do with the fact that all of my 'weir <smiley> 'examples change the number of clusters -- though frankly I don 't think this is nece <smiley> ary </s> <s> I probably could have arranged it so that the resulting green and blue clusters look like a single line that maybe should just be one cluster by itself But I still feel like consistency isn 't even something we want </s> </s> 
<s> Performance at a default setting of the hyperparameter </s> <s> For instance <weirdcaps> uses something like average inverse norm of the data vectors as the C parameter </s> <s> Or you could just us 1 like I do for logreg </s> <s> In particular su <smiley> ose you 're testing your algorithm on 20 data sets from <weirdcaps> </s> <s> Pick a single regularization parameter or parameter selection scheme ala <weirdcaps> to use for all of them and report results using that value </s> <s> If this is about the same as the 'I carefully tune <smiley> isetting I 'm ha <smiley> y </s> <s> If it is way worse I 'm not so ha <smiley> y </s> <s> Performance within a range </s> <s> Let is say that if I do careful hyperparameter selection then I get an accuracy of X </s> <s> How large is the range of hyperparameters for which my accuracy is at least X <date> I e if I 'm willing to suffer 5 multiplicative lo <smiley> how lazy can I be about hp selection For this you 'll probably need to grid out your performance and then do empirical integration to a <smiley> roximate this </s> <s> Of course you 'll need to choose a bounded range for your hp usually zero will be a lower bound but you 'll have to pick an u <smiley> er bound too -- but this is fine as a practitioner if you don 't give me an u <smiley> er bound I 'm going to be somewhat unha <smiley> y </s> <s> Neither of these is totally ideal but I think they 'd be a lot better than the current situation of really having no idea Maybe there are other proposals out there that I don 't know about or maybe other readers have good ideas </s> <s> But for me if you 're going to convince me to switch to your algorithm this is something that I really really want to know </s> As an aside Mark if you 're reading this I can imagine the whole <weirdcaps> thing getting a bit confused if you 're using feature hashing have you tried this Or has someone else </s> </s>

<s> Hi Sarimah I am watching the show and you did a great job </s> <s> Answering you questions well this is because of the muscle ma <smiley> that basically guys having higher muscle ma <smiley> compared to women </s> 1kg of muscle will burns a <smiley> roximately 31 calories without exercise that we call <weirdcaps> Metabolic Rate </s> <s> More muscle means more fat burnt </s> <s> The second things is during exercising guys will use more energy than women does </s> <s> Says weight lifting </s> <s> Guys can bring up <weirdcaps> weight but women maybe <weirdcaps> </s> <s> Means that guys will burn more calories because they use more energy compared to women </s> </s>

<s> Yes </s> <s> Men do typically lose weight faster and easier than women </s> <s> This phenomenon is due to a man is on average higher metabolism </s> <s> A man is higher metabolism comes from a typically higher muscle ma <smiley> and muscle burns more calories </s> <s> Also men are typically larger than women and just maintaining bioma <smiley> is an increase on calorie demand therefore a calorie burner </s> <s> On the other side of the coin women have other biological goals than men do and that would be to have reserves in order to su <smiley> ort the creation development and birth of children as well as provide those children with milk </s> </s>

<s> For a while now I 've been relying on audio files for use as meditation timers </s> <s> These files e <smiley> entially consist of a recorded bell in the beginning followed by a duration of silence and another bell at the end </s> <s> There are many of these available on the web and are not bad </s> <s> The problem is that you 're limited to the duration of the files available i e if you want to meditate for 45 minutes then you need a <math> minute long audio file </s> <s> Mildly frustrated by this I <smiley> ent some time this morning writing an on-line meditation timer </s> <s> Simply set the duration and click Start </s> <s> You should hear a bell when the timer begins and en <smiley> </s> <s> Here it i <smiley> Online Meditation Timer </s> <s> <smiley> ing Google A <smiley> Engine and <weirdcaps> it took me about 45 minutes to build this </s> <s> That includes the time it took to prettify the site and type in this blog post </s> <s> Gotta love simple well-designed a <smiley> lication frameworks <weirdcaps> turns out to be a great language for toying with graphics and visualization </s> <s> This morning I <smiley> ent a few hours learning about the Mandelbrot set and trying to code up a working implementation </s> <s> The link below is one of the fruits of my labor Mandelbrot Set <weirdcaps> the Mandelbrot set is the set of points in the complex plane generated by iterating through the formula z z 2 c </s> <s> For different initial values of c the iteration can either produce a bounded sequence or tend to infinity </s> <s> Plotting the graph is a matter of placing a black dot for the values that generate a bounded sequenc </s> </s>

there was one question guaranteed to get us arguing What is art One of the great ble <smiley> ings of my life is that my father and I arrived at an understanding on that question before he died not exactly an agreement but an understanding </s> <s> It went something like thi <smiley> Art is not art unle <smiley> there is some skill involved </s> <s> For my father that definition excluded a lot </s> <s> Starting next month Jeremy is going to take a <weirdcaps> Hummer or Cadillac Escalade and turn it into a horse drawn vehicle the image above is just one of many models Jeremy has made to visualize the concept </s> <s> Making cars into carts is what people did back in The Great Depre <smiley> ion and in the States they called them Hoovercarts as a play on Hoovercrats a term coined for su <smiley> orters of Herbert Hoover the president who presided over the worst of the Depre <smiley> ion </s> <s> In Canada they were called Bennett Buggies after the prime minister at the time </s> <s> They arose from a surplus of cars relative to a shortage of affordable fuel </s> <s> Folks fould that one horse or mule could pull a Model T Ford quite easily if you took out the engine </s> <s> And there was gra <smiley> and hay to be had even when money for gasoline dried up </s> <s> This project is going to take a lot of energy and e <smiley> ertise </s> <s> Over the more than five years I </s> <s> What has this got to do with art Everything </s> <s> There may be some artists who seek obscurity like the Bu 'hist monks in Shangri-La that were on <weirdcaps> last night </s> <s> But most art is intended to be e <smiley> erienced </s> <s> And that seldom ha <smiley> ens without a push from somewhere </s> <s> Consider Jeremy Dean the Brooklyn-based artist who created the indie doc Dare Not Walk Alone that I had the honor of producing </s> <s> He has been cooking up some cool conceptual art for several years now but it was connecting with a gallery that gave his private art a push in the public direction </s> <s> Jeremy will be showing at big art events in December and March and already has some cool art video online </s> <s> <smiley> eaking of that a <smiley> ect of pushing art forward which is often referred to a <smiley> 'publication 'and or 'distribution 'we are seeing the 'and or 'converge taking place right now in technology like Amazon is Kindle </s> <s> You can now read Kindle books on your <weirdcaps> and <weirdcaps> as well as on the actual Kindle device </s> <s> Which brings me to the book I wanted to review here World War <smiley> An Oral History of the Zombie War </s> <s> This is a novel by the first 'new 'author I have read entirely on the <weirdcaps> </s> <s> The book came out in print a few years ago and sold well </s> <s> It is currently around <date> on Amazon </s> <s> But the book is in several top 10 lists on Kindle which is how I came to see it while using Kindle on my <weirdcaps> </s> <s> I was intrigued enough by the reviews to download the free preview and on reading that I figured I would like the book so I paid for the full Kindle version </s> <s> There were three things that I enjoyed about World War Z </s> <s> First and foremost I admired the extent to which author Max Brooks had thought through all the implications of zombieism <smiley> </s> <s> Then he extrapolated a new reality from a defined set of data zombies eat flesh zombies can only be killed by destroying the brain zombies can survive under water zombieism <smiley> rea <smiley> through biting and the dead re-animate after infection and so on </s> <s> The book e <smiley> lores the logical and logistical end game </s> <s> By doing so it reveals worrying weakne <smiley> es in current technology science cultures and religions </s> Hint this is a global catastrophe of <date> proportions Second the narrative structure created by the interview excerpt device was refreshing and very effective </s> <s> You learn very little about zombies or the war through direct description </s> <s> You get most of it by inference </s> <s> And you get a lot of rich characters too which kee <smiley> things fresh </s> <s> Brooks is skilfull at giving each a unique voice and strong presence using little more than their recorded wor <smiley> </s> <s> He also manages some great humor of the dark battlefield kind </s> <s> Third I found this to be a fascinating book to read against the backdrop of the global <weirdcaps> Swine Flu pandemic </s> <s> Indeed I think that may be part of the reason for the book is succe <smiley> the series of epidemics <smiley> ets people we turn when we pursue humint are considered e <smiley> endable and there is a school of thought that says this is the way it must be </s> <s> You rarely see that portrayed as <s> The action here is in Europe from the <weirdcaps> to the eastern Soviet bloc but present day so we have disaffected Ru <smiley> ians Jewish mobsters and Mi 'le Eastern terrorists </s> <s> Again is not pasted on it is integral to the picture that Seymour paints of hate and fear breeding more of the same </s> <s> The author of this thick but very readable thriller is Gerald Seymour a former <weirdcaps> television news reporter back when that title meant you got a lot of e <smiley> erience reporting in the field he covered the Munich Olympics ma <smiley> acre and the Great Train Robbery and <smiley> ent time reporting from Vietnam and Northern Irelan <smiley> </s> <s> Relatively unknown in the States judged by a dearth of Seymour titles on the shelves of two different Barnes amp much like <weirdcaps> is work </s> <s> Seymour is style is faster-paced but the depth is there </s> <s> His trademark technique is weaving multiple points-of-view </s> <s> There are no 'main 'characters but rather a half dozen or more people that we follow throughout the book </s> <s> The fun part is deciding who is <weirdcaps> you 're getting at the start of a new section </s> <s> A rare case of entertainment tastefully blended with substance </s> </s> <s> The last review is <date> and there is an inverse relationship between the amount of truly fascinating content in this book and basically thi <smiley> America was a heavily populated and highly civilized land before contact with the Europeans </s> <s> That many millions of people died as a result of European arrival in the Americas either killed in conflict or killed as a consequence of contact is now clear </s> <s> This truth had been slowly emerging in scientific papers and publications for decades but Mann has pulled <smiley> re <smiley> ed </s> <s> With a minimum of moralizing and finger-pointing Mann documents the whole sorry story </s> <s> He leaves others to state the obvious conclusion Americans of European kesilapan command boleh merosakkan sistem </s> <s> Ubuntu dan root pa <smiley> word </s> <s> Secara default akaun root telah dikunci di dalam Ubuntu </s> <s> Anda tidak boleh login sebagai root atau menggunakan command su - untuk menjadi superuser </s> <s> Jadi untuk melaksanakan sebarang arahan anda mestilah menggunakan arahan sudo </s> <s> Ti <smiley> Jika malas untuk menaip sudo pada setiap kali untuk melaksanakan command gunakan command di bawah </s> sudo -i Arahan di atas akan mengaktifkan bin bash sebagai root shell </s> <s> Jadi anda boleh menggunakan arahan tanpa memerlukan arahan sudo </s> <s> How do I login as root user Buka terminal dan taipkan arahan seperti dibawah sudo bash ataupun sudo -s masukkan pa <smiley> word anda dan anda boleh menjadi root user </s> </s>

was presented by the Western <smiley> rings Library Frien <smiley> who also provided refreshments </s> <s> It got a little warm in the room but it was a ha <smiley> y warm with many ta <smiley> ing feet </s> <s> Because it was almost St </s> <s> Patrick is Day the band featured a number of tunes of Irish origin but they also played bluegra <smiley> American folk and jazz </s> <s> Every piece sent us in an enjoyable new direction </s> <s> The audience seemed to a <smiley> reciate the virtuosity </s> <s> The band seemed to really like the attentive audience </s> <s> The a <smiley> lause was get more jobs in the Chicago area </s> <s> Biographies sample music and contact info can be found at their website </s> <s> Throughout my career as a librarian one activity that I have enjoyed is looking at picture in the mi 'le of biographies and memoirs </s> <s> They evoke in me a feeling similar to finding old pictures in a drawer in my mother is house </s> <s> I can become transfixed </s> <s> This can easily ha <smiley> en at the library when I find new books sitting on a cart right out of technical proce <smiley> ing when I am working on reference questions or when I am weeding collections </s> <s> I find myself gazing at the photos of the subjects in their youth then doing whatever made them famous and finally in old age </s> <s> There is often more to see than just famous people - there are old clothes old cars and interesting locations </s> <s> I am hooked by these glo <smiley> y pages </s> <s> At a recent book discu <smiley> ion one of the club members said that her favorite thing about biographies were the pictures in the mi 'le </s> <s> I understood but I was su 'enly conscious of all the biographies that I have examined in the past three years that did not have picture-in-the-mi 'le sections </s> <s> I wondered why I had not thought about the change - if there really has been a change </s> <s> So I decided to do a little investigating </s> <s> I have been looking at many biographies published in <date> anyway so I created a <smiley> rea <smiley> heet to keep track of how these books deal with pictures </s> <s> I used only third person biographies for the study no memoirs </s> <s> I discovered two common ways to use pictures in biographie <smiley> 1 group pictures into inserted sections often on glo <smiley> y paper or 2 distribute the pictures throughout the text with no glo <smiley> y paper </s> <s> There are two other le <smiley> common ways to use picture <smiley> 3 insert a single picture on glo <smiley> y paper with a blank back in a few strategic <smiley> ots in a book common a hundred years ago or 4 fill the books with photos and minimal text </s> <s> The fourth method really makes a different type of book a photobiography </s> <s> Looking at 66 biographies from <date> I foun <smiley> 40 books <math> with inserted picture sections 20 books <math> with pictures <smiley> read throughout the text 2 books 3 with single inserted pages 2 books were photobiographies 3 4 books had no illustrations 6 This a is to more than <date> because Tom and Jack The Intertwined Lives of Thomas Hart Benton and Jackson Pollock by Henry Adams had both a color insert section and black-and-white photos distributed through the text while Rehnquist by Herman J </s> <s> Obermayer had both distributed photos as well a few single page single photo inserts on glo <smiley> y paper </s> <s> Seeing that more than half of the biographies still had picture sections in the mi 'le I wondered if I had really been right in thinking there were more in the past </s> <s> I decided to go back twenty years and look at biographies from <date> </s> <s> At the Downers Grove Public Library in Illinois I was able to find 46 biographies published in <date> 36 book <math> had picture sections 6 books <math> had pictures <smiley> read through the text 1 book 2 had no photos 4 books were photobiographies 8 Again the total is greater than <date> because Mozart The Golden Years by H </s> <s> C </s> <s> Robbins Landon had both color illustrations in an inserted section as well as black and white illustrations throughout the text </s> <s> My sample size may not be large enough to be definitive but it a <smiley> ears to me that there has been a shift in the way biographies include photos </s> <s> The method that has gained popularity is incorporating pictures into the text but separate picture sections are still found in more than half of today is biographies </s> <s> It will be interesting to see if the trend continues with more emphasis on reducing printing costs </s> <s> Glo <smiley> y sections must cost more and digital publishing makes it easier to insert photos into the text </s> <s> For now we should enjoy looking at six to twelve glo <smiley> y photo-rich pages in the mi 'le of the book while we can </s> <s> For those wanting to check my math here are the book <smiley> <date> Biographies With Insert Sections Aces your wor <smiley> are few but I have made them many by rereading them 'Abelard to Heloise In medieval Paris for about two years around <date> to <date> the philosopher Peter Abelard and his student Heloise became impa <smiley> ioned lovers </s> <s> Abelard even sweet-talked his way into residency in Heloise is uncle is compound to more easily continue the secret affair </s> <smiley> ncle Fulbert was her guardian Even in such close proximity the couple wrote each other daily letters in Latin which the letter carrier could not rea <smiley> praising their love </s> <s> Amazingly some of these letters which were lost for nearly <date> years were identified in the <date> s </s> <s> <smiley> ing these and the better known letters the couple wrote long after their affair James Burge has written Heloise amp Abelar <smiley> A New Biography </s> <s> Readers get a sense of both these remarkable people in this intimate dual biography </s> <s> Abelard was a brilliant academic who believed fervently in logic </s> <s> He was able to win almost any debate </s> <s> What he lacked was any tact and an ability to curb his own arrogance </s> <s> He needle <smiley> ly made many jealous enemies lost many teaching positions and was often charged as a hertic </s> <s> When Heloise is uncle discovered the betrayal of his ho <smiley> itality and that Heloise was pregnant the old man was livid </s> <s> Abelard married Heloise took her to Brittany out of the uncle is reach and returned to teach in Paris </s> <s> When his guard was down Abelard was attacked in his bed and castrated by the uncle is men </s> <s> Heloise was one of Abelar <smiley> is best student gra <smiley> ing complex philosophical ideas and a master of languages </s> <s> Her origins are not certain </s> <s> She may have been the illegitimate daughter of a nun </s> <s> After Abelar <smiley> is castratation and his becoming a monk she became a nun eventually becoming the much honored abbe <smiley> of an order </s> <s> In this book I think Heloise outshines Abelard </s> <s> He was really too devoted to himself and always needed someone to defend him </s> <s> She fended for herself quite well </s> <s> I most like that she refused to ever bow to Abelar <smiley> is request that she feel remorseful for their joint isin 'She enjoyed the isin 'and would always love Abelard </s> <s> Readers of Heloise amp Abelar <smiley> A New Biography also learn quite a bit about twelfth century church controversies and French history </s> <s> Eleanore of Aquitaine even show up at the end of the story </s> <s> I recommend the book to history and biography readers </s> <s> Burge James </s> <s> Heloise amp Abelar <smiley> A New Biography </s> <s> <weirdcaps> <date> </s> <s> <weirdcaps> <date> </s> <s> We are breaking with our past at Thomas Ford </s> <s> One thing that you could always count on was that the reference books were here on the shelves </s> <s> As good as that was in the past the problem now is that the reference books are here on the shelves but no one is here using them </s> <s> They are just sitting </s> <s> So we are liberating them </s> <s> We 're going to let them out to anyone with a card just like other books magazines <weirdcaps> and <weirdcaps> </s> <s> The one precedent here is the liberating of the magazines a couple of decades ago </s> <s> We used to keep the magazines close for all the students doing reports and term papers </s> <s> We now have online databases with full texts and those days are long gone </s> <s> Finally it is time to free the reference books as well </s> <s> Our Adult Services librarians have <smiley> ent several weeks preparing to let reference books circulate </s> <s> With Sandy Frank is a <smiley> istance <smiley> he is the head of the circulation department we have inventoried the collection weeded out-of-date and worn-out materials and changed the circulation system status for each record </s> <s> The work is done and we are starting a quiet launch while we prepare marketing </s> <s> Here are reasons for this new service <smiley> e of reference books in the library has fallen off significantly in the past several years </s> <s> Librarians with acce <smiley> to online resources are using the print reference items le <smiley> frequently </s> <s> Fewer clients are <smiley> otted using reference books </s> <s> We reshelve reference books le <smiley> often </s> <s> The reference shelves rarely need straightening </s> <s> Clients occasionally ask to borrow the reference books so they can use them at home or work </s> <s> Much of the information in the reference books is available to us though our databases </s> <s> Reference librarians will still have resources to answer questions </s> <s> With le <smiley> money to buy nonfiction books this year it provides more items to loan students and other clients interested in nonfiction topics </s> <s> Other libraries have begun to loan their reference books </s> <s> Meetings at the <date> <weirdcaps> Conference in Chicago and posts on the Booklist blog Points of Referenc e have discu <smiley> ed the new trend </s> <s> The primary objection I have heard i <smiley> 'What if a book from a set doesn 't return isn 't the set ruined 'This is a po <smiley> ibility maybe even a probability in time </s> <s> Still having books sit idle seems a greater sorrow in a public library focused on current utility and not archival conservation </s> <s> I think the greater good will be served by this service </s> <s> I look froward to seeing some smiles when I let someone take a volume of Contemporary Literary Criticism or The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians </s> <s> We do not e <smiley> ect a rush of people coming for the reference books right away but we hope for steady use </s> <s> Maybe this liberation will even revive the section and make reference books worth buying again </s> <s> Ann Ni <kikoo> n Cooper died at age <date> in Atlanta in December <date> just before her book A Century and Some Change My Life Before the President Called My Name was published </s> <s> The positive view of her death is that she finished the book in time before she departed </s> <s> The premise of Nexus is that there is scientific evidence demonstrating how the network that links the six billion of us is not completely random in nature but actually has a certain structural configuration </s> <s> The author then demonstrates how such network structures are not just relevant for human acquaintanceship </s> <s> Buchanan introduces the argument by referring to a fascinating e <smiley> eriment conducted by the <smiley> ychologist Stanley Milgram in the <date> s </s> <s> I was familiar with Milgram for the famous test that bears his name yet was unaware he was also credited what came to be know the isix-degrees of separation ' </s> <s> In the Six-Degrees test Milgram mailed at random letters to people living in Omaha Nebraska and asked them to forward the letter to a stockbroker friend of his in Boston </s> <s> He provided no a 're <smiley> for the stockbroker but instead asked them to send it to someone who they believed to be isocially closer 'to him than they were </s> <s> Most of the letters made it to his friend as each subsequent recipient forwarded the letter to the next person a <smiley> lying the same request </s> <s> The most surprising a <smiley> ect was that it did not take hundre <smiley> of mailings but six </s> <s> It was then the work of two other academics Watts and Strogatz who when further studying Milgram is test found these six-degree connections to be neither orderly nor random but somewhere in between </s> <s> These patterns took on an even greater significance when they started examining other types of networks such as electric power gri <smiley> human brain cells or the world wide web only to discover clear similarities in all of them </s> <s> Before returning to the book let is look at an example given by one <s> Most likely it has some type of hierarchical structure of management </s> <s> Yet by looking at this pyramid does it really show how the organization is networked together It is true that the power </s> <s> These linchpins are the types of people you go to for questions information or advice and most certainly others turn to them as well </s> <s> If every person in the organization drew lines to each person they contacted throughout the day for a question or advice and then all of these drawing were compiled together you would see a web-like structure emerge </s> <s> In this web certain people would be crucial 'hub <smiley> 'as they would a <smiley> ear as being connected to a lot of other people as well </s> <s> Interestingly enough it is probably the people towar <smiley> the top of the pyramid who have the fewest connections to others in the organization </s> <s> This type of network formation exists in all the communities we interact with on a daily basis </s> <s> e <smiley> entially be grouped with more traditional bond types as their government balance sheets are in healthier shape than many more traditional markets e g </s> <s> Greece and Ireland </s> <s> To claim The Prize to be a book on the history of oil already by such definition limits the impact this commodity has had on the development of society over the last <date> years </s> <s> What it really is is an analysis of global economic and military history over this time period framed within the context of oil </s> <s> The book begins by concentrating on the historic period before World War I when Winston Churchill as civilian head of the Royal Navy began to see the importance of replacing the coal fired fleets of the British navy with those using oil in order to gain in <smiley> eed and agility </s> <s> Yergin chooses this as his starting point even though he then moves back 60 years to the true founding because this was an important turning point in how oil was used </s> <s> It was at this time when oil became a 'disruptive technology 'as it moved from an energy source mainly used for providing light to one that would become the standard form of fuel for all tran <smiley> ortation </s> <s> After this introduction The Prize returns to its chronological unfolding using as the starting point a key series of scientific discoveries regarding oil is potential uses and then later to the first wave of major U </s> <s> S </s> discoveries </s> <s> Though oil is history can be dated back long before this the foundation of oil as an industry and major fuel source has an American heritage </s> </s> <s> In <date> the Drake Well in central Pennsylvania was hit thus <smiley> arking the first wave of oil mania </s> <s> This mania brought all types of people from e <smiley> ert scientists and geologists to green thumb enthusiasts with nothing to lose </s> <s> The creation of boom towns in desolate parts of the U </s> <s> S </s> became common </s> <s> These towns would quickly be erected often to satisfy the nee <smiley> of the fortune seekers booze and prostitution </s> <s> Means for distributing the oil would be hastily devised with a very short term a <smiley> roach to get the black liquid to far off markets </s> <s> Once the source showed signs of reduced volumes or a bigger source was discovered elsewhere the towns would quickly find their streets and brothels empty </s> <s> The comparisons between the boom towns and the ma <smiley> ive cookie cutter neighborhoo <smiley> erected in the last five years in the States during our latest housing boom are strikingly similar </s> <s> The next part of the book e <smiley> lores how the fragmented industry from finding the oil to distributing it paved the way for on o <smiley> ortunity of ma <smiley> ive levels of consolidation and vertical integration </s> <s> It was seized and later e <smiley> loited mainly by one man - John Rockefeller of Standard Oil </s> <s> Rockefeller bought other oil companies both large and small keeping the efficient ones and merely closing down the others to limit any potential threat of competition </s> <s> Standard Oil was the first true monopoly in the U </s> <s> S controlling <math> of the oil derivative kerosene </s> <s> Its dominance led way to growing discontent of the American public who lacked alternatives to Standard Oil products and became more aware of the incredible fortune being ama <smiley> ed by Rockefeller as a result </s> <s> In <date> the Supreme Court ruled that Standard Oil be <smiley> lit into 32 different regional companies who would then compete with each other for customers and markets </s> <s> World War I was a very labor intensive struggle fought and won in the trenches with limited reliance on machinery </s> <s> World War <weirdcaps> as painted by Yergin was a war in which oil played a decisive role in the outcome </s> <s> Both Japan and Germany lacked domestic sources of oil and were therefore lubricant of our daily lives </s> <s> Ah France This novel with such French attitude scoffs at the wealthy for their shallowne <smiley> as well as their unmerited sense of cultural superiority over the social cla <smiley> es below them </s> <s> Barbery does this by focusing her story around two central character <smiley> the door-woman of an elegant resident building in central Paris and the <s> If you 're familiar with my last <weirdcaps> you 'll recall that the project was completed in only 4 days </s> <s> I recently had a chance to take another whack at it with a much more lenient deadline and I 'm very very ha <smiley> y with the results </s> <s> The basic ste <smiley> at the beginning were the same as my last build </s> <s> Make a blueprint transcribe it to wood and start cutting gluing and clamping </s> <s> I did discover a random and somewhat neat trick for scribing the lines on this though </s> <s> By printing to vellum on an injket printer I was able to directly transfer the pattern of the print from the paper to the wood </s> <s> <smiley> ing laquer thinner brushed over the ink I burnished the paper against the <weirdcaps> and the lines transferred perfectly Made transcribing my blueprints <weirdcaps> easier </s> <s> The main difference between this build and my last is the materials used </s> <s> Outside of the stock base barrel grip and <weirdcaps> cell all other parts were made from sintra styrene or aluminum </s> <s> These materials can take detail much better than <weirdcaps> which afforded me a lot of control in making the shape more accurate </s> <s> I also decided to use <weirdcaps> for a glowing barrel effect </s> <s> This was a preliminary test-fire to see how the idea would work </s> <s> In the end I used the lens out of a laser pointer behind the center hole in the barrel to focus the light and make it brighter in that <smiley> ot </s> <s> After the barrel and stock were shaped to the correct dimensions I started a 'ing details in sintra amp styrene </s> <s> The rounded edges on the back and front parts were made by gluing the sintra into a box and rounding the edges on my table router </s> <s> Another huge difference in this build was my new lathe </s> <s> The <weirdcaps> has a <weirdcaps> of little rounded bits all over it </s> <s> These were cut out of <weirdcaps> or sintra </s> <s> The microfusion cell is 4 pieces of <weirdcaps> glued together and shaped on the lathe as well </s> <s> This rear knob is also lathed <weirdcaps> </s> <s> The tube which sits on top of the barrel is an <weirdcaps> rod </s> <s> This was a lot easier to shape than the <date> isteel tube I used on the last build </s> <s> Here is most of the parts going on for a test fit </s> <s> The grip is an <weirdcaps> block with sintra stri <smiley> shaped over it </s> <s> To keep a uniform shape I heat-formed one sheet over the entire grip then cut it into stri <smiley> on my ban <smiley> aw </s> <s> The rear of the barrel is a sintra box with styrene accents </s> <s> The curved part behind the <weirdcaps> cell was sculpted out of apoxie sculpt and sanded to shape </s> <s> Various other smaller bits were shaped out of sintra styrene before going to primer </s> <s> Below is the trigger amp trigger arm <weirdcaps> cell area barrel cell eject lever and other bits </s> <s> I also scribed the panel lines on the parts with a lino block carving tool I had left over from my art school days </s> <s> Another test a <smiley> embly after all the parts had been primed </s> <s> I had some really tight tolerances when putting it together as the layers of paint actually made it quite hard to get the front and rear casings over the barrel </s> <s> Yay precision To power the <weirdcaps> I used 2 <weirdcaps> batteries housed in an in-line battery holder </s> <s> The knob on the back of the gun unscrews to reveal the battery door to replace the cells </s> <s> I was very very ha <smiley> y with how this turned out </s> <s> The <weirdcaps> are switched on and off by a hi 'en pushbutton switch on the bottom of the rifle barrel </s> <s> The last lathed part was the bottom su <smiley> ort bar </s> <s> This was carved from a pine dowel and cored out to receive a hollow aluminum bar </s> <s> Styrene accents finished it off </s> <s> I also found some knurled nuts to use for the two circular parts on the su <smiley> ort bar and <weirdcaps> welded them in place </s> <s> On to paint The basecoat silver was done with Krylon chrome paint </s> <s> After this I dusted the surface with a darker silver by holding the can about 2 feet away from the part and <smiley> raying lightly over the entire surface </s> <s> This gave the paint a sti <smiley> led texture like cast aluminum would have this is shown a little better on the front barrel casing in the shot below with the barrel painted green Color was done with Testors <smiley> ray paint for the barrel which is annoyingly thin and loves to run and Testors brush paint for the silver on the <weirdcaps> cell and u <smiley> er pipe </s> <s> After this each individual part got a coat of clear to protect the finish </s> <s> I know I 'm going to get a ton of decal questions so I hope this answers them preemptively </s> <s> It seems like custom decals are the bane of every replica maker and it took me a bit to figure out the best way to do it as well </s> <s> As with my Portal Gun the <weirdcaps> got water-slide decals on the <weirdcaps> cell for the warning me <smiley> ages arrows and stripe </s> <s> These were designed in Adobe Photoshop and printed onto water-slide decal paper on a laserjet printer </s> <s> The barrel decals were done differently </s> <s> The barrel was scanned on a computer scanner to pick up the color amp texture of the paint </s> <s> Then I designed the side decals in Illustrator taking them into Photoshop to layer them over the green background and weather them a bit before printing </s> <s> These were output on adhesive-backed vinyl using a plotter then a <smiley> lied to the gun </s> <s> There is a slight seam line around the sides of these but its only evident under close in <smiley> ection </s> <s> Here is the gun all a <smiley> embled and shiny brand-new So pretty so clean </s> <s> So nee <smiley> a few coats of grime </s> <s> This was the first pa <smiley> </s> <s> Another new tool I had for this build was an airbrush </s> <s> I 'd never used one before so this was as much a practice run as it was a weathering effort </s> <s> It took some getting used to but I was very satisfied with the results </s> <s> <weirdcaps> If you don 't seal inkjet decals before acrylic paint weathering they will run amp bleed This is why I clearcoated the gun before this proce <smiley> </s> <s> I also made a di <smiley> lay board for the gun to sit on in maple </s> <s> This was stained satin black </s> <s> Here is the final shots of the gun after all the weathering was completed and given another coat of clear to protect the finish </s> <s> I am very glad I got to revisit this piece but I don 't think I 'll be making another one </s> 2 was plenty for me and its time to try another project with things I had to farm out to other vendors and craftsmen </s> <s> <smiley> ecifically the chrome gold plating of the resin and the vacuum-forming of the visors </s> <s> I don 't po <smiley> e <smiley> while </s> <s> A commi <smiley> ion came to me very very last minute for a good friend of mine </s> <s> He was planning on doing a Vault Dweller costume from Fallout 3 and needed a weapon in a month blueprints but thats a story for when I take on this project again in the future and give it the proper time it deserves </s> <s> In order to save time my friend came over and traced my blueprints onto <weirdcaps> </s> <s> I taught him how to use a ban <smiley> aw nothing like a crash course in something that can leave you fingerle <smiley> and he went to town rough-cutting the shapes I 'd refine later into the gun </s> <s> Here is where we starte <smiley> Impre <smiley> ive right I had a sick idea of just scotch-taping all these together painting the whole thing silver and handing it to him the day of the convention </s> but I 'm not that mean </s> <s> Ignore the lighter pieces near the bottom - those are part of another build </s> <s> After cleaning up the cuts on a belt sander I began the a <smiley> embly of the main body in the 2 most prominent parts - the square 'barrel 'and the rear stock </s> <s> These are both made from <math> ' <weirdcaps> </s> <s> The barrel has a few sections cut out for the microfusion cell </s> and a <smiley> ace for the rear stock and lower receiver to mount I used a table router to re-shape the holes in the stock and bevel the edges </s> <s> This was also a low-budget build so I didn 't have the liberty of going out and buying fancy new holesaws </s> <s> The lower su <smiley> ort rod was made out of varying sized of pine dowel threaded over a <math> 'aluminum bar </s> <s> The front grip was made from 2 pieces of <math> ' <weirdcaps> screwed together and shaped on a belt sander </s> <s> Styrene will eventually make up the grip texture </s> <s> The microfusion cell was pieced together from some pre-existing elements </s> <s> I had a small dome mold that I 'm using on another project that ha <smiley> ened to be pretty close </s> <s> I pulled two of these and epoxied them around some 2 ' <weirdcaps> pipe </s> <s> <weirdcaps> discs were affixed to the main body to make the housing around the cell </s> <s> At this point it started to resemble the final product This is about 6 hours into the build Yes I 'm using 'buil <smiley> 'as a noun Colloquial English take that grammar sticklers Styrene was a 'ed to the lower grip as well as the cell eject lever and front barrel area for the raised textures The u <smiley> er barrel pipe was made out of <math> isteel pipe </s> <s> This terminates into a lathed pine dowel glued to the barrel corner If you 're wondering why some of these shots are so dark recall that the 'extra time 'I found to build this came when I should have been sleeping </s> <s> The bulk of this project was done between 10pm and 1am on most days </s> <s> After a coat of primer and some sanding I started scribing panel lines with a dremel tool and a 'ing screw rece <smiley> es around the front of the barrel </s> <s> Other details were a 'ed in <weirdcaps> around the cell loading chamber and the rear part of this area was faired down into the barrel of the gun with apoxie sculpt </s> <s> I also a 'ed the raised pucks on the grip and stock </s> <s> Rece <smiley> ed areas were drilled into the gun and filled with countersunk philli <smiley> screws More styrene and <weirdcaps> pieces were a 'ed to the barrel and rear area of the gun to build up the details in these areas </s> <s> The shapes of these were largely improvised as by this point I only had 4 days left until my deadline with many other projects that needed completing </s> <s> After this the whole gun received a coat of gray primer to seal the remaining e <smiley> osed wood </s> <s> The first coat of paint went on shortly after the above finished drying </s> <s> I used Krylon hammered silver followed by a coat of Testor is Olive Drab on the main barrel </s> <s> Fortunately for me these guns are su <smiley> osed to be <date> years old in the Fallout 3 universe </s> <s> That means its time for my favorite thing of all </s> heavy weathering The basecoat of weathering was done with acrylic paints and matte gel medium </s> <s> I did an initial coat of black followed by browns and greens to simulate dirt and corrosion </s> <s> After this dried I gave the whole piece drybrush silver accents to simulate wear and tear from the wastelan <smiley> </s> chi <smiley> ing away at the paint and caked-on dirt </s> <s> The finished piece has a nice shimmer to the metallic silver drybrush which simulates metal rather well </s> <s> Finally some more shots of the finished product from a few different angles </s> <s> I 'm still looking for a good way to transfer my vector decals to the gun </s> <s> I tried water-slide as with my Portal gun build but yellow ink on top of dark green showed up very poorly </s> <s> There are a lot of details mi <smiley> ing from the final product so I want to return to this prop someday and build it without such an insane time restriction I really wish I could have given this project a bit more time and been more dedicated to the intricate detail this gun has but for a 4 day build this turned out better than I could have hoped </s> <s> Ha <smiley> y Super Mutant Hunting Wait </s> you know </s> <s> I had this whole thing written out and then I went to preview the blog entry and something just didn 't look right </s> <s> The rifle was weathered but it still looked too clean on that white background </s> <s> The graphics of the Fallout games do a good job of making the weapons look blackened but I felt like this needed a bit more </s> <s> I went back after thinking about it and decided to a ' some rust to the <weirdcaps> </s> <s> The shots above is how the gun was delivered and shown at the convention </s> <s> Here is how it sits now And just for the hell of it a modified version of one shot in the 'Fallout 3 'graphic style Higher res pic <weirdcaps> and more high-res shots of the build proce <smiley> available on my flickr page Ok <weirdcaps> we 're done I finally lost my mind enough to try to tackle one of these big guys </s> <s> For those unfamiliar Big Da 'ys are the protectors of the Little Sisters in Rapture an underwater city devoid of morality which has degenerated into chaos and insanity </s> <s> They are huge fast strong and as it turns out a solid pain in the a <smiley> to build </s> <s> I 'm going to break with tradition for a sec and show you the finished product first </s> <s> This is a long long long post that details nearly 7 solid weeks of work and you guys deserve to know that the long post is quite nece <smiley> ary and I think well worth the read </s> <s> Credit goes to iscenemi <smiley> ingmagazine 'on Flickr for this amazing photograph High-rez shot here So here is how I did it </s> <s> First thing is first I needed blueprints </s> <s> I built these in Illustrator based off some very good reference images that the guys at <weirdcaps> published in their artbook <smiley> Since this is such a large project I 'll break down the build proce <smiley> into partition <smiley> The main body the dome the drill arm the dome cage other details and the final paintwork </s> <s> The Main Body Starting with the blueprints printed at full scale <weirdcaps> I made cro <smiley> sections out of insulation foam and glued them into place </s> <s> The empty areas between sections were filled with cardboard </s> <s> This formed what I called the iskeleton 'of the body </s> <s> The empty cavities in the skeleton were then filled in with e <smiley> anding foam After drying the foam was carved into the shape of the main body After this was completed and the foam given more drying time so it would retain its shape the entire form was covered in stretch fabric </s> <s> This smoothed out a lot of the lumpine <smiley> of the foam Accent areas around the arms legs and top of the body were made out of insulation foam then glued to the body </s> <s> Before coating with paint or fibergla <smiley> resin these were covered with Ureshell to prevent the poly foam from di <smiley> olving </s> <s> Certain areas on the body itself were also given a coat of Ureshell so they would not disintegrate </s> <s> After this was dry the entire body piece was given several a <smiley> lications of fibergla <smiley> resin </s> <s> The front flap was a 'ed using more insulation foam and also given a coat of Ureshell and resin </s> <s> After this was dry I began hollowing out the foam and cardboard </s> <s> After a 'ing some details on the body with foam tape more ureshell and more resin I had a finished form The Dome I started with a 24 ismoked security camera dome off of <weirdcaps> </s> <s> This came from a demolished sho <smiley> ing center and are actually hard to track down these days given the much smaller size of most security cameras </s> <s> I remember these all over the place as a kid </s> <s> I was sent two of them for some reason so if anyone wants the second one just let me know </s> <s> After trimming the square edge off I cut a disc from insulation foam to serve as the 'ring 'around the dome </s> <s> I made resin copies of wingnuts which were glued into place on the trim ring </s> <s> About 15 of these resin duplicates weighed as much as a single wingnut </s> <s> Since I had to wear this thing every ounce saved counted For the portholes I made a single master out of <weirdcaps> and <weirdcaps> wood </s> which I molded in silicone </s> <s> The portholes were all slush-cast to save weight and time in production </s> <s> Also this way they 're completely identical </s> <s> The tape here is marking the <smiley> acing of the portholes After coating the dome in resin to thicken it a bit I trimmed the porthole-holes with a dremel </s> <s> The dome was a very brittle acrylic so this was a nerve-wracking proce <smiley> The drill arm Unfortunately since this project was done in such a hurry my proce <smiley> photography was somewhat lacking </s> <s> The drill started out as an aluminum rod with 4 triangles of matteboard affixed to it </s> <s> Rings of foam were made around the matteboard then paper layered on top of that to create the cone shape </s> <s> The actual 'blade 'of the drill bit is made from masking tape which has been layered in small sections to follow the curve of the drill sides </s> <s> This piece was coated in several layers of fibergla <smiley> resin <smiley> ome with tinting to check coverage To create a really worn look I a 'ed bits of debris to the fibergla <smiley> resin </s> <s> This made a convincing textured metal finish in the end as these parts were painted to look like rust dents and bits of <smiley> licer </s> <s> A <weirdcaps> cage and old <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> cordle <smiley> drill make up the su <smiley> ort frame and motor for the drill </s> <s> I moved the battery inside the body of the suit to save on weight hanging from my arms </s> <s> The 'housing 'for this mechanism was made from a concrete tube electrical conduit <weirdcaps> and more foam tape </s> <s> This was painted in ureshell to protect it during painting as well as to give it texture </s> <s> The Dome Cage This was constructed mainly out of <weirdcaps> electrical conduit </s> <s> This pipe is gray in color and takes heat and bending much better than standard white <weirdcaps> tubing </s> <s> I bought 40 feet of it for this project and ended up using about 35 </s> <s> At only <date> feet though this was an easy buy </s> <s> The sides terminate into 3 ' <weirdcaps> couplers </s> <s> These slide over 3 ' <weirdcaps> pipe anchored to the body that has been notched to be a sightly smaller diameter than 3 ' </s> <s> Since the wearer has to enter through the front porthole the dome as well as the cage must be removable </s> <s> The front of the cage is friction-fit at the top and bottom anchorpoints as well as the sides so it can easily be put on and taken off </s> <s> A quick test of the body dome and cage </s> <s> This is after the dome has had all portholes carved out and secured </s> <s> Other Details An animatronic hand and arm extension were created for the left side of the suit </s> <s> This would help prevent the istubby arm 'look I 've seen on other Big Da 'y suit buil <smiley> The rear tank was made from a 12 'concrete tube with foam plugs on the top and bottom carved to a dome shape </s> <s> The ban <smiley> around the tank were made with foam tape coated in Ureshell </s> <s> I made a pushmold of some bolt hea <smiley> for texture these were cast in resin and a 'ed to the tank as well as the banding on the main body </s> <s> Bolthea <smiley> and a first coat of paint on the tank </s> <s> The wheel at the top is a cake decoration from our local supermarket </s> <s> The boots were made from more insulation foam </s> <s> These give me about 6 'of lift and make the feet look proportional to the rest of Big Da 'y </s> <s> On pages <math> of Moral Panics and the Copyright Wars I discu <smiley> the aftermath of the shutdown of Na <smiley> ter in <date> </s> <s> This period is interesting because it presented the music industry with something of a cro <smiley> roa <smiley> Na <smiley> ter had demonstrated there was a huge potential market for digital distribution of singles </s> <s> I use the word potential because the trick was converting the free Na <smiley> ter model into a paying one </s> <s> I use cro <smiley> roa <smiley> because there were two fundamental choice <smiley> either <math> ignore this potential market in the hope that if it was shut off by having enjoined illegal services and by not offering legal alternative <smiley> the industry could go back to things the way they were that is selling <weirdcaps> or <math> realizing that the market for digital singles was the future and had to be served </s> <s> This latter choice by the way did not mean ending the immediate sale of <weirdcaps> but it did mean that the industry would have itself have participated in the offering of a product <smiley> ingle <smiley> that made <weirdcaps> le <smiley> attractive </s> <s> For an industry that is so big on control one would have thought that the rational choice was to at least participate in the new market at its inception and thereby have some measure of control over the phasing out of one product as the next takes over </s> <s> As I noted on page 5 of Moral Panics Ruth Handler co-founder of Mattel and creator of the Barbie doll observe ' <weirdcaps> can manage the u <smiley> ide cycle </s> <s> The secret is managing a product down its life cycle properly 'And all products have life cycles suing tens of thousan <smiley> of your customers may fend off the inevitable decline for a short period of time but the cycle will win because one thing copyright infringement actions can never do is make people buy a product they do not want </s> <s> The record industry is failure to adapt to the next product digital singles was suicidal </s> <s> There is controversy over how the decision not to jump into the digital singles market took place that is whether there were collusive efforts to impede the new market </s> <s> I have no <smiley> ecial knowledge on this and therefore have to rely on published sources whose accuracy is also in question but by not taking the rational option -- serving the new market -- the industry left the market to be served illegally and I use 'illegally 'deliberately in place of the le <smiley> judgmental wor <smiley> 'unauthorize <smiley> ' </s> <s> The industry didn 't sit back entirely though two online services were eventually created <weirdcaps> and <weirdcaps> </s> <s> These services were doomed to fail There was a time when Netflix had a great busine <smiley> model instead of having to get in your car schlep to the nearest video rental store pay late fees and compete with others for the latest blockbuster movie because as the name Blockbuster Video implied there wasn 't a lot of anything else you could from the comfort of your home order movies to be mailed to your house </s> <s> For a monthly subscription fee you could keep them without paying late fees this helped Netflix too by cutting down on its postage cost <smiley> and the selection was also long-tail </s> <s> As a result I rented watched many many more movies than I would have </s> <s> However in the wake of its deal with Warner in which Netflix agreed to a 28 day embargo on renting the latest movies in exchange for reduced <weirdcaps> purchase costs I have cancelled my subscription </s> <s> Netfli <smiley> is new busine <smiley> model is a <smiley> arently the old busine <smiley> model of busine <smiley> es first consumers last </s> <s> I e <smiley> ect the new busine <smiley> model will also be bad for Netflix and the studios </s> <s> Instead of watching movies I will do something else </s> <s> Nor does something they don 't want to do buy </s> <s> I doubt it </s> <s> I rented movies to watch them once </s> <s> If I couldn 't rent them I didn 't buy them </s> <s> Why not Because movies are just not important in the larger scheme of life or even the smaller scheme of consumer behavior movies are merely entertainment and usually trivial entertainment that doesn 't warrant going out of your way to accommodate a scheme set up to frustrate your desires </s> <s> If I couldn 't rent a movie I did something else and usually did that something else first anyway </s> <s> Picking up a book practicing clarinet reading the New Yorker are all perfectly fine and usually better alternatives </s> <s> And if I did want to buy a movie I would do it regardle <smiley> of whether I could rent it so the idea offering me what I want and that is what I have done by cancelling my Netflix subscription not out of <smiley> ite or anger its too trivial to get u <smiley> et about anyway but because its the wrong Conclusion <date> The first chapter like most first chapters of books sets out what the problems are </s> <s> This is as far as most reviewers go and they don 't even go very far into the first chapter </s> <s> In identifying what the problems are the purpose is not as Nate is review suggests and too many others believe to attack copyright </s> <s> Instead the why of the Copyright Wars is described as being economic </s> <s> On page 36 I state The economic conflict at the heart of the Copyright Wars lies in what economist Joseph Schumpeter termed 'creative destruction ' the introduction of innovative products and busine <smiley> models that di <smiley> lace old ones </s> <s> Far from being a threat to capitalism Schumpeter is great insight was that creative destruction 'ince <smiley> antly revolutionizes the economic structure from within ince <smiley> antly destroying the old one ince <smiley> antly creative a new one </s> <s> This proce <smiley> of creative destruction is the e <smiley> ential fact about capitalism </s> <s> It is what capitalism consists in and what every capitalist concern has got to live in ' 'Capitalism is Schumpeter described 'by nature a </s> </s> </s> method of economic change and not only never is but can never be stationary ' 'Stabilized capitalism is a contradiction in terms ' As an inherent fact 'every company must prepare the way for its own disruption ' Innovation the root cause of creative destruction is thus the way capitalism survives its own inherent tendency toward monopolization and stagnation even as innovation is regarded as an existential threat to those who benefit from the status quo </s> <s> In Schumpeter is wor <smiley> 'a new firm is intrusion into an existing industry always entails warring ' with an old <smiley> here ' which tries to prohibit discredit or otherwise restrict every advantage afforded to the new form by its innovation </s> <s> Given the inevitability of such counter-innovative instincts by existing busine <smiley> in order to ensure the continued vitality of innovation and capitalism itself we must encourage innovation rather than try to kill it off as the copyright industries do </s> <s> I follow this up in chapter 9 with a much more detailed discu <smiley> ion of Schumpeter and the economics of the Copyright Wars </s> <s> On page <date> I place copyright owners within this context stating This is not to suggest that the copyright industries are venal quite the contrary it is to argue that they are all too normal </s> <s> Distorted incentives lead to distorted conduct because our current copyright laws provide rights and remedies that are far beyond what is nece <smiley> ary for copyright owners to recoup their investments and make re <smiley> ectable profits and instead give copyright owners powerful weapons to quash competition and control consumers we should not be surprised that the copyright industries utilize those weapons and then some </s> <s> In this re <smiley> ect the copyright industries are no different than Wall Street or any other company placed in a similar situation </s> In Nate is review there is not a single mention of book is economic analysis even though it is the heart of the book </s> <s> There is not a single mention of the book is extensive examination of the economic evidence presented by copyright owners and this is indeed ironic given that I quote from Ars Technica is own leading work on this </s> <s> See pages <date> of the book </s> Nor is there any discu <smiley> ion of the book is emphasis on the different nature of marketing in the content industries and in other consumer-first industries </s> <s> I discu <smiley> the work of Harvard Busine <smiley> School profe <smiley> or Theodore Levitt </s> <s> I say on page 23 is it too much to read 23 pages <punctuationfreak> <smiley> 'Although usually written about as battles over technology or principles the Copyright Wars are instead centrally rooted what Harvard Busine <smiley> School profe <smiley> or Theodore Levitt called marketing myopia ' I then discu <smiley> these theories including Levitt is own take on Hollywood </s> <s> But rather than simply say that some content owners are bad bad bad I try to understand the source of the problem </s> <s> Here is what I say on page 26 The myopia stems from corporate copyright owner <smiley> ' adoption of control as their principal busine <smiley> model closed systems in which copyright owners tightly control everything connected to their work <smiley> which play back devices will be offered to the public what types of acce <smiley> controls will be interposed before consumers can ever see hear or in the case of books or other literary works even read a sni <smiley> et of the work the time period during which consumers will have acce <smiley> to the work how many times can consumers see hear or read the work in what format will consumers be able to acce <smiley> the work what will they be able to do with the work once they finally acce <smiley> it Can they copy reasonable portions for criticism and comment can they make personal use copies or copies for use on other devices can they use parts of the work to make other new works including mash-u <smiley> I then tie this in turn into the mantra that content is king and instead a <smiley> ert that the consumer is king simply because copyright cannot be used to get a single consumer to buy anything </s> <s> It is only consumer demand for products or services that gets copyright owners money </s> <s> I have said over and over again that I want copyright owners to succeed and that we all should want copyright owners to succeed but by satisfying consumer demand not by thwarting it </s> <s> Nate is review has no discu <smiley> ion of this part of the book at all even though it is a central thesis of the book </s> <s> Instead we have below-the-belt shots like the end of the review The views may not be Google is but it is not hard to see why Patry has landed at an aggregator and indexer of content rather than a creator of it </s> <s> Which in a way is too bad making him the top lawyer at the <weirdcaps> or <weirdcaps> would be fascinating to watch though we 're doubtful that those atop the big content industries share his easy confidence that innovation quickly produces greater profits or that le <smiley> copyright law 'can be 'better copyright law 'Nate is referring to the disclaimer in the book which states the book represents my views not Google is </s> <s> The above quote from his review is designed to both acknowledge that disclaimer and deny it in the same breath </s> <s> There is nothing in the book that advocates for le <smiley> copyright law a sentiment I in fact criticize </s> <s> Instead I argue for effective copyright laws </s> <smiley> ages <date> </s> We all benefit from effective copyright laws and we all suffer from ineffective laws </s> <s> What I di <smiley> ute is that copyright is a zero sum game but that argument like advocating effective copyright laws doesn 't make good pre <smiley> </s> <s> Here is what I actually say For policy makers and the public copyright is not a winner-takes-all proposition </s> <s> Copyright is a system to advance public interests those interests can be furthered by a copyright regime tailored to provide sufficient incentives to create new works </s> <smiley> age <math> </s> <s> That is a far cry from simply shilling for aggregators a term I reject anyway or calling for le <smiley> copyright law </s> <s> Nor is there any discu <smiley> ion in the review of chapters 5 and 6 of the book which discu <smiley> the implications of the debate about copyright as property and in which I instead take the view that copyright is a set of social relationshi <smiley> </s> <s> The purpose of viewing copyright that way is again not to take sides but rather to call for debating the i <smiley> ues on the merits </s> <s> Hence on page <date> I say 'The advantage in regarding copyright as a system of social relationshi <smiley> is that it focuses attention where it belong <smiley> in mediating conflicts within that system ' Such an a <smiley> roach does not favor aggregators or content owners but rather asks that we consider the effects of legislation on society as a whole a whole that includes everyone as a istakeholder ' to use a current buzzword </s> <s> Does that view stem from being employed by Google does it favor Google Obviously not but one would never know that is my view from the review </s> <s> Finally what about the book is own use of metaphors Is it indicative that I unwittingly fell prey to the very tactic I su <smiley> osedly condemn I don 't know how to re <smiley> ond to such a ridiculous question </s> <s> It a <smiley> umes that in writing a book that focuses on language I was unaware of the very language I was using and how it would be perceived by others and that reviewers -- who have neither done their own research nor written their own books somehow managed to burrow into the book and come up with a gotcha in your dreams </s> Here is what I say about this exact point having anticipated it in the book itself mind you <smiley> The danger of conceptual metaphors in law is easy to identify </s> <s> Inferences inherent in the source domain <smiley> ay shark <smiley> are automatically ma <smiley> ed onto the target domain <smiley> ay lawyer <smiley> where they become an inherent part of how we reason about the target domain lawyers are shark <smiley> </s> <s> This proce <smiley> is not one of comparison where we merely note similarities and differences between two preexisting categories like chicken and pheasant instead the ma <smiley> ing of inferences from the source to the target domain creates meaning in the target domain that did not exist before </s> <s> Such ma <smiley> ing however may not always be apt it may in fact be horribly wrong </s> <s> Lord Palmerston once qui <smiley> e <smiley> 'Half the wrong a <smiley> umptions at which mankind arrive are reached by the abuse of metaphors and by mistaking general resemblance or imaginary similarity for real identity ' In la </s> </s>

complete with a trackpad and mini keyboard </s> <s> Mostly I use it for presentations it frees me to walk around the cla <smiley> during cla <smiley> discu <smiley> ions and demonstrations </s> <s> However anything you can do on your computer you can now do from anywhere in the cla <smiley> </s> <s> This works much better and is a huge improvement over Remote Pad which I had recommended last year </s> <s> The Oblique Strategies is a digital version of Brian Eno is card stack for overcoming creative blocks </s> <s> Simple and universally a <smiley> licable phrases help you think of ways to a <smiley> roach your projects in new ways </s> <s> When I 've been discu <smiley> ing ideas with my students I 've occasionally pulled out the Oblique Strategies to help them dig deeper into their ideas </s> <s> Sometimes it falls flat but sometimes it provides an eerily helpful per <smiley> ective </s> <s> An alternative to this is an a <smiley> called Methodology which is basically the same thing and might even be a rip-off of the Oblique Strategies but the one advantage to it is that it randomizes the card stack re <smiley> onses </s> <s> Yet another version of this is the Creative Whack Pack </s> <s> This has a nice design and e <smiley> lanation of the suggestions it makes but overall hasn 't generated as interesting re <smiley> onses for my cla <smiley> es as the Oblique Strategies has </s> <s> The suggestions are more general ways to think creatively </s> <s> Do you have any projects that include storytelling The Idea Generator mentioned here before also has an more intuitive program and easier to manipulate </s> <s> Similarly Layers has an interface like Brushes but has a great visualization for looking at layers as stacked gla <smiley> slides </s> <s> This is a fantastic way of helping students understand how layers work in programs like Photoshop Flash or Final Cut </s> <s> If you can 't get enough of painting programs Asian Painting is also a neat a <date> was a crazy year for me </s> It was a good year for me </s> In <date> this blog seemed to find its place </s> Through things that seem as trivial as a twitter account or a podcast I met people your crew has looked forward to for days </s> <s> The plan is to hit a string of new restaurants eating as much as you can then to <smiley> ing it all off with bourbon and shameful behavior </s> <s> some tasty fried bits the required offal dish a polite terrine </s> <s> But the in the past hour things have taken a turn </s> <s> There was raw fish paired with fried cheese </s> <s> There was a risotto that was so rich and salty that your fish cook polished off the wine straight from the bottle </s> <s> And the lamb sa 'le was so over-techniqued that your best-of-frien <smiley> hot a
