dude Damien in their kitchen </s> <s> I hate that guy 'Bad food stays with you </s> <s> It haunts you </s> <s> You feel violated--your precious time and money wasted </s> <s> It is made even worse when frien <smiley> or e <smiley> ectations are involved </s> <s> And it is something that you are more likely to e <smiley> erience as the craft of cooking e <smiley> an <smiley> and evolves </s> <s> But why Is it as simple as a cook that doesn 't care or that isn 't truly pa <smiley> ionate about their craft Of course </s> <s> But I think in most cases it is something else completely </s> <s> Bad cooking ha <smiley> ens when things fall out of balance </s> <s> Temperature </s> <s> Tastes </s> <s> Textures </s> <s> A cook is focus </s> <s> A cook is attitude </s> <s> Have you ever eaten a meal with so much technique that the kitchen forgot about the actual taste Have you ever had a meal so rustic you were left wondering if the kitchen was just slo <smiley> ing it out Remember that night on the line where you were so focused on your meat tem <smiley> that your veg was constantly scorched Remember that night on the line when you were having so much fun that you kept forgetting to a ' that garnish you worked on for an hour Balance is e <smiley> ential to good cooking--on every level and in every position </s> <s> It is the most difficult thing to achieve--and when it is ha <smiley> ening it is almost invisible </s> <s> A cook is personality in general is not balanced </s> <s> A group of people given to such highs and lows and dedicated only to pleasure and sensuality where do you find balance in that As cooks comes to know themselves their awarene <smiley> of balance slowly starts to reveal itself </s> <s> They can feel the push and pull of their own emotions </s> <s> Their heart swells and almost bursts when things are good and shatters to pieces when things are bad--but they find a way to stay anchored in the mi 'le head down with only a deep breath as evidence that they 're feeling anything at all </s> <s> Coercing their mind into this mental mi 'le ground starts to translate into the pan then onto the plate </s> <s> The quiet balance in the cooks mind tells them when to hold back and when to push--be it with seasoning <smiley> eed or technique </s> <s> It is a mental high wire act that is exhausting with far greater consequences </s> <s> If you fall off the wire you die </s> <s> Big deal </s> <s> If you cook bad food you 've lost guests and shamed your kitchen </s> <s> You actually have to live with that </s> <s> Some cooks never find balance--and that is ok with them </s> <s> They produce food that they 're ha <smiley> y with--and that the vast majority of diners would be ha <smiley> y to eat </s> <s> But if the goal is to get better to progre <smiley> to contribute then isn 't it important to find a sustainable method for mentally and physically producing your craft If the goal is to be the best and create great food then isn 't balance the most important ingredient notes </s> sometimes indie music is indie because it completely sucks something I did not anticipate about losing weight none of my clothes fitting anymore <s> The newest State of the Bir <smiley> report is out and the news is not good </s> <s> The <date> Report concludes that accelerated climate change continues to alter the natural world as we know it diminishing the quality of our environment and leaving a lasting impact on many bird <smiley> ecies </s> <s> The new report was released this week by United States Secretary of the Interior Ken Salazar </s> 'Just as they did in <date> when Rachel Carson published Silent <smiley> ring our migratory bir <smiley> are sending us a me <smiley> age about the health of our planet ' Salazar said </s> 'That is why--for the first time ever--the Department of the Interior has deployed a coordinated strategy to plan for and re <smiley> ond to the impacts of climate change on the resources we manage ' Key findings from the 'State of the Bir <smiley> ' climate change report include Oceanic bir <smiley> are among the most vulnerable <smiley> ecies because they don 't raise many young each year they face challenges from a rapidly changing marine ecosystem and they nest on islan <smiley> that may be flooded as sea levels rise </s> <s> All 67 oceanic bird <smiley> ecies such as petrels and albatro <smiley> es are among the most vulnerable bir <smiley> on Earth to climate change </s> Hawaiian bir <smiley> such as endangered <smiley> ecies Puaiohi and 'Akiap l 'au already face multiple threats and are increasingly challenged by mosquito-borne diseases and invasive <smiley> ecies as climate change alters their native habitats </s> Bir <smiley> in coastal arctic alpine and gra <smiley> land habitats as well as those on Caribbean and other Pacific islan <smiley> show intermediate levels of vulnerability most bir <smiley> in aridlan <smiley> wetlan <smiley> and forests show relatively low vulnerability to climate change </s> For bird <smiley> ecies that are already of conservation concern such as the golden-cheeked warbler whooping crane and <smiley> ectacled eider the a 'ed vulnerability to climate change may hasten declines or prevent recovery </s> The report identified common bird <smiley> ecies such as the American oystercatcher common nighthawk and northern pintail that are likely to become <smiley> ecies of conservation concern as a result of climate change </s> <s> The report is a collaborative effort as part of the U </s> <s> S </s> <s> North American Bird Conservation Initiative between federal and state wildlife agencies and scientific and conservation organizations including partners from the American Bird Conservancy A <smiley> ociation of Fish and Wildlife Agencies Cornell Lab of Ornithology Klamath Bird Observatory National Audubon Society The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation The Nature Conservancy U </s> <s> S </s> <s> D </s> <s> A Ti <smiley> - Resources for Promotion This post originally a <smiley> eared on htt <smiley> surveihiphop blog <smiley> ot com Communication is not really a istep 'but it is one of the most important things </s> <s> In the Hip Hop Hunger event it was my fault that for the longest time I didn 't know that my school is portable stage wasn 't stable enough for ra <smiley> ing and dancing so I found that out with only a week before the event will ha <smiley> en </s> <s> As I write this I 'm writing this on Friday Feb <math> I 'm wondering if someone will be able to donate a portable stage on Wedne <smiley> ay </s> <s> Other than this things have ran smoothly because of early communication </s> <s> If this is your first event you 're planning you should probably talk with some people you know who have event e <smiley> erience and ask them if they can give you advice </s> <s> My frien <smiley> who are in a rock band called Supersonia have had many succe <smiley> ful events about two per year from sophomore year to senior year </s> <s> Before I planned the Hip Hop Hunger Event I sat down with one of them at a coffee shop and took notes about how to plan an event </s> <s> So if you know someone at your school who is done something remotely similar to what you are planning then talk with them </s> <s> Forms of Communication The type of communication you have with people will depend on your event and your goals </s> <s> In the Hip Hop Hunger event it was my goal to get some big name acts at it and I used email with them </s> <s> It doesn 't hurt to ask e <smiley> ecially if it is for charity </s> <s> It doesn 't hurt to have at least that small connection with someone in which you invited them to come but they couldn 't make it </s> <s> If the event is for-profit as o <smiley> osed to for-charity you will have to figure out your budget because then it is likely you would pay the artists </s> If the event is not some sort of fundraiser or charity event and you want to do it at school you might have to pay the school or venue I also contacted people at my school and when I talked to them I just <smiley> oke and exchanged phone numbers </s> <s> Also it is good to figure out what is the best way of communication for the artist event-crew-person </s> <s> If you 're using email and you have their phone number and it takes awhile for them to re <smiley> ond then try calling Also if you get stuck in a game of phone tag or if the other person prefers email then email is a good choice </s> <s> The best way of course is to <smiley> eak face-to-face and if that is an option it is good to do it at least twice before the event </s> <s> Tone and Attitude Here is a good article about writing effective email <smiley> <weirdcaps> Baby on Writing Good Emails </s> <s> In whatever way you contact someone your attitude should be that you are requesting and not forcing anything on someone </s> <s> Also if someone agrees to help you even if it is their job you should a <smiley> roach them with the attitude that they are doing something extra for you </s> <s> Your heart should be thankful and if you are they will remember that </s> <s> Other posts in this serie <s> Someone emailed me with a question about planning events and this is how I re <smiley> onde <smiley> The first step is to brainstorm and write down every idea you can think of </s> <s> The ideas artists around November of <date> even though the concert wasn 't until February 08 </s> <s> If the event is something you 're pa <smiley> ionate about that will make it better it has to be something <s> I turned the water on as hot as I could stand it </s> <s> Steam quickly filled the room and choked out the air as I ste <smiley> ed naked into the shower </s> <smiley> he next part is embarra <smiley> ing and humiliating to admit Facing the water I closed my eyes </s> <s> I took a deep breath and held it as I interlocked my fingers tightly behind my head and leaned forward into the stream pouring down </s> <s> Titling my head toward the ground I allowed the water to wash over my neck and back hoping to release the built-up tension in my shoulders and constriction looming deep within my chest </s> <s> Then a giant exhale </s> <s> With my forehead now resting against the shower wall and my forearms squeezing the blood surrounding my temples I remembered to relax </s> <s> To stop trying to hold on to it </s> <s> To let it flow through me like rain </s> <s> And it did </s> <s> And as a result I kind of lost it </s> <s> I started to cry - a very rare occurrence for me Although I can 't be sure if they were tears or just water droplets from the showerhead falling to my feet </s> <s> Either way it doesn 't matter and neither does this confe <smiley> ion </s> <s> This story has my everyday life that are often too difficult for me to verbalize </s> <s> So I put pen to paper in my coveted Moleskine or I blog about it here </s> <s> I write it all out and I write through it </s> <s> This time it is different </s> <s> This time I can 't write about it and what is even more difficult is that I 've realized I have no one to even talk about it with to help me cope </s> <s> I don 't have that type of relationship with any of my bu 'ies or even with anyone in my family </s> <s> It is like emotional paralysis where feeling too much is leaving me numb </s> <s> So instead I 'm include <smiley> who participated in the series </s> <s> Elisa is 'All You Need Is Love 'blog series project will definitely get you thinking and questioning love and your own life 'If a tree falls in a forest and no one is around to hear it does it make a sound 'Is is a philosophical ri 'le that raises questions regarding observation and knowledge of reality </s> <s> That theory is calle <smiley> isubjective idealism 'and refers to a time in which objects cease to exist once there is nobody around to perceive them </s> <s> However one may argue that 'if a tree falls in the forest and no one hears it did it really fall 'Meaning - the objects of sense exist only when they are perceived </s> <s> The common sense answer is yes </s> <s> It obviously makes a sound since we know that a tree falling makes noise regardle <smiley> of whether anyone is around or not </s> <s> The metaphysical answer is no </s> <s> The tree does not make a sound if no one is there to witne <smiley> it falling </s> <s> And indeed the act of making a sound isn 't even a quandary all that matters is that the tree in fact ceases to exist if no one is there to witne <smiley> it </s> <s> The production of sound requires 3 thing <smiley> a source a medium and a receiver </s> <s> But what about ha <smiley> ine <smiley> It also nee <smiley> the same 3 elements </s> <s> So is ha <smiley> ine <smiley> only real when shared There is the po <smiley> ibility of unperceived existence </s> <s> That something can exist without being perceived </s> <s> If no one is around to see hear or feel your ha <smiley> ine <smiley> does it not exist Does ha <smiley> ine <smiley> need a witne <smiley> Someone to validate it Someone to share in it to make it real For years I didn 't realize how unha <smiley> y I was until I was ha <smiley> y </s> <s> And you never realize how ha <smiley> y you were until that ha <smiley> ine <smiley> disa <smiley> ears from your life </s> <s> Ha <smiley> ine <smiley> is not tangible but yet it feels very fragile in our han <smiley> </s> <s> Hold too tightly and you smother it </s> <s> Hold too carele <smiley> ly and you lose it </s> <s> Uncla <smiley> your han <smiley> and you <s> It protects us from the harsh truths and cold realities of a life we are not yet ready to see </s> <s> As children we aren 't prepared to deal with the heartbreak and confusion that later reveals itself with age and wi <smiley> om </s> <s> Like every kid I looked up to my father </s> <s> I idolized him </s> <s> Worshiped him He was my Superman </s> <s> A man that could do no wrong </s> <s> A man that was always right </s> <s> A man that knew best </s> <s> And a man that was in fact human </s> <s> It often takes years before we see our parents for who they really are </s> <s> Not these fictitious superheroes we have built-up in our mind and heart but rather people </s> <s> People that make mistakes </s> <s> It was only a year after I graduated college that I learned that painful le <smiley> on </s> <s> That the man I had admired and role modeled myself after for <math> years of my life had been telling me embellished truths </s> <s> While the phrase 'embellished truth isoun <smiley> more pleasing to the ear than the wor <smiley> 'lie 'both are e <smiley> entially the same </s> <s> To embellish is to enhance a statement or narrative with fictitious a 'itions to beautify <s> A simple method for finding south using nothing but an analog wristwatch and the sun Hold a watch with 12 o 'clock at left </s> <s> Move your arm so the hour hand points at the sun </s> <s> The <smiley> ot halfway between the hour hand and the 12 is south </s> <s> A few important caveats </s> <s> First if you 're in the southern hemi <smiley> here you would point 12 o 'clock at the sun but still <smiley> lit the difference between 12 and the hour hand for north </s> <s> Also if you practice daylight saving time you should subtract one hour from the hour hand </s> <s> <smiley> e your <s> Twas the Irish what invented the pipes you know and they gave them to the Scots as a joke </s> <s> And the Scots haven 't gotten the joke yet Chocolate Guinne <smiley> Cake by Nigella Lawson This cake is magnificent in its damp blackne <smiley> </s> <s> I can 't say that you can absolutely taste the stout in it but there is certainly a resonant ferrous tang which I ha <smiley> en to love </s> <s> The best way of describing it is to say that it is like gingerbread without the <smiley> ices </s> <s> There is enough sugar a certain understatement here to counter any potential bitterne <smiley> of the Guinne <smiley> and although I 've eaten versions of this made up like a chocolate layer cake stuffed and slathered in a rich chocolate frosting I think that can take away from its dark majesty </s> <s> Besides I wanted to make a cream cheese frosting to echo the pale head that sits on top of a gla <smiley> of stout </s> <s> It is unconventional to a ' cream but it makes it frothier and lighter which I regard as aesthetically and gastronomically desirable </s> <s> But it is perfectly acceptable to leave the cake un-ice <smiley> in fact it tastes gorgeous plain </s> <s> Ingredients for the cake 1 cup Guinne <smiley> 1 stick plus 2 table <smiley> oons unsalted butter <math> cup unsweetened cocoa 2 cu <smiley> superfine sugar <math> cup sour cream 2 eggs 1 table <smiley> oon pure vanilla extract 2 cu <smiley> all-purpose flour 2 <math> tea <smiley> oons baking soda Ingredients for the to <smiley> ing 8 oz Philadelphia cream cheese 1 <math> cu <smiley> confectioner <smiley> ' sugar <math> cup heavy cream Nigella is Suggestion <smiley> For a simpler de <smiley> ert replace the frosting with a light dusting of powered sugar </s> <s> Preheat the over to <date> F and butter and line a 9 inch <smiley> ringform pan </s> <s> Pour the Guinne <smiley> into a large wide saucepan a ' the butter in <smiley> oons or slices and heat until the butter is melted at which time you should whisk in the cocoa and sugar </s> <s> Beat the sour cream with the eggs and vanilla and then pour into the brown buttery beery pan and finally whisk in the flour and baking soda </s> <s> Pour the cake batter into the greased and lined pan and bake for 45 minutes to an hour </s> <s> Leave to cool completely in the pan on a cooling rack as it is quite a damp cake </s> <s> When the cake is cold sit it on a flat platter or cake stand and get on with the frosting </s> <s> Lightly whip the cream cheese until smooth sift over the confectioner is sugar and then beat them both together </s> <s> Or do this in a proce <smiley> or putting the unsifted confectioner <smiley> ' sugar in first and blitz to remove lum <smiley> before a 'ing the cheese </s> <s> A ' the cream and beat again until it makes a <smiley> readable consistency </s> <s> Ice the top of the black cake so that it resembles the frothy top of the famous pint </s> <s> This <weirdcaps> regarding tulip i <smiley> 'broken 'and the coloring is caused by a virus </s> <s> During the Dutch Tulip Craze bulbs with dual colorings were highly sought-after and commanded ridiculous prices </s> <s> This particular bulb gave her an o <smiley> ortunity to talk about the snowdrop craze that is currently sweeping England where gardeners are paying hundre <smiley> of poun <smiley> for single bulbs </s> <s> She told us about parties and gatherings with Brits crawling around gardens on all fours counting <smiley> ots on the leaves of snowdro <smiley> </s> <s> The snowdrop craze in England won 't the Cypre <smiley> Vine labeled Burpee see <smiley> were what most people call Cardinal Climber </s> <s> I 've never grown Cardinal Climber but I have grown Cypre <smiley> Vine and it is my absolute favorite climbing vine to grow in the garden </s> <s> The first time I saw what I know to be Cypre <smiley> Vine labeled as Cardinal Climber by Burpee I thought it had to be an error then I thought of Burpee see <smiley> at Menar <smiley> </s> <s> The one on the right is packaged as an heirloom and the one on the left is just a regular packet </s> <s> They 're both the same weight and price and seem to use the same photograph </s> <s> The 'heirloom 'packet lists Cypre <smiley> Vine and Cardinal Climber as the common name </s> <s> I know that common names vary from region to region and from person to person </s> <s> A Google search for 'Cypre <smiley> Vine 'will result in page after pages of results discu <smiley> ing or picturing the Cypre <smiley> Vine I grow </s> <s> Similarly a search of Ipomoea quamoclit the botanical name listed on the heirloom package will return results for Cypre <smiley> Vine </s> <s> Do a search for Cardinal Climber or Ipomoea stoleri or Ipomoea x multifida and you 'll get results for Cardinal Climber the plant pictured on these two seed packs </s> <s> Park See <smiley> sells the vine pictured in these two seed packets as Cardinal Climber Ipomoea x multifida </s> <s> So what is up with the Cypre <smiley> Vine sold by Burpee Was there a name change that I haven 't been able to find or is this an error on Burpee is part I don 't think an error like this woul <smiley> 've gone unnoticed by gardeners who are sticklers for properly identified plants </s> <s> To most gardeners this probably doesn 't matter but I 'm a seed nerd who likes medicinal plant garden in Chicago I 've wanted to create a garden where I could grow many herbs annuals and perennials that are used in alternative medicines </s> <s> The idea of being able to create all-natural remedies from ingredients I 'd grow and harvest right in my own garden really a <smiley> eals to the urban homesteader inside me </s> <s> It is a shame that with every succe <smiley> ive generation we move further and further away from growing pharmacies in our gardens like our ancestors did heck our gran <smiley> arents did </s> <s> When I heard of the <weirdcaps> Two documentary series Grow Your Own Drugs by ethnobotanist James Wong that has him trying natural remedies on members of the public I wished it aired here in America </s> <s> It hasn 't been picked up or copied by American broadcasters but fortunately his book Grow Your Own Drugs is being published in America this month and I 've got my han <smiley> on a copy of this international best-selling book </s> <s> Grow Your Own Drugs isn 't as nefarious as it soun <smiley> it is all perfectly legal stuff and just teaches you how to use the various healing properties of many plants that you can grow in your own garden </s> <s> This book is set up like a cook book with a list of ingredient and equipment mortar and pestle gla <smiley> jars-simple things you probably already have that you 'll use often and should have on hand </s> <s> Nothing seems terribly e <smiley> ensive and can be found at your local home goo <smiley> store and health foo <smiley> store </s> <s> Grow Your Own Drugs teaches you how to make things like teas creams lotions balms gargles and cough syru <smiley> for common ailments from plants you can grow in your garden </s> <s> It guides you through creating natural remedies for things like digestive disorders skin complaints aches amp pains an <smiley> 'female problems 'The <math> recipes are easy to follow and most consist of only a handful of ingredients </s> <s> If you don 't have a lot of <smiley> ace for growing the plants that make up the ingredients you stick to growing the Top 10 medicinal herbs and source the others from places like your local farmers market health food store or a regular grocery store </s> <s> The last third of the book lists the Top <date> medicinal plants by fruit vegetables trees amp shrubs roots herbs and flowers and leaves </s> <s> The suggested plants section contains some information on growing but it mostly lists the beneficial properties of the plants and the growing conditions and times of years you could forage for them </s> <s> With a few exceptions the majority of these plants are plants you can find in your local garden center or grow from seed </s> <s> Now that I know that lady is mantle can be made into a salve to stop bleeding in cuts and woun <smiley> or to ease itchy skin I 'm going to have to stop letting the dogs pee on my plants </s> <s> Grow Your Own Drugs is a pretty cool book and one I 'd recommend to gardeners who would like to dabble with making their own remedies for common ailments or who like to grow productive gardens </s> <s> It is published in the U </s> <s> S by Reader is Digest and retails for <date> Growing your own food </s> <s> Grow Great Grub Organic Food from Small <smiley> aces is Gayla Trail is second book </s> <s> It is a beautifully produced book on edible gardening perha <smiley> the most beautifully done book on the subject I 've ever seen </s> <s> Grow Great Grub is filled with information and ti <smiley> on composting seed starting suggestions on which vegetables herbs and edible flowers you should grow what vegetables herbs and flowers you should grow based on the site conditions of where you plan on vegetable gardening </s> <s> There are even recipes to help you prepare dishes so that you use the cro <smiley> your garden produces </s> <s> For crafty gardeners or people who aren 't afraid of small <weirdcaps> gardening project Gayla included a few like the u <smiley> ide down tomato container </s> <s> If you have ever been on the You Grow Girl garden blog or the gardening forum you 've no doubt noticed Gayla is trademark graphic Grow Girl site without your lap getting hot from the overheating laptop </s> <s> Grow Great Grub is a beautiful vegetable gardening book filled with good gardening information and in <smiley> iring photos that makes vegetable gardening look stylish and affordable to younger gardeners and those of us without huge gardening budgets </s> <s> This is a great vegetable gardening book for people in urban areas who only have small <smiley> aces like balconies decks porches or roofto <smiley> who want to get into growing some of their own food </s> <s> It is written in a casual and fun style that got a copy of Grow Your Own Eat Your Own by Bob Flowerdew </s> <s> While fli <smiley> ing through the pages I was charmed by the photography design of the book and food styling for the recipes </s> <s> Yes I judge books by their cover and the whole look of the book is a bit of a shock for someone accustomed to the antiseptic in a good way design of books and magazines by Martha Stewart or Organic Gardening magazine </s> <s> While they contain good information and are aesthetically pleasing it sometimes bothers me to see hand models with perfectly manicured fingernails and oxford shirts in gardening publications </s> <s> Where was I Oh yes </s> <s> Everything about the garden farm that is pictured in this book would probably give Martha Stewart a heart attack </s> <s> An old garden gate leaning against a pile of unidentifiable junk strawberries growing in tire planters a backyard vineyard planted in white buckets mi <smiley> ing windowpanes a la 'er leaned against the grape arbor that leans against a dilapidated shed </s> <s> All of these beautifully flawed vignettes would probably be cro <smiley> ed out of photos or not show at all in most garden books and magazines </s> <s> In Grow Your Own Eat Your Own the largest photos are dedicated to the chaos of a real garden one that isn 't concerned about the way it looks because the purpose of the garden is to grow fresh organic cro <smiley> </s> <s> Who is Grow Your Own Eat Your Own for Gardeners and the latest urban and backyard agriculture enthusiasts </s> <s> People interested in a sustainable way of life where they 're connected to the food they 're putting on their table </s> <s> While you can find many books about growing your own food they only guide you to a certain point </s> <s> What do you do with the crop you grow so much of you don 't know what to do with besides unloading it on your frien <smiley> and family And what to do with that crop that doesn 't yield you enough to share with your frien <smiley> and family How do you keep all of that fresh produce fresh Not many gardening books give you practical advice such as preserving canning juicing or give recipes that make the most of the cro <smiley> your grow Grow Your Own Eat Your Own does </s> <s> What I like the most about the ideas for preserving and recipes is that it doesn 't look like you need fancy kitchen gadgets and a <smiley> liances to make the dishes preserves and deserts suggested </s> <s> After you 've picked out all of the vegetables and fruit trees you want to grow in your garden pick up a copy of Grow Your Own Eat Your Own so you know how to preserve and produce your grew in your garden </s> <s> I wasn 't familiar with Bob Flowerdew before I received a copy of this book but the book jacket informs me that he i <smiley> 'Britain and Europe is leading organic gardener 'With a surname like Flowerdew it probably shouldn 't have come as a surprise but it did </s> <s> Other books by Mr </s> <s> configure in an order that you can remember xev sed -n s ' -keycode - <smiley> <math> <smiley> <smiley> - ' 'keycode 1 ' p uniq Close the window when you are done </s> <s> There should be an out put left that looks somewhat like so keycode 36 keycode <date> keycode <date> keycode <date> The first line isn 't actually a media key so just ignore delete it </s> <s> Now we must set up xmodmap to <s> Last week Hard A <smiley> ets Investor published another one of my articles </s> <s> In it I compared the correlations between several energy <weirdcaps> and the prices of commodities they are tracking </s> <s> The takeaway me <smiley> age is that for the most part <weirdcaps> do a bad job tracking commodities prices </s> <s> There are a few reasons for this </s> <s> The first and primary reason why the correlation is le <smiley> than perfect is that the front-month futures contract for every commodity is constantly changing </s> <s> Since most <weirdcaps> hold only the front-month contract this means that sometime before e <smiley> iration the fund must sell its holding of one <smiley> oon to e <smiley> ire contract and then purchase another <smiley> oon to be front-month contract </s> <s> There is almost always a significant discrepency between the two prices particularly if it is a commodity that doesn 't deliver every month </s> <s> Take a look at the futures chains on the <weirdcaps> group website for crude oil gold and corn </s> <s> As of writing the difference between the front month and second month contract is about 40 1 and 10 re <smiley> ectively </s> <s> That may not seem like much but that price difference represents a pure lo <smiley> in the value of the fund with every roll that takes place </s> <s> Just to prevent declines the fund would on average have to be increasing in value between 1 and 5 a month </s> <s> That means that depending on the commodity and the fund a monthly percentage increase if not sufficiently high may actually mean you 're losing money </s> <s> The second problem with <weirdcaps> is that they create a secondary market on top of what is already a volatile market in its own right </s> <s> And while the underlying instruments are the same for both futures contract <smiley> the factors driving the su <smiley> ly and demand may be drastically different </s> <s> For example while natural gas might be moving up on strong demand resulting from a particular weather forecast if the primary participants are energy hedgers no such demand would exist for <weirdcaps> the worl <smiley> is biggest natural gas etf </s> <s> As such <weirdcaps> might theoretically follow the price of gas with something of a lag rather than actually track the price in real time </s> <s> Don 't take my word for it take a look at this graph comparing oil price movements with the price of <weirdcaps> the worl <smiley> is biggest crude oil <weirdcaps> over the last four year <smiley> Click here to download Flash Player now View the full Crude vs <weirdcaps> chart at Wikinvest Now you might be saying 'those charts seem to follow each other reasonably well 'but that is the problem </s> <s> Reasonably well isn 't good enough </s> <s> An investor buying a share or shares in a commodity <weirdcaps> that puportedly tracks the price of a commodity wants her investment to actually do just that not merely track the price 'reasonably well ' </s> <s> It is true that there are some <weirdcaps> e <smiley> ecially those dealing with precious metals that eliminate the problem of the roll yield altogether simply by buying and hoarding the commodity in question and storing it in a vault somewhere no futures contracts required </s> <s> While certainly effective in mitigating the problem this only works for a very <smiley> ecific subset of commodities that do not have a cliff for their usefulne <smiley> </s> <s> Other than those few cases in general the moral is that if you really truly want e <smiley> osure to commodities don 't waste your time with an <weirdcaps> </s> <s> As they stand very few of them can be relied upon to achieve their goals </s> <s> Though that may change in the future for now your best bet is get into the futures market directly </s> <s> Last week a couple of the major commodities exchanges announced the a 'ition of some new futures contracts to help producers and consumers of raw goo <smiley> hedge their e <smiley> enses and simultaneously give commodities traders three more reasons to develop stre <smiley> -related ulcers </s> <s> First acro <smiley> the pond the worl <smiley> is foremost metals market the London Metal Exchange <weirdcaps> yesterday opened trading of cobalt and molybdenum futures </s> <s> In shocking concordance with my previous post about the emerging need for a lithium futures contract the cobalt contract is designed <smiley> ecifically with battery manufacturers in mind cobalt being a major input to rechargeable batteries in things like lapto <smiley> and cellphones </s> <s> Molybdenum which I had never heard of before this Wall Street Journal article is a <smiley> arently used in the production of stainle <smiley> steel </s> <s> Meanwhile here in the States the ever-growing Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced that it will be a 'ing a contract for distiller is dried grain 'G a by-product of corn ethanol production </s> <s> This is interesting because with the a 'ition of the contract which will begin trading in April ethanol producers can now effectively hedge every step of their production </s> <s> For example before the harvest you might buy a corn contract so as to protect yourself from une <smiley> ected price swings at your local grain elevator </s> <s> Then once you 've got your corn and begin distilling ethanol you can sell both a 'G and ethanol contract to lock in prices for your two resultant byproducts </s> <s> Further you can buy or sell oil gas or natural gas contracts to take advantage of <smiley> read deviations between the fuels </s> <s> This is also interesting because the 'G contract may become a major hedge-staple for corporations that produce ethanol for non-fuel purposes </s> you know like Jack Daniel is </s> <s> The government and now the private markets are con <smiley> iring to make ethanol a real and viable energy source with plenty of economic safegaur <smiley> </s> <s> A bizarre reaction to these announcements is concern that opening these contracts to the public will increase volatility in the prices of the commodities and could potentially drive them too far one way or the other </s> <s> Yes that is true prices will become more volatile </s> but only for the traders </s> <s> The hedgers <smiley> eople producing and consuming ethanol actually need volatility to protect themselves from things like price-fixing and su 'en une <smiley> ected swings </s> <s> Without and open public market there is no way to plan for and predict what 'G would and will cost </s> <s> Also hedgers are not entering and exiting positions over and over to make a quick buck they are locking prices in exiting positions and taking the difference as market protection </s> <s> As per my post last night and today is news on housing starts I certainly ought to eat a little crow according to the Census Bureau January housing starts were up from December as well as January <date> </s> <s> <smiley> ecifically according to the Bureau is report Privately-owned housing starts in January were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of <date> <date> </s> <s> This is 2 8 percent <date> above the revised December estimate of <date> <date> and is <date> percent <date> above the January <date> rate of <date> <date> </s> <s> So yes it a <smiley> ears I was wrong with my initial a <smiley> e <smiley> ment and the housing market indeed showed signs of picking up in January potentially contributing to the Lumber run-up of the last month </s> <s> However the actual meaning of the housing start increase is slightly more complicated than the above quoted numbers and I would make the case much le <smiley> meaningful than reports are making it out to be </s> <s> Let me e <smiley> lain </s> <s> First regarding the meaning of the number itself the 2 8 increase in housing starts is an increase in the seasonally adjusted housing start rate </s> <s> Because the <weirdcaps> Housing market is highly seasonal i e </s> more building projects begin in the <smiley> ring and summer month <smiley> examining tren <smiley> on a purely month to month basis is not meaningful when analyzing long-term tren <smiley> </s> <s> Housing starts will almost always go up in March and they will almost always go down in October </s> <s> As such the <weirdcaps> Census Bureau developed a statistical method called X12 and its predece <smiley> or X <math> used to remove the e <smiley> ected seasonal effects of this type of data </s> <s> The best article I could find describing the algorithm is o 'ly enough on an old Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas webpage but suffice to say the algorithm is designed to remove e <smiley> ected seasonal effects for a given data series thereby showing the actual overarching trend </s> <s> Thus the published number is a point estimate for what the current annual housing start rate is in this case <date> <date> housing units started per year </s> <s> As with any statistical analysis there is a margin of error to that point estimate and the margin is given right in the reporting sentence 'This is 2 8 percent <date> above the revised December estimates 'Wait a minute 2 8 <date> That should give us a range of 8 7 to <math> 3 and if I 'm not mistaken 8 7 0 <date> </s> <s> As any statistician can tell you a confidence range that includes zero is not statistically significant at all </s> <s> And the Census Bureau uses a <math> confidence interval in their calculations so it is not as though they 're being overly conservative with their estimates and confidence ranges </s> <s> In other wor <smiley> this number is fundamentally meaningle <smiley> </s> <s> In fact if you actually bothered to read the report as a <smiley> arently no one in the media di <smiley> you 'd see that the ' <date> 'figure is asterisked with a footnote that rea <smiley> as follow <smiley> ' <math> confidence interval includes zero </s> <s> The Census Bureau does not have sufficient statistical evidence to conclude that the actual change is different from zero 'So in other wor <smiley> there is no evidence that there was a change in the seasonally adjusted rate <weirdcaps> </s> <s> This number is meaningle <smiley> </s> <s> Moving on de <smiley> ite the lack of evidence for a month over month change the increase in rate from January last to now does a <smiley> ear to be truly significant with a confidence interval of <date> percent <date> between 8 8 and <date> for the change from January <date> is seasonally adjusted rate </s> Note that that range does not cro <smiley> zero The report also lists the raw housing start numbers those that haven 't been seasonally adjuste <smiley> </s> <s> Here are the highlights all numbers pulled from the aforementioned report <smiley> <date> Year in full <date> <date> <date> Year in full <date> <date> January <date> 31 <date> November <date> 42 <date> December <date> 37 <date> January <date> 37 <date> The takeaway from all of this is that the housing market has improved significantly since <date> </s> <s> In fact using either the December or January estimate for the seasonally adjusted housing start rate yiel <smiley> a significant improvement over the <date> total figure </s> <s> However there is not sufficient evidence to suggest that any further progre <smiley> has been made over the last two or three months the numbers both seasonally adjusted and raw do not demonstrate sufficient statistical significance to draw that conclusion </s> <s> Starker still is that the market today remains at about <math> of where it was in <date> </s> <s> How did the Lumber market today re <smiley> ond to all this Somehow de <smiley> ite the hype prices moved mostly sideways either this information was already priced in or it doesn 't really exist </s> <s> Full Disclosure As of writing author is short May <date> Lumber <weirdcaps> Today is Wall Street Journal ran a great article on the recent surge in remained stagnant lumber wholesalers saw no need to maintain large inventories throughout <date> further disincentivizing output from loggers and mills </s> <s> Because of the lack of demand and low prices several lumber mills have indefinitely shuttered </s> <s> This of course in itself drove prices higher </s> <s> The article <smiley> ecifically mentions Canfor Corporation a Vancouver-based producer re <smiley> onsible for half a percent of total North American lumber output who indefinitely ceased operation on January 5th <date> as one of the major mills to shut down amid the sluggish market </s> <s> Annually home builders restock their lumber su <smiley> lies in January and February in anticipation of the upcoming <smiley> ring building season </s> <s> As su <smiley> ly was already incredibly tight and production was being scaled back acro <smiley> the board wholesale buying triggered a su <smiley> ly shock up the chain sending prices higher </s> <s> A 'itionally some firms continued buying on anticipation of consumers taking advantage of the federal home-buying tax credit before it e <smiley> ires </s> <s> As the industry was not in any place to su 'enly ramp up production the market created something of a feedback loop driving prices higher from January through to today </s> <s> Exacerbating the problem is that shuttered su <smiley> ended mills do not have the capital or guarantee of near-term capital to quickly start up operations again </s> <s> What is perha <smiley> most interesting about this is that everyone seems to be in agreement that the surge is entirely su <smiley> ly driven </s> <s> To the question of demand the article says the following <smiley> 'The su <smiley> ly crunch is striking because just a few years ago the North American lumber industry was able to su <smiley> ly enough wood to start more than two million homes a year </s> <s> That was nearly four times the pace of home starts in December 'In other wor <smiley> Layman </s> who called this the only sustained su <smiley> ly-driven rally he has seen in 30 years of trading lumber 'Thirty years is a long time and Mr </s> <s> Layman is quote only serves to highlight just how strange this market rally seems on the surface </s> <s> My readers already know that I 'm bearish on Lumber but honestly everything about this rally seems crazy to me </s> <s> At least now we understand the circumstances that pushed prices high in the first place but for this kind of rally to be sustained </s> <s> I 'm just not sure what it would take short of a <smiley> ectacular resurgence in the housing industry </s> <s> Tomorrow the <weirdcaps> Census Bureau will announce the figures for January housing starts </s> <s> A slight bump will be good news for the lumber bulls a downtick could mean the beginning of the rally is end </s> <s> I 'll put a post up as soon as we see what ha <smiley> ens and what it is immediate effect may be </s> <s> Sorry about the dearth of posts lately but I 've been out of town </s> <s> <smiley> eaking of </s> <s> I just got back from a trip to beautiful Whitefish Montana </s> <s> If you 're a skier and or outdoor enthusiast I can 't recommend the city highly enough </s> <s> On the train ride out there I ended up having dinner with a couple of Montanans who own and work a farm on the eastern edge of the state </s> <s> We got to talking and I asked them what they raise to which the re <smiley> onse came from the husban <smiley> 'Durum wheat peas and chickpeas 'On hearing the word wheat my interest was piqued so I aske <smiley> 'I 'm curious do you ever use futures contracts to hedge your cro <smiley> 'To which he jumped into a very long very interesting discu <smiley> ion about the commodities markets </s> <s> The short answer to my question was no because there is no durum wheat futures contract he doesn 't really have the option to hedge in the commodities markets however he can often lock prices in advance with individually agreed upon 'forwar <smiley> 'agreements with grain purchasers though he admitted that this is not as useful as a true futures contract because there is le <smiley> liquidity in the market 'If you can 't deliver your full crop 'he sai <smiley> 'you 'd better have the cash ' </s> <s> Following this conversation the man is wife asked me <smiley> 'How do you know so much about wheat 'I e <smiley> lained that I was a commodities investor and sometime analyst to which she sai ' <weirdcaps> because you sound exactly like our son 'What does your son do 'He is a wheat farmer 'The commodities markets have always fascinated me because in some sense it is one of the last pure markets in the country </s> <s> When you put a bid in for a commodity like wheat you 're not betting on earnings reports or interest rates <weirdcaps> scandals cash flow statement readjustments corporate lawsuits etc </s> etc </s> <s> You are simply betting on the price of a bushel of wheat </s> <s> It is one of the few places in the world of busine <smiley> where the Montana Farmer and Wall Street Analyst are not just peers but equal e <smiley> erts and it is a market that is open to <weirdcaps> </s> <s> If that doesn 't stir your inner capitalist I don 't know what would </s> <s> By bearish of course I mean pe <smiley> imistic </s> <s> In other wor <smiley> I e <smiley> ect the price to go down </s> <s> Here is a chart of Lumber futures prices over the last month Click here to download Flash Player now View the full <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> chart at Wikinvest Of particular interest is the big upward movement starting on January 28th </s> <s> Between then and this last Friday lumber <weirdcaps> went up the se <smiley> ion limit of 10 thousand board feet <weirdcaps> </s> <s> At the beginning of the month I was bearish on Lumber because I su <smiley> ected housing starts have not actually increased whatsoever and at the time I took a short position only to be sto <smiley> ed out in accordance with my personal trading philosophy however now I am even more bearish because I don 't think this pricing run up either makes sense or is in any way sustainable </s> <s> Quick background about the market the random length lumber futures contract what most people mean when they say 'lumber ' is used extensively by lumber industry participants that is timber harvesters and construction companies to hedge against erratic price movements in the cash market the price you get at your local mill on any given day </s> <s> The biggest factor affecting lumber prices is the <weirdcaps> housing market </s> <s> When the housing market is booming lumber skyrockets </s> <s> When home construction is depre <smiley> ed so too the lumber market </s> <s> There is very little else driving lumber prices as most of the lumber we use is grown domestically we e <smiley> ort almost none of it and what lumber we do import comes almost exclusively from Canada </s> <s> Now that that is out of the way </s> a recent article from Reuters basically comes to the following conclusions as to why the price has shot u <smiley> There are fewer mills currently in operation many had closed down when the housing market dried u <smiley> creating a minor su <smiley> ly shock in the cash market and sending prices up </s> <s> There is an e <smiley> ected increase in demand as the result of the a <smiley> roaching ' <smiley> ring building season ' </s> <s> A 'realtor survey ishowed pending home sales were up 1 in December </s> <s> My reason for being bearish on Lumber right now is that I believe there is a logical fallacy at play in the market </s> <s> Follow me here on this treatise If the housing market picks up i e </s> demand increase <smiley> Lumber inventories i e </s> su <smiley> ly should be pre <smiley> ured and may diminish </s> <s> If inventories stay the same or diminish The price should go up </s> <s> This is basic su <smiley> ly and demand but I 've made each bullet cascading to point out the conditional nature of how the market in theory re <smiley> on <smiley> </s> <s> The other way for the price to go up would be as follow <smiley> If lumber inventories diminish i e </s> su <smiley> ly decrease <smiley> If the housing market moves sideways or picks up i e </s> demand stays the same or increase <smiley> The price should go up </s> <s> Note the difference between the two cases </s> <s> In the first demand is the driving conditional in the second su <smiley> ly </s> <s> Also note and this is what is important that demand and demand alone has an effect on the other predictive variable in the equation </s> <s> That is to say when demand changes there is <weirdcaps> an effect upon the su <smiley> ly </s> <smiley> es I know it is po <smiley> ible that demand has been perfectly predicted and su <smiley> lies tailored to meet the e <smiley> ected demand but this is incredibly unlikely in a market based upon a fungible commodity such as Lumber When su <smiley> ly decreases on the other hand there is by no means any nece <smiley> ary or e <smiley> ected re <smiley> onse in demand </s> <s> Demand could stay the same demand could increase demand could decrease </s> <s> There is simply no way to know or even extrapolate based on su <smiley> ly alone </s> <s> What we have in the lumber market is the second scenario </s> <s> Su <smiley> lies seem to be diminishing because of the drawdown in milling operations </s> <s> However that in and of itself in theory anyway should not cause the price to go up </s> <s> For that to ha <smiley> en we 'd need to see that demand has at least not diminished or at best has increased </s> <s> If this were the other way around if we knew that demand really was increasing we could infer that su <smiley> ly was likely to decline and the facts about the mill drawdowns would confirm this and we could say that yes indeed lumber prices ought to go up </s> <s> However we cannot say that demand for lumber is increasing we can only say that su <smiley> ly looks like it might be decreasing and there is at best a po <smiley> ibility that demand is on the rise depending on how much faith you put in a self-reported survey from an industry with a financial incentive to make itself look healthy </s> <s> As for the ispring building season 'mentioned in the Reuters article it is important to note that this is buying by retail lumber dealers in anticipation of the season </s> <s> This is not a construction company buying lumber to build a house </s> <s> Unle <smiley> that lumber is actually used it will just sit on the shelf delaying future orders and a 'ing to the su <smiley> ly </s> <s> Of course we can talk about what a market should or shouldn 't do in theory about what is the right or wrong e <smiley> ected price movement based on any set of information but the truth is that a market cannot be right or wrong </s> <s> A market simply is </s> <s> Lumber is trading at over <date> <weirdcaps> because someone was willing to buy a contract at that price and someone was willing to sell </s> <s> However while the market itself cannot be wrong the participants in the market can be </s> <s> Extrapolating that su <smiley> ly is decreasing based on mill slow-down is an a <smiley> umption and it can be incorrect </s> <s> Believing the housing market is picking up is an a <smiley> umption and it too can be incorrect </s> <s> If two people a buyer and a seller have the same incorrect a <smiley> umptions the price they agree on will force the market in a particular direction and this will ha <smiley> en regardle <smiley> of the a <smiley> umption <smiley> ' validity </s> <s> Now this buyer and this seller they might be right </s> <s> It might be the case that lumber su <smiley> ly is falling and that demand is picking back up but personally I don 't think so </s> <s> I don 't think the housing market is picking up and I don 't think su <smiley> lies are in any way close to depleted enough to cause a significant shortage </s> <s> Housing starts declined in December you can read the reports on the Random Lengths website a sort of trade-mag for the lumber industry do we have any reason beyond the above 'realtor survey 'to believe they have increased since Again maybe </s> <s> Maybe I 'm wrong about this it is very po <smiley> ible but I simply don 't see housing starts increasing enough to justify this price run up </s> <s> Again I could be wrong </s> <s> I could be dead wrong and the <weirdcaps> housing market might be ready to e <smiley> lode and the decline in mill output might cause a serious su <smiley> ly shock but even so in closing let me drop a little per <smiley> ective </s> <s> The last time lumber was consistently trading above <date> <weirdcaps> was May - August <date> </s> <s> Between then and now it broke the <date> barrier only one other time August <date> </s> <s> As I discu <smiley> ed in a prior post almost always draw quick people observational sketches with a pen </s> <s> I have a nice Faber Castell ' <smiley> ' <weirdcaps> pen </s> nb <smiley> If I 'm drawing from my imagination then I almost always use a medium-hard pencil nb <smiley> H is or F is </s> nb <smiley> If I like the drawing I will sometimes refine it with a soft <weirdcaps> pencil </s> nb <smiley> If I a ' color I usually scan in my drawing set the drawing layer in Photoshop or Illustrator to 'multiply ' blend mode and a ' color on layers below that </s> <s> This is an illustration I made for an insurance company a few years ago </s> nb <smiley> I was going through some old files and stumbled on it </s> <s> It seems to give the sense of busy which is what I am right now </s> nb <smiley> It is an animated gif that I the natural development of the characters and their lives </s> <s> Importantly for me this is <weirdcaps> a Christian allegory </s> <s> Playing the 'who is the Christ figure 'game with Christian-penned fantasy novels quickly grows tiresome and takes me out of the book and into 'theology debate 'mode </s> <s> Jeffery Overstreet deftly avoi <smiley> this while still dealing with times that try men is souls </s> <s> Thomas Paine was actually talking about the American colonies fighting for independence from British rule </s> but it is the first quote that po <smiley> ed into their No Greater Joy ministry - <weirdcaps> is blog has an excellent list of warnings amp critiques of what they teach and the horrific consequences For me any kind of useful parenting advice is going to lead me to balance grace amp truth to show both justice amp mercy to use discipline in order to build up the character of my boys rather than break their <smiley> irits </s> <s> It will not affirm my cultural preconceptions but instead in <smiley> ire me to treat my family and e <smiley> </s> my children as gifts entrusted to me amp my wife </s> <s> Good parenting techniques will not nece <smiley> arily make my life easier </s> <s> In fact they will focus on helping me raise adults rather than control children </s> <s> When the advice goes the other way - and particularly when the advice purports to be 'Go <smiley> is way '- I need to call it what it is </s> a lie </s> <s> You didn 't know this All you have to do is watch read watch the news to figure it out </s> <s> For example did you know that Avatar is the 'highest gro <smiley> ing film of all time ' Really - of course that means you don 't take inflation into account </s> or currency fluctuation </s> or the one a bit more serious </s> <s> Did you know that the current war in Iraq which on March 20th of this year will have lasted 7 year <smiley> is longer than World War Two Granted that depen <smiley> on when you count <weirdcaps> as starting </s> <s> See if you date it by American involvement it is not quite 3 years amp 9 months from the attack on Pearl Harbor in December <date> to the surrender of Japan in August <date> </s> <s> The traditional start of the war however is September 1 <date> with the Nazi invasion of Poland which makes the war almost 6 years long </s> and I would suggest that you could make a case for the starting date being the Japanese invasion of Manchuria <smiley> eptember 13 <date> which means the war lasted 14 years </s> <s> But what really cheesed me off about <weirdcaps> is comparison of the Iraq War last week was the length comparison to <weirdcaps> followed by a list of Americans killed amp wounded in Iraq </s> <s> In nearly 7 years of fighting amp occupation <date> American soldiers have been killed and a <smiley> roximately 30 <date> troo <smiley> have been wounded </s> <s> Those are tough numbers - no one wants to see that kind of grief amp pain visited on families amp frien <smiley> </s> <s> However <weirdcaps> failed to provide context to those numbers </s> particularly since they had <weirdcaps> made the length comparison to the Second World War </s> <s> Over <date> <date> <weirdcaps> soldiers were killed during our involvement in <weirdcaps> </s> <date> <date> plus were wounded </s> <s> In fact over 19 <date> <weirdcaps> troo <smiley> were killed during the Battle of the Bulge which lasted just over 6 weeks </s> <s> Look I 'm not arguing for or against the Iraq War </s> or the succe <smiley> of a <weirdcaps> movie for that matter </s> <s> What drives me crazy is that by refusing to set our pronouncements in historical context we make decisions based on our visceral reaction rather than on good sense </s> and that is exacerbated when we imply false comparisons of data </s> <s> <weirdcaps> I 'll climb down off my soapbox amp start working on my sermon for this week now </s> <s> I posted a bit yesterday about my <s> This article written by Jonathan Hartley was originally published in the Python Magazine </s> <s> Acceptance Testing </s> <s> <weirdcaps> A <smiley> lications using <weirdcaps> Unit tests demonstrate to developers that individual functions and cla <smiley> es work as e <smiley> ected </s> <s> Acceptance tests are an orthogonal complement to this </s> <s> They verify to everybody including managers and clients that features they understand and care about are completed and working correctly </s> <s> They also prove that the system as a whole is correctly integrated and that no regre <smiley> ions have occurred </s> <s> Resolver Systems is developing a </s> <s> <weirdcaps> desktop <smiley> rea <smiley> heet a <smiley> lication Resolver One for which we have accumulated an acceptance testing framework </s> <s> This framework uses Python is standard unittest module and is executed using <weirdcaps> </s> <s> While Resolver One is written in <weirdcaps> this technique allows <weirdcaps> tests to interact with product code written in any </s> <s> <weirdcaps> language </s> <s> This article describes the principles of this <weirdcaps> acceptance testing framework and demonstrates them by creating an acceptance test for a small sample C <weirdcaps> a <smiley> lication </s> <s> March 9th that is tomorrow at the time of typing <weirdcaps> in Action is the Manning are 1 </s> <s> I can very easy use everything I know about the </s> <s> Net Framework <weirdcaps> </s> <s> Net and nb <smiley> C 2 </s> <s> I can run <weirdcaps> in Visual Studio 3 </s> <s> I can ever pickled up because it also e <smiley> lains a lot of not just Python but also about </s> <s> Net </s> <s> If any book deserved to be pickled up this is it </s> <s> Have a great <date> </s> <s> My belief is that the answer to the question in the title of this entry is an emphatic yes </s> <s> Microsoft have poured a lot of money into <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> and the Dynamic Language Runtime and have demonstrated a consistent commitment since the inception of <weirdcaps> </s> <s> What they haven 't done is build full su <smiley> ort into their premier development tool Visual Studio </s> <s> The reason for this is that it is a very difficult problem </s> <s> Visual Studio is built around statically typed languages </s> <s> Features like intellisense refactoring and code navigation all rely on having type information which is absent in languages like Python and Ruby </s> <smiley> he way they are implemented in Visual Studio requires that information I mean What Microsoft have done is provide example integration in the form of <weirdcaps> Studio which frankly sucks </s> <s> Many important features are fragile broken or mi <smiley> ing altogether </s> <s> Good <weirdcaps> like <weirdcaps> and Wing do provide these features so it is definitely po <smiley> ible - it just requires a lot of work from scratch </s> <s> Microsoft have however a 'ed intellisense for Javascript particularly for <weirdcaps> into Visual Studio </s> <s> Javascript is of course a dynamic language but without having tried the integration I can 't tell you how well it compares to using a good Python <weirdcaps> </s> <s> I believe that Microsoft would like to a ' su <smiley> ort for dynamic languages to Visual Studio and that it will come eventually </s> <s> Really they have a lot to lose by not doing it </s> <s> Now they have a good platform for dynamic developers to use which they give away free but the tools they charge for don 't really su <smiley> ort them </s> <s> This puts them in a position of either bringing developers to their platform but not being able to make any money or having their existing developers stay with their platform but losing dependence on the toolset </s> <s> Neither option looks much good for Microsoft </s> <weirdcaps> for those who can 't wait for official Microsoft su <smiley> ort and have Visual Studio <date> try Jeff Hardy is <weirdcaps> for Visual Studio Extensions Anyway K </s> <s> Scott Allen sees things a little differently and I understand his frustration Is Microsoft taking Dynamic Languages Seriously Consider this <weirdcaps> got underway in July of <date> </s> <s> Five years later it a <smiley> ears <weirdcaps> is still not a candidate to be a first cla <smiley> language in the </s> <s> <weirdcaps> framework and tools </s> <s> You can vote on this i <smiley> ue </s> <s> Microsoft first released <weirdcaps> at Mix in <date> </s> <s> Nearly three years later it a <smiley> ears <weirdcaps> is still not a candidate to be a first cla <smiley> language in the </s> <s> <weirdcaps> framework and tools </s> <s> You can vote on this i <smiley> ue </s> <s> A first cla <smiley> language is deployed when the full </s> <s> <weirdcaps> framework is installed </s> <s> It is as easy to find as csc exe </s> <s> It is not a language you have to ask the <weirdcaps> department to install separately </s> <s> It is not a language that requires you to jump out of Visual Studio to edit or run </s> <s> Most of all a first cla <smiley> language doesn 't require justification to higher powers </s> <s> A first cla <smiley> language is pre-certified and stamped with a seal of a <smiley> roval </s> <s> It is as easy to use in the locked-down big corporate setting as the company paper shre 'er </s> <s> Of course here we are talking about Microsoft as if it was a single entity with a single intention </s> <s> The reality of course is that Microsoft is a huge company with many divisions and even more individuals working there </s> <s> In all likelihood the vast majority of Microsoft employees have never heard of <weirdcaps> </s> <s> The relevant division is the programming languages group which includes Visual Studio development and where the majority of employees who are developers probably have heard of <weirdcaps> if not actually used it </s> <s> A 'ing official dynamic languages su <smiley> ort to Visual Studio would require substantial investment of time and effort so even if everyone in this department was determined to a ' su <smiley> ort it would still be dependent on forces from other parts of the company who have other nee <smiley> and priorities </s> <s> Ironclad is a compatibility layer that allows you to use Python C extensions with <weirdcaps> </s> <s> Ironclad is open source and development has been funded by Resolver Systems and it is integrated into Resolver One to allow you to use Numpy within Resolver One <smiley> rea <smiley> heets </s> <s> Ironclad works by implementing the Python C <weirdcaps> in a combination of C C and Python </s> <s> Although Ironclad only works on 32 bit Windows at the moment the implementation has been done in such a way that porting it to run on other platforms with Mono and 64 bit would be relatively easy </s> <s> Patches welcomed Recent development has changed the implementation to use gcc-xml to acce <smiley> and transform the Python C source code </s> <s> By reusing as much of the original implementation as po <smiley> ible it minimizes the amount that nee <smiley> to be 'hand-code <smiley> ' </s> <s> It leaves only a moderately small core that would need to be reimplemented if Jython <weirdcaps> or other implementation <smiley> wanted to reuse Ironclad </s> <s> The C would need to be re-coded in Java or <weirdcaps> using the platform is native <weirdcaps> instead of <weirdcaps> on </s> <s> <weirdcaps> </s> <s> The advantage of reusing Ironclad is that difficult problems like handling the Global <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> You might wonder why I would knock on something like The Box for being a bunch of nonsense and yet praise Hausu House for being a bunch of nonsense </s> <s> Well the answer is simple as someone who prefers story to anything else I felt annoyed by Richard Kelly turning the intriguing and unique concept of The Box into yet house that turns out to be haunte <smiley> a million times so the batshit incomprehensible-by-design nature of it allowed me to be entertained by the story all over again </s> <s> If I had to 'pitch ' the movie to someone I would probably say it was David Lynch is version of Evil Dead 2 or maybe The Grudge as written by James Joyce </s> <s> Blending animation <smiley> latter outright nonsense a dancing skeleton for example typical haunted house motifs and screwball comedy antics into a single film Nobuhiko Obayashi has created a stream-of-conscious horror comedy that simply must be seen to be believed and even then you 'll probably figure you were dreaming part of it up </s> 'Did I really just see a piano eat a girl ' you might ask yourself after the film has concluded </s> <s> Yes </s> <s> Yes you did </s> <s> The film is structure sort of defies reviewing or even my usual sort of 'reactionary ' type posting </s> <s> It is all so rambunctious and free-flowing I 'm hard-pre <smiley> a single viewing is simply not enough to <weirdcaps> everything </s> <s> The editing is rapid-fire the girls never really pause in between their lines and it is got a pretty crowded cast about a dozen main character <smiley> de <smiley> ite only being 87 minutes long </s> <s> Some of the stylistic flourishes are a bit annoying though </s> <s> At one point the film a <smiley> ears to have been shot at maybe 12 frames per second which would be fine for a quick iscare ' shot but it is used for a lengthy tracking shot consisting of the girls trying to exit the house and make a phone call while talking </s> <s> It gave me a bit of a headache honestly </s> <s> Perha <smiley> it was an error that they couldn 't afford or didn 't have the time cast to reshoot but it is a blight all the same things and meeting real people is for some reason objectively better than your natural inclination to stay in every night Are you tired of being made to feel like your desire to never leave the house again is wrong Did you answer yes to one or more of these questions but are afraid to admit to people that this is how you really feel If so good news You are like me And it truly is great news the History Channel is top </s> and bottom </s> rated shows ever 'Life After People 'was a huge succe <smiley> and I 'm still doing interviews about it phoned in to New Zealand and Australia </s> <s> culture -- will soon be released in the Western Hemi <smiley> here by Nimble Books and in the Eastern Hemi <smiley> here by Altair Australia </s> <s> Included will be those infamous articles about <s> e </s> <s> The next part of the problem is figuring out how to test for unbounded sequences </s> <s> A good a <smiley> roximation can be reached by running through n iterations and quitting if the magnitude of z excee <smiley> 2 </s> <s> The magnitude of a complex number with real part a and imaginary part b is sqrt a 2 b <math> </s> <s> For simple graphs a reasonable value for n is <date> </s> <s> Here is what a simple Mandelbrot set grapher in <weirdcaps> looks like for var x 1 x for var y 1 y var count 0 var size 0 var cx xcorner <smiley> zoom this width var cy ycorner <smiley> y zoom this height var zx 0 var zy 0 while count count 1 temp zx z <smiley> - zy zy zy 2 zx zy cy zx temp cx size zx z <smiley> zy zy this </s> <s> Plot <smiley> y count count serves as a good color hint </s> By setting the xcorner ycorner and zoom variables the above code allows you to pan acro <smiley> and zoom into various points in the set </s> <s> To accommodate for pretty visualizations you can use count to determine the color of the pixel </s> <s> A barebones implementation is available here mandelbrot js </s> <s> Although it is not a very efficient implementation it is very simple and if you squint hard enough you can see how the code relates to the visualization </s> <s> The Mandelbrot Set Generator is a harne <smiley> I built with mandelbrot js </s> <s> Play with the parameters and let me know if you find anything interesting </s> <s> It also turns out to be a good br </s> </s>

<s> It is been a while since I last posted anything </s> <s> My family and I moved from the valley to Seattle </s> <s> We love it up here but we 've been very busy </s> <s> Anyway on to something somewhat interesting </s> <s> Question In C what is the difference between the following new Foo new Foo <smiley> Give up I almost di <smiley> They 're both valid and they both return a pointer to a newly constructed Foo on the heap </s> <s> They only produce different results when Foo is a <weirdcaps> type </s> <s> In a nutshell a <weirdcaps> <smiley> lain Ol ' Data type is a cla <smiley> struct that only contains data members that are scalar types int unsigned char float bool etc or other <weirdcaps> types </s> <s> Basically a <weirdcaps> object looks like an old C-style struct </s> <s> For example <smiley> orry about the lack of indentation blogger ate it <weirdcaps> cla <smiley> Foo public int a <weirdcaps> a pod cla <smiley> Bar public int a string name not a <weirdcaps> type The difference between new Foo and new Foo <smiley> is that former will be uninitialized and the latter will be default initialized to zero when Foo is a <weirdcaps> type </s> <s> So when not using the form with the parens the member 'a 'can contain garbage but with the paren <smiley> 'a 'will always be initialized to 0 </s> <s> Let is see cat pod cc include struct Foo int a int main <smiley> Foo- foo new Foo foo- a 7 delete foo Foo- new_foo new Foo printf <smiley> 'new_foo - a <smiley> n ' new_foo - a delete new_foo return 0 g -o pod pod cc pod new_foo- a 7 But if we simply a ' empty parens to our new Foo we 'll get different behavior again this is only because Foo is a <weirdcaps> type </s> cat pod cc include struct Foo int a int main <smiley> Foo- foo new Foo <smiley> foo- a 7 delete foo Foo- new_foo new Foo <smiley> printf <smiley> 'new_foo- a <smiley> n ' new_foo- a delete new_foo return 0 g -o pod pod cc pod new_foo- a 0 And that is about it </s> <s> The two forms are nearly identical </s> <s> They behave the same except when used on a <weirdcaps> type in which case the form with parens initializes the members to zero </s> <s> Perha <smiley> not that useful but somewhat interesting </s> <s> I 'm moving soon and I 'm trying to get Comcast setup at the new location </s> <s> I went through their online ordering proce <smiley> and aside from the fact that there was no <smiley> roce <smiley> es -e 'printf ' <smiley> n ' <weirdcaps> undef 'com a <smiley> le </s> <s> <weirdcaps> ' <smiley> ' A <smiley> lications <weirdcaps> a <smiley> mv A <smiley> lications <weirdcaps> a <smiley> Desktop perl <weirdcaps> <smiley> roce <smiley> es -e 'printf ' <smiley> n ' <weirdcaps> undef 'com a <smiley> le </s> <s> <weirdcaps> ' <smiley> ' <smiley> ers jgm Desktop <weirdcaps> a <smiley> mv Desktop <weirdcaps> a <smiley> A <smiley> lications perl <weirdcaps> <smiley> roce <smiley> es -e 'printf ' <smiley> n ' <weirdcaps> undef undef ' <weirdcaps> a <smiley> ' <smiley> ' A <smiley> lications <weirdcaps> a <smiley> <smiley> es I know mdfind could do something similar </s> <s> But it wouldn 't nece <smiley> arily return the one that <weirdcaps> thinks is the 'preferre <smiley> 'one if there were multiple a <smiley> lications with the same bundle <weirdcaps> There is often confusion about the difference between the following three declarations in Objective-C id foo1 <weirdcaps> -foo2 id lt <weirdcaps> gt foo3 The first one is the most common </s> <s> It simply declares a pointer to some Objective-C object <smiley> ee usr include objc objc h </s> id gives the compiler no information about the actual type of the object so the compiler cannot do compile-time type checking for you </s> <s> Thus the compiler will let you send any <math> me <smiley> age to objects declared id </s> <s> Actually this is why the common idiom of <smiley> Foo alloc init doesn 't cause the compiler to complain </s> alloc is declared to return type id so the compiler won 't yell when you then send the returned object the me <smiley> age init or even <weirdcaps> blah </s> <s> So objects declared using id are just dynamically typed at runtime </s> <s> The compiler has no useful information about the object is real type so it can 't warn you if you send it a me <smiley> age that it may not re <smiley> ond to </s> <s> Just because we know that an id is an Objective-C object does not mean that it points to an object that derives from <weirdcaps> or that it even has common metho <smiley> like retain and release </s> <s> One solution is to statically type our variable using <weirdcaps> as shown in number 2 above </s> <s> This gives the compiler information about the cla <smiley> of the object pointed to by foo2 so the compiler can warn if you send a me <smiley> age to foo2 that an <weirdcaps> doesn 't re <smiley> ond to </s> <s> This means you can safely call retain release description etc but the compiler will warn if you call length or count or anything that an <weirdcaps> doesn 't re <smiley> ond to </s> <s> So declaring a generic pointer of type <weirdcaps> is very similar to what you would do in other languages like Java but it is really a bit too restrictive for a language as flexible as Objective-C </s> <s> De <smiley> ite what you may have learned at one point not all Foundation Cocoa objects derive from <weirdcaps> </s> <s> As an example <weirdcaps> is not derived from <weirdcaps> so the foo2 pointer above would not be able to hold an <weirdcaps> subcla <smiley> even though <weirdcaps> does implement common metho <smiley> like retain and release </s> <s> What you really want is a pointer to any object that behaves like an <weirdcaps> </s> <s> And that is exactly what the third case does </s> <s> Declaring an object as id lt <weirdcaps> gt tells the compiler that you don 't care what type the object is but you do care that it conforms to the <smiley> ecified <weirdcaps> protocol-- </s> <s> The compiler will ensure that all objects you a <smiley> ign to that pointer conform to the required protocol </s> <s> A pointer typed like this can safely hold any <weirdcaps> because <weirdcaps> conforms to the <weirdcaps> protocol but it could also hold any <weirdcaps> because <weirdcaps> also conforms to the <weirdcaps> protocol </s> <s> In english the declaration id lt <weirdcaps> gt foo3 say <smiley> 'foo3 is a pointer to an object of any type that behaves like an <weirdcaps> ' </s> <s> This is very powerful convenient and e <smiley> re <smiley> ive </s> <s> In reality we often don 't care what type an object is we just care that it re <smiley> on <smiley> to the me <smiley> ages that we want to send it e g retain release </s> <s> So how do you decide which form you want to use It is pretty easy </s> <s> If you don 't want or can 't have any type checking then use a plain id </s> <s> This is very common for return types on metho <smiley> that don 't know the type of object they 're returning e g alloc </s> <s> It is also common to declare delegates to be type id because delegates are generally checked at runtime with <weirdcaps> and they usually aren 't retained </s> <s> However if you do want compile-time type checking you must decide between the second and third cases </s> <s> Well let me just help you out mdash you want the third case - I 've very very <weirdcaps> rarely seen a situation where <weirdcaps> - worked but id lt <weirdcaps> gt would not </s> <s> And using the protocol form has the advantage that it will work with <weirdcaps> </s> <s> You may think that you never use <weirdcaps> but Cocoa is distributed objects system makes heavy use of <weirdcaps> subcla <smiley> es </s> <s> A 'itionally the common case is that you simply want to ensure that an object can be retained or released and in that case the protocol form conveys that intent better you really don 't care what cla <smiley> the object is you only care that it behaves like an <weirdcaps> </s> - Well not 'any 'me <smiley> age </s> <s> If you send a me <smiley> age using a selector that the compiler has never seen it may warn that it has never seen that selector </s> <s> This is nice in the event that you mistype init as inti </s> -- Now when I say ' <weirdcaps> 'here I 'm talking about the protocol <smiley> rotocol named <weirdcaps> </s> <s> There is also a cla <smiley> named <weirdcaps> that does indeed conform to the <weirdcaps> protocol but they are two different things </s> <s> Markd over at the Borkware Miniblog posted some great pictures mdash and hilarious captions mdash of Macworld '08 </s> </s> 
<s> Some of you may know the legend of the long lost film The White Gazelle made by Tony Laudati in I believe <date> </s> <s> It was featured in Cinemagic magazine long long ago but until now the movie itself was unavailable for viewing to anyone who didn 't know Tony personally </s> <s> Well thanks to today is digital culture it is now available - for 99 cents no le <smiley> <punctuationfreak> on a site called Filmginder </s> <s> White Gazelle on Filmgrinder This is an amateur production </s> shot in 16mm but featuring some incredible sculpting and in-camera compositing effects </s> <s> The compositing isn 't as flawle <smiley> as it would be if shot on 35mm film with a pin-registered camera </s> the 16mm models are known to suffer from what is calle <smiley> 'film weave ' making compositing effects tricky </s> <s> All that said as soon as I found out the film was available I went ahead and downloaded it </s> <s> I was able to pay through my <weirdcaps> account simple as pie and no problems whatsoever with joining the site or getting the download </s> <s> I really love the atmo <smiley> here of this movie </s> <s> There is something primal about it </s>
