This is what the shot was looking like at first </s> <s> Download this one here </s> <s> Note the problems with the lighting </s> very hard glaring light on the forehea <smiley> and the faces in shadow </s> <s> This is a result of the way they 're sculpted </s> <s> Note </s> <s> I am <weirdcaps> di <smiley> ing Scott Radke is sculpting <punctuationfreak> I <weirdcaps> these hea <smiley> </s> but because of the way they 're done </s> eyes set so wide and facing different directions bare forehea <smiley> with no hair covering them that face directly into the light plane and somewhat glo <smiley> y paint - it makes them very hard to light </s> <s> It is a challenge like everything about this project </s> <s> And it is forcing me to dig deep and find a different way to work </s> <s> Here is the solution that is working best so far </s> <s> These are my lights </s> <s> I 'm only using 2 for this shot and note </s> they 're both facing <weirdcaps> </s> rather than the more normal option of being aimed directly at the set </s> <s> See the next image to understand <weirdcaps> </s> <s> See the big white sheets of paper fastened to the front of the set They 're reflectors </s> <s> The lights are both aimed at them and then only reflected light is bounced back onto the set to light the pu <smiley> ets </s> for this pic I actually had a light aimed directly at the set just to make things show up better Reflected light has some very nice properties </s> it is very diffused doesn 't cast a clear shadow and it has a lot le <smiley> glare than direct light does </s> <s> And because this is all fill light coming from the front it fills in details like the eye sockets that were in deep shadow before </s> <s> This kind of reflected lighting seems to be the only solution to the lighting problems posed by these hea <smiley> </s> <s> But </s> if you compare the two shots above even though the direct lighting causes glare and shadow problems it has a much more dramatic look to it </s> creating great shadows that define the form of the hea <smiley> </s> the fully reflected light doesn 't do this </s> <s> In fact reflected light like this is often called cartoon lighting because of the lack of drama and overall illuminated feel </s> <s> I want to try to find a halfway solution </s> <s> I think if I can aim a light or two directly at the set with plenty of neutral density gels grey color filter <smiley> to dim them down while still keeping the reflected lighting I currently have I should be able to get the best of both worl <smiley> </s> <s> Time will tell </s> artificial3d com omega <weirdcaps> a pair of recent posts - Analyze this and the followup Analysister -I brought up the idea of some a <smiley> ects of a movie <smiley> urface story being readily discernible to the left logical brain and some more subtle parts to the right intuitive brain </s> <s> I had never thought about this until making the Analyze this post and discu <smiley> ing the way Kubrick is films seem to work on a viewer </s> <s> For convenience is sake I 've included a table below listing the well-known attributes of these two hemi <smiley> heres of the brain </s> <s> Right Brain vs </s> <s> Left Brain Definition This theory of the structure and functions of the mind suggests that the two different sides of the brain control two different 'mode <smiley> ' of thinking </s> <s> It also suggests that each of us prefers one mode over the other </s> <s> Discu <smiley> ion E <smiley> erimentation has shown that the two different sides or hemi <smiley> heres of the brain are re <smiley> onsible for different manners of thinking </s> <s> The following table illustrates the differences between left-brain and right-brain thinking Left Brain Right Brain Logical Sequential Rational Analytical Objective Looks at parts Random Intuitive Holistic Synthesizing Subjective Looks at wholes Article It su 'enly occurred to me that this division between two different ways of thinking soun <smiley> very familiar </s> in fact I 've encountered very nearly the same division between ways of thinking - one logical and focused the other intuitive and 'fuzzy ' but in a non-scientific context The Apollonian Dionysian dichotomy Apollonian and Dionysian are terms used by Nietzsche in The Birth of Tragedy to designate the two central principles in Greek culture </s> <s> The Apollonian which corre <smiley> on <smiley> to Schopenhauer is principium individuationis <smiley> 'principle of individuation ' is the basis of all analytic distinctions </s> <s> Everything that is part of the unique individuality of man or thing is Apollonian in character all types of form or structure are Apollonian since form serves to define or individualize that which is formed thus sculpture is the most Apollonian of the arts since it relies entirely on form for its effect </s> <s> Rational thought is also Apollonian since it is structured and makes distinctions </s> <s> The Dionysian which corre <smiley> on <smiley> roughly to Schopenhauer is conception of Will is directly o <smiley> osed to the Apollonian </s> <s> Drunkenne <smiley> and madne <smiley> are Dionysian because they break down a man is individual character all forms of enthusiasm and ecstasy are Dionysian for in such states man gives up his individuality and submerges himself in a greater whole music is the most Dionysian of the arts since it a <smiley> eals directly to man is instinctive chaotic emotions and not to his formally reasoning mind </s> <s> Nietzsche believed that both forces were present in Greek tragedy and that the true tragedy could only be produced by the tension between them </s> <s> He used the names Apollonian and Dionysian for the two forces because Apollo as the sun-god represents light clarity and form whereas Dionysus as the wine-god represents drunkenne <smiley> and ecstasy </s> <s> Article I discu <smiley> ed this in an old post on my original blog htt <smiley> <repeatedchars> darkstrider net july8_ <date> html Sorry I can 't link directly to it </s> <s> I used to hand-code that blog and didn 't know how to separate posts so I can only link to the entire page but it is the second post </s> <s> Just scroll down a little bit </s> <s> I was profoundly taken by this idea when I first encountered it in Camille Paglia is book Sexual Personae and she really made me aware of these two different modes of perception cognition </s> <s> These little tables I posted here and similar ones you see on the web are very brief and only cover the basics but Paglia di <smiley> ects it quite deeply </s> <s> She also relates these modes of thinking to what she terms the Male principle and the Female principle </s> left brain Apollonian being the male and right brain Dionysian being the female </s> <s> Don 't oversimplify and think she is making a general division between men and women </s> people have some of each tendency in their makeup just as we all use both left and right brain </s> <s> Many women exhibit strong male tendencies while many men have female tendencies </s> <s> Well when I connected these various ideas together it became clear to me that they are very real tendencies that exist in all of us </s> <s> Modern sbrain science as it often does is merely re-inforcing ancient wi <smiley> om </s> <s> The Greeks were aware of this dichotomy centuries ago and now it is been discovered in the very structure of the brain itself </s> so science has only shown us figuratively where Apollo and Dionysus live </s> <s> It makes me wonder </s> how many of the other Olympian go <smiley> could be said to embody some part of human nature </s> god of war </s> go 'e <smiley> of the hunt go 'e <smiley> of love </s> interesting </s> <s> And doubtle <smiley> not new Only something that hadn 't occurred to me before </s> <s> So </s> taking all this into account </s> the idea of a dichotomy in modes of thinking that is existed in human nature for a long time and that it is cro <smiley> ed up in various ways both scientific and mythical artistic I began to wonder if it is reared its head in any other ways </s> <s> And sure enough a couple similar dichotomies presented themselves to my questing mind </s> <s> Dichotomy in politics E <smiley> loring the neurobiology of politics scientists have found that liberals tolerate ambiguity and conflict better than conservatives because of how their brains work </s> <s> In a simple e <smiley> eriment reported today in the journal Nature Neuroscience scientists at New York University and <weirdcaps> show that political orientation is related to differences in how the brain proce <smiley> es information </s> <s> Previous <smiley> ychological studies have found that conservatives tend to be more structured and persistent in their judgments whereas liberals are more open to new e <smiley> eriences </s> <s> The latest study found those traits are not confined to political situations but also influence everyday decisions </s> <s> This is just a section of an article posted here </s> <s> To condense these tendencies down to their most basic for purposes of simplicity we could call one Focused and the other Vague or Fuzzy </s> <s> Which then led me to my next and so far last revelation </s> <s> Ro <smiley> and Cones Article Two different kin <smiley> of 'photoreceptor <smiley> ' or neurons in the eye </s> <s> Ro <smiley> are re <smiley> onsible for night vision and peripheral vision </s> they 're not as 'focuse <smiley> ' as the cones which see detail and color </s> <s> Therefore the vision of the ro <smiley> could be characterized as 'fuzzy ' or vague but in some way superior to the rod-vision </s> <s> Have you ever noticed that if you 're looking up into the night sky very dim stars or very distant galaxies which at first look like dim star <smiley> can 't be seen by looking directly at them cone <smiley> but only by looking a little bit away activating the ro <smiley> </s> <s> To me all these various dichotomies sound very similar </s> <s> In fact I 'd venture to say taken as a whole they point out the same basic division in the human being </s> a divergence between different modes of </s> is it perception cognition or interpretation Hard to say </s> <s> And I won 't make any statements here aside from bringing up what I think is a very interesting conundrum revealing itself to us in various ways - Mythical a way of giving meaning to things we don 't understan <smiley> Scientific a way of studying nature and Political -- and that might have a profound meaning as far as what it means to be human </s> </s> <s> And with this post hopefully I conclude this little obse <smiley> ion that began just before Halloween when wrote </s> <s> Lining up to enrich uranium - Editorials amp Commentary - International Herald Tribune Never underestimate the potential for erratic policy when economic and political interests collide even when the policy involves preventing the <smiley> read of nuclear weapons </s> <s> This ha <smiley> ened last month when in rapid succe <smiley> ion Argentina Australia and South Africa joined a growing list of countries interested in enriching uranium for commercial purposes </s> <s> That is the same activity that Iran claims as its inalienable right and that the United States the European Union Ru <smiley> ia and China insist must be halted in the interest of nonproliferation </s> <s> Is it fair or feasible to allow some countries to enrich uranium while attempting to prevent others from doing it The answer is not simple </s> <s> It turns on a number of technical economic and political considerations </s> <s> The technical dimension is most straightforward </s> <s> It pertains to the dual purpose of uranium enrichment to produce fuel for civilian reactors and e <smiley> losive material for nuclear weapons </s> <s> It is not surprising therefore that most of the countries that have an active or latent uranium-enrichment industry also po <smiley> e <smiley> once made or tried to acquire nuclear weapons </s> <s> Today most of the arguments in su <smiley> ort of new enrichment capacity are couched in economic terms generally linked to the buzz about major global e <smiley> ansion in nuclear energy </s> <s> Argentina Australia Brazil and South Africa for example portray their renewed interest in terms of projected domestic consumption and new e <smiley> ort o <smiley> ortunities </s> <s> In fact current global enrichment capacity excee <smiley> demand </s> <s> The projected boom in nuclear-energy development in most countries has yet to be matched by major new orders and the ability of newcomers to su <smiley> lant the entrenched su <smiley> liers is problematic </s> <s> Moreover the financial costs of reviving antiquated and previously uneconomical enrichment facilities in Argentina and South Africa are likely to be enormous </s> <s> So other factors are at play </s> <s> Almost all the new and pro <smiley> ective entrants in the enrichment busine <smiley> a <smiley> ear anxious to establish their credentials as having existing technology 'have-not <smiley> ' customer <smiley> under various proposals to establish multinational nuclear fuel centers and fuel-su <smiley> ly arrangements </s> <s> These proposals include President George W lateral subdivision in mammals corre <smiley> on <smiley> to a dorsal ventral subdivision in zebrafish </s> <s> They also did an anterograde tracer to confirm this connection </s> <s> Plus as further follow us and they may not dip into the stream in time to catch the evanescent ri <smiley> les in the flow that our remark started </s> <s> To see re <smiley> onses to us from those we don 't follow we have to click the Mentions tab </s> <s> However as our view is of those we choose to follow our emotional re <smiley> onse is set by that and we behave more civilly in return </s> <s> Buzz reverses this </s> <s> The general comments from frien <smiley> are in the Buzz tab but anyone can use ' <smiley> ' to mention you forcing the whole conversational thread into your inbox </s> <s> Similarly if you comment on someone else is Buzz any further u <smiley> ates to the web show up in your main email inbox </s> <s> The tragedy of the comments ensues where annoying people can take over the discu <smiley> ion and their replies are privileged twice over those you choose to follow </s> <s> This is the <weirdcaps> comments problem yet magnified when all hear the wor <smiley> of one the conversation often decays </s> <s> Mutual media By bringing in Twitter blogs Google Reader shared items photos and other Activity Streams fee <smiley> Buzz has the potential to be a way to connect the the prioritisation of secondary commentary and poking over collated ideas can be reversed in Buzz this could be made to work </s> <s> Small world networks Social connections are a small-world network standar <smiley> so it could help encourage others to do this better </s> <s> Mike Arrington wrote a plea for better social software on Sunday The online social lan <smiley> cape today sort of feels <smiley> puts his or her pictures on which site is a huge challenge </s> <s> What enabled Google to solve the search problem was a common standard for e <smiley> re <smiley> ing pages and the links between them so that they could index the webpages and derive a metric for which ones were more important </s> <s> They didn 't do this by replacing the web with a structured database that they curated they worked with the standar <smiley> in use to make sense of it </s> <s> To solve the social conundrum we need the equivalent - agreed standar <smiley> in wide <smiley> read use so that we can generalize acro <smiley> sites </s> <s> Fortunately we have these </s> <s> We have <weirdcaps> and <weirdcaps> for delegated login we have <weirdcaps> other microformats and Portable Contacts for public and private people connections we have Fee <smiley> and Activity Streams for translating social actions between sites </s> <s> This enabling social infrastructure means that we 'll be able to have a new generation of sites that enhance our web e <smiley> erience through social filtering without our connections being centralised in a single company is database </s> <s> Once we get used to the e <smiley> erience of being able to delegate login personal connections and activity u <smiley> ates we 'll look askance at developers who insist we create yet another profile and invite all our <s> Cavum by Wolfgang Kramer and Michael Kiesling In Kramer and Kiesling is new 'Cavum ' the designers offer a new 'gamer is game 'that reflects the unique sensibilities which have given us games from 'Torre <smiley> 'to 'Maharaja ' </s> <s> As is typical of this team they present us with a wide ranging menu of choices each turn and enormous freedom to manage our strategies </s> <s> For some this freedom lets players fully manage complex strategies while for others the freedom only means confusion and headaches </s> <s> What is e <smiley> ecially interesting is how the designer <smiley> ' style is e <smiley> re <smiley> ed in a new way - disguised but still unmistakably Kramer and Kiesling </s> <s> Wolfgang Kramer and Michael Kiesling have been working together as co-designers since <date> but they came to the attention of many gamers with the release of Tikal and Torres in <date> </s> <s> In both of these games players had free form turns in which they could choose from a menu of actions - moving building e <smiley> loring creating new pawns - each of which required the e <smiley> enditure of some number of 'Action Point <smiley> 'which were limited every turn </s> <s> Tikal was followed by Java in <date> and Mexica in <date> and these games are regarded as a trilogy - for their obvious use of this shared system for the use of masks on their box cover art and also for the graphic design used in the games by artist Franz Vohwinkel </s> <s> Depending on how you felt about these games the ' <weirdcaps> 'trilogy either referred to 'Action Point <smiley> 'or 'Analysis Paralysi <smiley> 'because such freedom could lead players to get stuck managing the details of each game turn </s> <s> With some subsequent games such a <smiley> 'Maharaja ' 'Australia ' 'Bison ' and even 'Sunken City ' this system got stretched in different directions but what remained constant was the use of a menu of potential choices confronting players that allows them to manage their turns with great flexibility </s> <s> Cavum is a relatively complex tile laying track building game in which the designers place their stamp in a new way </s> <s> At the beginning of the 'phase ' players fill their player mats with the 12 a <smiley> ets shown above </s> <s> Each represents an action he 'll be able to take once </s> <s> Four of them are ordinary tiles to lay although each one has a different amount of track or in this case 'tunnel ' One has a piece of track with a big ol ' piece of dynamite on it </s> <s> The three cubes are stations - and these are the only pieces that a player truly owns </s> <s> They will serve as starting and ending points for paths the player will trace in an effort to claim gems and they will also block other player <smiley> ' paths </s> <s> The gray tile with stones on it represents a 'vein 'which the player may place an <smiley> 'discover '- and will be a source from which all players claim gems </s> <s> Then there are two wild tiles which may substitute for any of the above and finally the symbol for pro <smiley> ecting </s> <s> This will always be the player is last action in the turn when he traces a path between any two of his stations cro <smiley> ing through any quantity of tunnels in an attempt to pa <smiley> through previously placed veins and pick up as many gems as po <smiley> ible </s> <s> Here is where I think the designers really show their true colors </s> <s> During a phase a player is going to engage in all twelve of his actions </s> <s> However the phase is broken up into any number of turns </s> <s> During a player turn he must select between one and four of his actions to perform before pa <smiley> ing his turn </s> <s> So these twelve actions might be distributed among as many as twelve and as few as three player turns per phase </s> <s> Each phase always culminates in the pro <smiley> ecting action </s> <s> So one player might choose to rush with his actions to ensure that gems are still on the board when it is time to pro <smiley> ect </s> <s> Another might proceed very slowly forcing all players to take their actions so that he may use all the resources out there when he finally pro <smiley> ects </s> <s> With such flexibility it is easy to see why this is very much a gamer is game - and one which can succumb to Analysis Paralysis in the wrong han <smiley> </s> <s> I wonder to what degree Kramer and Kiesling were in <smiley> ired by Martin Wallace is 'Age of Steam ' as they seem to have created a sort of negative image of the Wallace cla <smiley> ic </s> <s> In Age of Steam players are tracing paths with cities as the end points running through as many towns as po <smiley> ible </s> <s> In this case players own the tracks and the cities are public </s> <s> In Cavum things are reversed </s> <s> The paths are public but the end points - the stations - are what is owned by the players </s> <s> In Age of Steam goo <smiley> begin on cities and get removed as they are used </s> <s> In Cavum the goo <smiley> that are removed a <smiley> ear on the veins - which are the equivalent of Age of Steam is 'town <smiley> ' </s> <s> Age of Steam paths colored for clarity There is an important consequence of having players share all the 'track 'in Cavum </s> <s> They need to be interconnected with lots of junctions so that one player can trace from his stations through various veins and back to another of his stations while another player can use much of the same track use many of the same veins but return to his own station </s> <s> In Age of Steam where players own each piece of track exclusively the paths don 't interconnect as much and tend to be simpler </s> <s> Can you connect a path between any two blue stations cube <smiley> that pa <smiley> through as many gems as po <smiley> ible without pa <smiley> ing through any red or yellow stations Can you do it before other players get impatient This tangled web is what can make Cavum more than a little brain-burning </s> <s> What about that dynamite Each turn a player must place at least one tile with dynamite on it </s> <s> It is po <smiley> ible to cover up those pieces with normal tunnels in order to delay their destruction but at the end of the turn all e <smiley> osed dynamite tiles get removed - and also take out all top tiles in the six adjacent <smiley> aces </s> <s> In a four player game it is po <smiley> ible for 28 tiles to go to heaven Some have characterized this a <smiley> ect of the game as very nasty </s> <s> Incredible as it soun <smiley> I don 't think this rule is there e <smiley> ecially to a ' a 'take that 'element to the game and in my playing it didn 't come off as mean </s> <s> Rather the board can get so dense and locked in I think that the designers put in the dynamite in order to insure that the board continues to change after each phase </s> <s> The game is not that nasty because once a player has created a path it is difficult to obstruct that path until after he has collected his gems </s> <s> The dynamite doesn 't blow until the very end of the phase </s> <s> A 'itionally although stations block other player <smiley> ' paths they can 't be played on existing track </s> <s> Even if someone places a track tile in your way you may be able to promote it by placing another tile on it - as long as the new tile has more connections </s> <s> The only way I know of to to me <smiley> with an existing path is to promote it with a new tile that changes its connections </s> <s> Note that unlike Age of Steam all existing connections do not need to be preserved </s> <s> The way that the designers stray from their Action Point menu and instead <smiley> ecify the particular actions a player must allocate during each phase is a very clever way of directing game play </s> <s> If this game were from the <weirdcaps> trilogy it is po <smiley> ible that each action would have had its own cost </s> <s> A simple tile might cost 2 <weirdcaps> one with all connections might cost 6 <weirdcaps> tiles with dynamite could have their own cost as would stations </s> <s> The game would have been even more free form perha <smiley> more strategic and certainly more ma 'ening </s> <s> Instead each player gets a series of <date> 6 branch tiles and they all must be used </s> <s> Any tile may promote any other tile with fewer branches </s> <s> There becomes a natural flow and strategy to the phase </s> <s> Try to start out with the simplest tile po <smiley> ible and as o <smiley> onents me <smiley> with you hold back the more complex tiles to play on top and rescue yourself </s> <s> Or else use your six early on secure a complex path - but leave yourself vulnerable if another tile you were relying on gets rerouted </s> <s> I think that with this method Kramer and Kiesling have struck a nice balance between freedom and structure in their use of an action menu </s> <s> Where things seemed to <smiley> in out of control was in the paths themselves which need to be twisty and often difficult to visualize </s> <s> Indeed all players tend to be creating paths which all cro <smiley> over the same terrain and it seemed difficult to create a master plan that brilliantly snatched lots of gems </s> <s> Rather you 're more likely to feel like an idiot if you don 't get lots of gems </s> <s> I su <smiley> ect that e <smiley> erienced players will learn to visualize the board better make more strategic use of stations and reduce the a <smiley> arent chaos </s> <s> But in my playing understanding the board was a little like tracking a single strand of <smiley> aghetti as it win <smiley> its way around the meatballs </s> <s> If the game were just about laying tunnels and grabbing gems it wouldn 't be a Kramer Kiesling game </s> <s> On top of all this there is a modest economic system to value the gems that you do get </s> <s> At the beginning of each phase you can take order tiles </s> <s> It is exactly what you think </s> <s> Taking the one pictured is a commitment to acquire and trade a light blue a dark blue a green and a red for 26 points </s> <s> Fail to do so and you lose 2 points </s> <s> The risks aren 't great but neither are the rewar <smiley> because you can still sell gems back to the market - potentially doing even better </s> <s> In the example here eight of the yellow gems are either still on the board or in people is han <smiley> </s> <s> A reverse auction is held starting at '8 'and going down and the lowest bi 'ing player could sell as many yellow gems as he owns at his bid price </s> <s> So there are two ways to collect points for your gems and which is better will depend on how many players own a given color and how aggre <smiley> ive the bi 'ing gets </s> <s> The ability to sell gems either to the market or by completing orders struck some of us in our se <smiley> ion as a little o ' </s> <s> It watered down the tension </s> <s> If players must complete orders then a player has pre <smiley> ure to get the right combination knowing that not getting the last gem is a big lo <smiley> of potential points </s> <s> Such high stakes would provide a natural bomb in the game as it does in Alan Moon is Ticket to Ride </s> <s> Alternately forcing players into the market would have created a more economically oriented games in which players must monitor which gems are valuable jockey for those and close o <smiley> onents out of them </s> <s> By providing both alternatives players are most likely to go for orders - but relax knowing that the market provides something of a safety net if plans go awry </s> <s> Perha <smiley> the 'all or nothing 'game created too much chaos but this is so obviously a gamer is game it is surprising to see it made a little more family friendly </s> <s> I 'd love to <smiley> eak with the designers to learn what they were thinking </s> <s> I enjoy path laying games and I e <smiley> ecially enjoy the complexity that Kramer and Kiesling bring to their best gamer is games </s> <s> Given the history of such games I am not convinced that paths laid by Cavum make the most satisfying use of the choices the genre has to offer </s> <s> The use of actions in the menu in which players may order and group their 12 actions in any way they like - seems to have enormous potential and I hope to see it in a future game </s> <s> The actual tile and path creation seemed overly involved and counterintuitive </s> <s> I look forward to future playings to see if I 'm able to wrap my brain around this game or whether the game proves to be the stronger and wra <smiley> itself around me </s> <s> <weirdcaps> by Donald X </s> <s> Vaccarino If Sylla was a blend of old wines in a new bottle Dominion is a tasty young wine which seems unlikely to mature greatly </s> <s> Dominion has become an overnight hit and so many readers have already played it to death since its recent release </s> <s> I 've played it only once but what stan <smiley> out about it is its originality de <smiley> ite its simplicity </s> <s> The goal is to collect the most and best victory point car <smiley> into your deck </s> <s> Each player has his own deck of ten car <smiley> - seven with <math> gold and three with <math> <weirdcaps> </s> <s> He draws five car <smiley> from his deck and can use the gold car <smiley> to buy either more gold more <weirdcaps> is or any one of ten <smiley> ecial power car <smiley> <smiley> 'kingdom car <smiley> ' which are arranged in a di <smiley> lay </s> <s> Car <smiley> so purchased are placed into his deck for future draws </s> <s> After the player has used a power from one of his <smiley> ecial car <smiley> and purchased a card using his gold then both used and unused car <smiley> from his hand are placed in his discard pile - to be recycled when his draw deck has been used up </s> <s> In this way players are consistently drawing five car <smiley> taking actions buying new car <smiley> and then drawing more </s> <s> Car <smiley> used - or not - are continually being recycled but at a slower pace as his deck grows in size </s> <s> When sufficient car <smiley> have been purchased the game en <smiley> and the player with the most points in <weirdcaps> car <smiley> wins </s> <s> This feature of continually drawing and renewing one is own deck and building that deck on the fly is very original and the game plays like no other Eurogame </s> <s> Because a player must as a default draw exactly five car <smiley> a turn and work with only those car <smiley> at any given time the game requires a player not to maximize his a <smiley> ets with the most extensive di <smiley> lay of powers po <smiley> ible </s> <s> Instead the game is about concentration </s> <s> How can a player build a deck such that a random a <smiley> ortment of any five car <smiley> at a time be most powerful most consistently What we see is that the cost of a 'ing gold car <smiley> to his hand is di <smiley> roportionately high with higher values of gold </s> <s> Gold ca r <smiley> valued at <math> have no cost those valued at <math> cost three and those valued at <math> cost six </s> <s> This seems counterintuitive until you realize that normally a deck consisting of all <math> value gold car <smiley> could never buy anything costing more than five and then only rarely while a deck of <math> value gold car <smiley> can much more easily accumulate brawny values used to purchase big <weirdcaps> car <smiley> or strong powers </s> <s> In any given game there are ten different kingdom car <smiley> to choose from but the game comes with 25 unique decks so that the smorgasboard of choices may be different with each game </s> <s> Examples of powers in the set I used were ones that gave players extra actions and or extra o <smiley> ortunities to buy car <smiley> </s> <s> There were powers which allowed a player to a ' three car <smiley> into his hand remember they all recycle so this is an alternative way of concentrating your han <smiley> and ones which permitted gold car <smiley> to be upgraded to the next higher level </s> <s> Player interaction is very limited and from what I saw came in two forms </s> <s> One is that there are a few car <smiley> which enable a player to 'attack 'others for example by forcing them to discard down to three car <smiley> and other car <smiley> which enabled players to defend against such attacks </s> <s> In my game these were used <smiley> aringly because they don 't really help you advance your agenda and even a defensive card nee <smiley> to 'just ha <smiley> en to be 'in your hand at the time of an attack for it to do any good </s> <s> The other form of player interaction concerns the pace of the game </s> <s> A strategy which relies on gradually building up a killer hand and then collecting <weirdcaps> is can be counteracted by a strategy which attempts to buy lots of cheap car <smiley> and end the game quickly </s> <s> In practice I don 't believe that players gain from building up large decks because their powers are not cumulative </s> <s> You 're still drawing only five car <smiley> at a time </s> <s> The value of a large powerful deck is that it is le <smiley> diluted by <weirdcaps> car <smiley> </s> <s> But an o <smiley> onent cannot surprise you by ending the game </s> <s> If other players switch into 'collecting <weirdcaps> car <smiley> 'mode you can shift gears quickly </s> <s> Certainly the dynamic deck building of Dominion is original </s> <s> A 'ing to the freshne <smiley> of the game is the way that 25 distinct decks of kingdom car <smiley> can be mixed and matched to create unique situations for the players </s> <s> However many players have compared this game with Tom Lehmann is 'Race for the Galaxy '- with many fans stating their preference for the latter </s> <s> If Dominion is unique - is the comparison reasonable Looking at the ways that each game works she <smiley> some light on what makes each game <smiley> ecial - and also how very different mechanisms can be brothers under the skin </s> <s> Like 'Race for the Galaxy 'and its predece <smiley> or 'San Juan 'by Andreas Seyfarth Dominion is an economic game based entirely in car <smiley> </s> <s> Each player collects car <smiley> which enable him to buy yet other car <smiley> which a ' to a player is collection giving him new powers and more victory points </s> <s> One glaring difference which drives different a <smiley> roaches in each game is that in Race for the Galaxy players are purchasing car <smiley> for a permanent di <smiley> lay in front of them while in Dominion purchased car <smiley> simply enter a player is deck </s> <s> The Race for the Galaxy player has a <smiley> ets which are continually growing as each purchased card accumulates powers on top of those already present </s> <s> Every new a <smiley> et is a good thing </s> <s> In Dominion only a few car <smiley> are operating at any one time and then they are quickly recycled and the player moves on to another set </s> <s> It is good to have lots of kingdom car <smiley> because a hand dominated by <weirdcaps> is can 't purchase anything new </s> <s> It is also po <smiley> ible to select a variety of car <smiley> which are likely to interact in productive ways when they show up together </s> <s> But the effectivene <smiley> of any deck is going to max out quickly as the best you can do is to get a handful of productive interactions and then move on to the next draw </s> <s> Dominion requires a new kind of thinking - one in which more isn 't always better </s> <s> In Dominion players begin the game by selecting ten different decks of power car <smiley> and those become the fixed choices throughout the game </s> <s> In Race for the Galaxy there is a single deck used in all games but players must make choices from the car <smiley> they randomly draw throughout the game </s> <s> The argument for replayability in Dominion is that with ten out of twenty five po <smiley> ible car <smiley> being used in a game there are 3 3 million different po <smiley> ible combination </s> <s> In Race for the Galaxy there is only one </s> <s> Yet Dominion has a hi 'en weakne <smiley> </s> <s> It lacks sufficient ability to surprise the players and force them to react to unanticipated challenges and o <smiley> ortunities </s> <s> When a game forces a player to keep on his toes and potentially change his strategy substantially I call it a Nervous System </s> <s> In Dominion the e <smiley> erienced player can survey the available car <smiley> map out his strategy and execute it </s> <s> The degree to which car <smiley> interact in his hand will force tactical decisions but not generally a rethinking of the plan </s> <s> In comparison Race for the Galaxy has only about <date> car <smiley> but they are all or nearly all different and their a <smiley> earance at any time is entirely unpredictable </s> <s> A player can set off down a particular path </s> and discover o <smiley> ortunities in his car <smiley> which tickle him into straying down a new path </s> <s> Furthermore because the player is actions depend both on his own choices and those of his o <smiley> onents he may find himself with une <smiley> ected o <smiley> ortunities to e <smiley> loit </s> <s> Dominion is a sufficiently short game that it isn 't cri <smiley> led by the lack of surprise </s> <s> You can lay out a set of ten car <smiley> to start with - and for the next thirty minutes maybe that is all the surprise you need </s> <s> But it is a limitation that is in the game is structure </s> <s> Like a mechanical dog which has dozens of interchangable parts there is lots of potential variety but after a while I su <smiley> ect that players may find that underneath it all it still always barks to the same cues </s> <s> Time will tell </s> <s> It is been a long time since I 've contributed to this Journal the last article a <smiley> eared over six months ago </s> <s> That is just wrong </s> <s> I have been working on an article - about the 'Frustration Factor 'in games </s> <s> However work and writer is anxiety have been pushing it out and out and </s> <s> It is a tricky thing to create an article about types of game mechanisms because the subject is so vague </s> <s> Worse any given topic seems to be so br oad that I keep writing when I ought to just wrap it up </s> <s> So in an effort to get the train moving again I 'm offering a sort of article that I 've <smiley> ecifically avoided in the past </s> <s> Game reviews </s> <s> <weirdcaps> - This is not your father is game review </s> <s> It is not even Schloe <smiley> er or Vasel is game review </s> <s> It is a game review <weirdcaps> style </s> 1 The focus is on the game mechanics </s> <s> E <smiley> ect little or no discu <smiley> ion about the theme or components </s> 2 Game mechanics are described in their most e <smiley> ential form </s> <s> There will be no rehash of all the rules but instead a focus on the handful of mechanisms that drive the game and the decisions they offer </s> 3 I may provide only a pa <smiley> ing mention of whether I think the game is good </s> <s> Don 't e <smiley> ect a buyer is guide </s> <s> More emphasis will be placed on what mechanics are innovative or effective and why </s> <s> In most cases I only had a chance to play the game once </s> <s> One reason I 've avoided writing reviews in the past is that there are so many of them out there already </s> <s> To <smiley> ing another one onto the net seems redundant </s> <s> However I had the good fortune to attend <weirdcaps> con and had a chance to play many new games which I know there is lots of curiosity about </s> <s> I 'm going to limit each post to a single review </s> <s> This will hopefully make it easier for people searching for information about a given game to find it and will also keep each post to a manageable length </s> <s> My hope is to publish a new review every three or four days </s> <s> Here goes </s> <s> <weirdcaps> by Dominque Ehrhard Ehrhard used to be a considerable force in Eurogame design but he hasn 't been on the gamer is game radar for a while </s> <s> When they came out I had great enthusiasm for both Condottiere and Sereni <smiley> ima but those are over ten years old </s> <s> Sylla is released by <smiley> tari and it has their fingerpri nts all over it </s> <s> It a <smiley> eals to gamers and has oodles of features that feel familiar competing auctions income generating tokens food shortages- and it offers situations where scarce resources must be carefully allocated among competing nee <smiley> </s> <s> The driving mechanism is that players each start with several character car <smiley> and will get to a ' another to their hand in each game turn </s> <s> Each character has one to three colored symbols red blue yellow and potentially an a 'itional <smiley> ecial power </s> <s> After a 'ing a n ew character at the beginning of each game turn players may use thes e in any of several auctions for tiles which grant benefits </s> <s> Each auction is color coded so a character with a red symbol m ay only be used in a 're <smiley> ' auction while a character with all three may be used in any of them but may only be ispent ' once the three c olors make him three times more flexible but not three times more valuable </s> <s> Among the other a <smiley> ets that players take each turn and also potentially from winning auctions are disks in any of three colors </s> <s> These disks will have varying values at the end of the game </s> <s> Players also earn money every game turn and also take income from certain tiles and from one of the characters </s> <s> The most original phase comes in the election to su <smiley> re <smiley> bad events </s> <s> Four events are dealt out and two of them will occur each turn </s> <s> Now un <smiley> ent car <smiley> with the a <smiley> ropriate <smiley> ecial power the soldier in the u <smiley> er left and the rather matriarchal looking 'vestal virgin 'in the u <smiley> er right may contribute to influence these events </s> <smiley> he first event card on the right may receive votes from both soldiers and Virgins the one below it only accepts votes from Virgins </s> <s> The two events receiving the fewest su <smiley> re <smiley> ing votes are the ones that occur and these may cause the values of certain chi <smiley> to drop or may cause a certain type of character card to become out of play for several turns </s> <s> Finally players may convert money into <weirdcaps> is </s> <s> Sometimes this is through an auction and sometimes at a fixed price </s> <s> From the description you 'll see that there is nothing glaringly innovative here </s> <s> There are auctions in multiple 'currencie <smiley> ' </s> <s> The auction to control events is similar to that found in Rieneck and Stadler is 'Cuba ' </s> <s> In Cuba though a single player selects the 'law <smiley> ' while in Sylla the votes are aggregated among players </s> <s> The varying values of the colored chi <smiley> is similarly a commonly found market mechanism </s> <s> In <smiley> ite of this I found Sylla to be greater than the sum of its parts </s> <s> There are A <weirdcaps> of mechanisms in play each game turn but all are reasonably familiar so the game is easy to learn </s> <s> One a <smiley> ect of the game I a <smiley> reciated is the fact that a given character typically can either be <smiley> ent in the auction for tiles <weirdcaps> provide income <weirdcaps> be a <smiley> lied to a subsequent voting proce <smiley> </s> <s> So many different sorts of nee <smiley> are competing for the attention of your very limited resources </s> <s> Since the <smiley> ecial powers differ from card to card the selection of characters becomes a strategic consideration </s> <s> It is not the same as having a bunch of money and many places to <smiley> end it </s> <s> Every card has only select places where it can be used </s> <s> An urgent need to come up with another red dot may force you to <smiley> end a card you were hoping to hold back for yet another urgent need </s> <s> Example of six tiles up for auction in a given turn </s> <s> Note that the first two only accept 're <smiley> 'car <smiley> the next two only 'yellow 'and the last only 'blue ' </s> <s> The winner of each auction chooses the tile to auction next </s> <s> Sylla is variety of character types and colors its pricing mechanisms for colored discs and its multiple distinct phases create plenty of o <smiley> ortunities to let players try out different strategies </s> <s> Does one concentrate in order to maintain strength or diversify in order to have flexibility If you focus on earning lots of tiles you may earn many discs - but if you ignore the events then other players may drive the value of your discs way down </s> <s> Another strategic decision lies in how many of your characters should be 'Christian 'as symbolized by the fish symbol </s> <s> At the end game all Christian car <smiley> gain bonus <weirdcaps> is </s> <s> The down side is that certain events can cause your Christians to remain out of play for one or more game turns </s> <s> An over reliance on such car <smiley> can cri <smiley> le your play indefinitely </s> <s> There are also good situational i <smiley> ues that arise </s> <s> You might e <smiley> ect to win a valuable tile by committing two car <smiley> </s> <s> If forced to bid three do you commit a card that you wanted to use in the event phase Every game turn has seven phases with perha <smiley> ten individual auctions but the game doesn 't come off as a repetitive auction fest </s> <s> For one the types of things being auctioned tend to vary throughout the turn and so do the m etho <smiley> used </s> <s> The auction for tiles is a traditional sequential auction while the bid to control events is more of a majority control type of play </s> <s> A 'itionally the variou <smiley> 'currencie <smiley> 'are in short su <smiley> ly so auctions don 't overstay their welcome </s> <s> Players might have at most four red car <smiley> to compete in a red tile auction and all a <smiley> ets are public </s> <s> The auction plays out tactically </s> <s> Do I want to commit everything to guarantee getting what I want - or do I hold back a smidgen to at least drive the price up and maybe get a bargain Each auction is over quickly and there is little downtime </s> <s> I enjoyed my one play of Sylla </s> <s> The play was certainly very familiar but while the game may have lacked focus the variety of arenas to compete in kept the game changing and engaging </s> <s> Players who have a <smiley> reciated the rock solid reliability and Euro-ishne <smiley> of other <smiley> tari games such as Amyitis and Caylus are likely to welcome another recognizable member of the family </s> <s> Printer friendly 'So what is this game about 'is the natural first question you might ask when someone brings out a new board game for you to try </s> <s> That question can have one of two answers depending on the angle you look at the game from theme or mechanics 'The game <smiley> ans <date> years of Egyptian history </s> <s> You goal is to influence Pharoahs build monuments farm on the Nile and advance the culture of the people in an attempt to a <smiley> ease the god of the Sun 'Okay but what is the game about 'It is a set collecting and auction game </s> <s> There is a wide variety of tiles that you 'll collect which combine in myriad ways to score points </s> <s> On your turn you 'll decide whether to a ' one more tile to the pool or to auction off the ones already there </s> <s> Your goal is to collect those tiles which will be most valuable to you prevent your o <smiley> onents from getting too many tiles valuable to them 'Either of the above is a reasonable description of Reiner Knizia is 'Ra ' </s> <s> Since this is the Journal of Boardgame Design I 'm interested almost <date> in the latter </s> <s> Either description could reasonably be called the game is 'theme ' but in practice 'theme 'has come to mean the historical context in which the game su <smiley> osedly takes place </s> <s> The designer drapes a bunch of mechanisms around the theme and he has a game </s> <s> Maybe the mechanisms are closely tied to the theme and often in Eurogames they aren 't </s> <s> A game at its best is more than a bunch of mechanisms </s> <s> It is a coherent system of mechanisms with a theme of its own </s> <s> Let is call this theme that summarizes the system of mechanisms the game concept </s> <s> There is nothing to prevent a game built from a bunch of connected mechanisms from being lots of fun but I think that having a strong game concept takes the game up a level </s> <s> It hel <smiley> to focus the player <smiley> ' goals </s> <s> It a is meaning to the game apart from the theme </s> <s> It defines the game 'Players choose among a series of actions which help them to score points gain resources or avoid catastrophes </s> <s> The more you are able to take the same action during the game the more valuable it becomes </s> <s> The trick is that in each turn a player is presented with three po <smiley> ible actions and he must decide which one to play and which ones to make available to the players to his left '- Notre Dame I enjoy e <smiley> laining game rules and I always introduce the game by first describing the game concept </s> <s> Every rule has a role in su <smiley> orting the game concept </s> <s> If players can wrap the whole idea of the game around their hea <smiley> then all the individual rules ought make sense </s> <s> Players can sit down and get to work at trying to win </s> <s> If they can 't get the game concept then most likely you 'll see the 'deer in the headlight <smiley> 'look 'Okay you e <smiley> lained the game to me but </s> what am I su <smiley> osed to do 'The i <smiley> ue of game concept surfaced when I recently first playe <smiley> 'Amyiti <smiley> 'by Cyril Demaegd </s> <s> On any given turn a player will take one of five different actions </s> <s> The Merchant and Peasant each give you distinct types of resources </s> <s> The Engineer gives you immediate points and a shot at a majority battle for more points on the main part of the board </s> <s> The Priest lets you take part in a different majority battle in a small part of the board which help you win more points or resources depending on where you choose to play </s> <s> Finally you may move the caravan - in which you <smiley> end the resources you earned elsewhere to earn points from car <smiley> income faster caravan movement or the ability to earn points on the main board which in turn is limited by choices made by players who chose the Engineer earlier in the game </s> <s> Deep breath </s> <s> So the game Amyitis is about </s> <s> I 'm not sure </s> <s> Cyril Demaegd has a defense of the structure of Amyitis which is worth reading </s> <s> He described it as having a istar structure 'rather than a 'line structure ' </s> <s> I think I understand his point </s> <s> Some games ones with a linear structure have their elements lined up like dominoes </s> <s> The first one effects the next one and so on down until the last mechanism which affects the victory conditions 'Power Gri <smiley> 'by Friedmann Friese is an example of this </s> <s> You buy power plants which give you capacity to use fuel </s> <s> You buy fuel that fills your plants and together they can power your cities </s> <s> You extend your network of cities which when powered give you victory points as well as income that fee <smiley> the entire cycle for the next game turn </s> <s> What I think is meant by a istar structure 'might corre <smiley> ond to what Americans call a 'wagon wheel 'or 'hub and <smiley> oke istructure </s> <s> There is a core mechanism and several secondary mechanisms </s> <s> The secondary mechanisms may be independent but they all affect the core mechanism </s> <s> The problem is that there is no core mechanism in Amyitis </s> <s> The garden which does take up the most physical <smiley> ace on the game board really turns out to be just another way of scoring points that is not obviously more important than any other </s> <s> Here is my picture of the Amyitis structure which looks more like the floor plan from a <smiley> y movie than a wagon wheel </s> <s> From all this it may come as a surprise when I say that I think Amyitis is a hell of a lot of fun </s> <s> There are some very clever mechanisms in the game and notwithstanding the nightmare diagram above the interrelationshi <smiley> play well </s> <s> However playing Amyitis is a little like playing with sand </s> <s> It can be lots of fun but there is nothing to hold on to </s> <s> A strong game concept doesn 't make a game good </s> <s> It makes </s> </s>

<s> An Ode to Women in Technology This post is part of Ada Lovelace Day in honor of women excelling in technology </s> <s> Quick </s> <s> Who was the first computer programmer Pause </s> <s> The answer Ada Lovelace She wrote the first 'program 'for Charles Babbage is analytical engine </s> <s> Babbage conceived the idea only to perform calculations but Lovelace saw beyond that purpose to the po <smiley> ibility that that first 'computer 'could calculate Bernoulli numbers - My decade-plus in the technology world has showered me with ble <smiley> ings </s> <s> One of these is the women that have guided and in <smiley> ired me </s> <s> Here are a few that I want to thank profusely for their guidance su <smiley> ort and in <smiley> iration Michelle opened the door </s> <s> Lisa illuminates just how big the world can be </s> <s> Liz in <smiley> ires with her burning intelligence and amazing poise </s> <s> Cyd shows how art <smiley> iritual and profe <smiley> ional life coexist </s> <s> Christina creates new worl <smiley> with her ability to reinvent herself </s> <s> Kit hel <smiley> me see the practical path and how to plot my own </s> <s> Stephanie embodies true wi <smiley> om creativity and focus </s> <s> And last but not least thanks to Mom for being completely open </s> <s> Without her example no doubt that it would be far more difficult to recognize the amazing women that surround me </s> <s> At the <weirdcaps> Summit this past week in Memphis it was brought to our attention that the <weirdcaps> community is ble <smiley> ed to have so many women that actively lead our practice </s> <s> I thank my lucky stars every day </s> -The analytical engine was never built but let is not blame Lovelace for the failure of the men around her </s> <s> Photo credit Thanks to </s> <s> We attempt set up a system where we take people and insert them into a machine that is designed to bend their will to a strategy </s> <s> There are capital inputs information and time </s> <s> The people and technology output goo <smiley> and or services receive the revenue pay the bills and take care of the customers </s> <s> This soun <smiley> great until in practice you realize that the strategy decided on by the executive leadership loses it is effectivene <smiley> at the front lines except for rare cases </s> <smiley> outhwest Airlines comes to mind here Check out this key point from Pollan Another <weirdcaps> talk on ethanol helped me understand industrial agriculture which of course is a Cartesian system </s> <s> It is based on this idea of that we bend other <smiley> ecies to our will and that we are in charge and that we create these factories and we have these technological inputs and we get the food out of it or the fuel or whatever we want </s> tells an winning or we 're winning </s> <s> Michael Pollan The Omnivore is Next Dilemma <weirdcaps> March <date> What Salatin does is create a situation where his animals and the gra <smiley> that they graze on maximize their 'desire <smiley> 'and in turn produce a truly incredible bounty of food with re <smiley> ect to the amount of land and the investment put into it </s> <s> The cows are not slammed into a barn given a bunch of corn which is not good for them shot up with antibiotics and fattened until they are 'market-ready 'Rather they are moved from small plot to small plot grazing on brand new delicious gra <smiley> that they is there desired delicacy </s> <s> Chickens then follow them into that same plot a few days later feed on their delicacy fat maggot <smiley> and they defecate as they scatter the cow manure acro <smiley> the lot - which acts as fertilizer for the gra <smiley> </s> <s> Amazingly the gra <smiley> itself contributes to this cycle </s> <s> It was tall just before the cows enter the plot </s> <s> After they leave it she <smiley> much of it is root system <smiley> ue to the root-shoot ratio </s> <s> Fungi worms and the like digest the dead roots into new soil </s> <s> Just a few weeks later the gra <smiley> is again luxurious and tall ready for the next cycle </s> <s> Busine <smiley> folk would do well to take a close look at these metho <smiley> </s> <s> We can continue to scale our organizations based on executive strategy a 'ing more capital and more people to execute the decisions of the central structure </s> <s> The problem with that a <smiley> roach is that the changing relationship of the organization to its capital and the importance of engaging your employees and customers at a more basic level <smiley> imilar to meeting the desires of the cows gra <smiley> and chicken <smiley> are changing </s> <s> My gut tells me that the answer lies in creating organizations that satisfy all the parts like Salatin is farm does </s> <s> You might think of the executives as the farmer the cows and chickens as the employees and the gra <smiley> and animal fee <smiley> as the capital inputs </s> <s> The customers are the same ones who want a Polyface chicken so badly that they drive out to the farm to pick it up </s> <smiley> o read more about the farm check out the excerpt from The Omnivore is Dilemma on Mother Jones Why should we care about this Well as a designer I 've run into too many situations where organization were ill-suited to ingesting and a <smiley> imilating what the customers and employees really need to be fully engaged </s> <s> This is not a knock on any executive manager or employee </s> <s> Rather it is just the truth of how the information flows and re <smiley> onsibility distributed in most organizations today </s> <s> Through metho <smiley> like mental models we can get into the thought proce <smiley> es of all involved and figure out where disconnects or misunderstandings lie </s> <s> I am building a practice around these models and how they can align an organization is resources and people in way most effective for both the company and the customers </s> <s> I hope you 'll come back at some analyst absolutely nails why large organizations will find it very very difficult to allow the level of tran <smiley> arency and real interaction nece <smiley> ary to evolve their busine <smiley> es both strategy and operation <smiley> as the face of market and internal communications continues to evolve </s> <s> He distinguishes three 'impo <smiley> ible 'conversation <smiley> asking for feedback saying positive things about their competitors and admitting they were wrong </s> <s> Asking for feedback is fine but most organizations are not at all set up to actually listen ingest the feedback and decide whether or how to a 're <smiley> the i <smiley> ue </s> <s> Employees are at the breaking point already 'Productivity 'in most organizations means employees are left with precious little time to adjust to new ideas unle <smiley> they come from management or from within carefully managed feedback channels </s> <s> Some employees may be able to get ahead or ignore some of their different rhythms </s> <s> E <smiley> erience allows me to understand why saying positive things about their competitors is so difficult but I wish there was a way to show the larger organizational that company is own ideas </s> <s> Market results di <smiley> lay an organization is effectivene <smiley> so stop being afraid to show some a <smiley> reciation of those with whom you share industry <smiley> ace </s> <s> Jeremiah makes this excellent point Customers aren 't stupid </s> <s> In fact they know who your competition is and they talk amongst each other </s> <s> Most companies are not actually part of the conversation but mostly adjacent to it </s> <s> In that position they will mi <smiley> some critical piece of intelligence </s> <s> Right now the status quo might be holding but <smiley> is first travel agent and if you think that is a dull subject for a book then you couldn 't be more wrong </s> <s> Cook was a genius The man was born in <date> while Napoleon was still in power </s> <s> He <smiley> ent the first half of his life arranging tours to English seashore resorts for the religious and temperance societies that he belonged to </s> <s> I don 't think it ever would logically go to the railroa <smiley> and hotels not to the poor fool who got stuck with buying everybody is tickets </s> <s> Like I said even Cook didn 't think there was money in it </s> <s> Travel in Cook is time was a dirty affair for people who weren ' t rich </s> <s> The railroa <smiley> advertised cheap rates to the seaside towns which resulted in shockingly crowded beaches and hotels </s> <s> It wasn 't uncommon for twelve people twelve to share a bed with other frien <smiley> sleeping on the floor </s> <s> Stre <smiley> ed out hotel patrons would sometimes show their resentment by pooping in the bureau drawers </s> <s> The streets were crowded with rowdies and the beaches were so densely packed that bathers could hardly see the sand above </s> <s> Women who could afford it rented clunky changing room wagons which attendants pulled out into the surf for them </s> <s> Occasionally big waves above would knock over the wagons and the women inside would have to be rescued sometimes by naked men </s> <s> It seems that a sizable number of men believed that bathing suits were unhealthy for the wearers </s> <s> Cook is insight was that was that many people would be be ha <smiley> ier in le <smiley> crowded resorts in places like Scotland </s> <s> Some of those resorts weren 't served by the railroad so Cook arranged for carriages or boats to su <smiley> lement the rail service </s> <s> Some English customers regarded the Scots as barbarous and didn 't relish the idea of negotiating with them for meals and hotel rooms so Scott sent agents ahead to take care of all that and he was even able to get group discounts </s> <s> Little by little he a <smiley> embled the modern concept of the package tour </s> <s> What is fascinating about all this was that each of Cook is improvements was copied by the railroa <smiley> and steamship lines who opened their own copy cat travel agencies and who had the advantage of established reputations and lots of money for advertising </s> <s> Amazingly Cook managed to stay ahead of the game </s> <s> How did he do it Maybe it is because his competitors were just hirelings of the railroad and had to get every change okayed by higher-u <smiley> </s> <s> Cook was free to innovate </s> <s> When a woman on one of his tours complained about unsanitary foreign toilets seats he quickly invented a personal folding metal toilet seat cover </s> <s> Now that is enterprise Cook also benefited from his philosophy </s> <s> Other travel agencies were diverted by lucrative commi <smiley> ions from the wealthy </s> <s> Cook the audience and looking down </s> <s> You don 't even need <weirdcaps> to get the effect </s> <s> If you 're Eisenstein or Richard Lester or Sergio Leonne then you love the technique where you show the audience an ultra-long shot then </s> then on the same shot you have someone step in front of the camera for an ultra close-up </s> <s> I love it when monsters stick their hea <smiley> out over the audience and look around as if they 're trying to figure out which person to eat first </s> <s> Amazing but true on a big <weirdcaps> screen you can give the audience the physical sensation of looking up at something </s> <s> I don 't mean a simple u <smiley> hot I mean a shot where you get a definite sensation of light-headedne <smiley> and insecurity about your balance as if you 'd tilted your head way back </s> <s> To see what I mean click to enlarge </s> <s> It is not enough to tilt the camera up to get this effect </s> <s> You have to have something very distracting to look at up there else the audience is logic will kick in and they 'll talk themselves out of the vertigo you want them to feel </s> <s> O 'ly enough shooting a glamorous woman in close-up doesn 't always work </s> <s> You can convey personality and charm in a close-up but not sexine <smiley> not sexine <smiley> in the glamour meaning of the word </s> <s> I gue <smiley> visual sex cues have a lot to do with proportions and you need to step back a little to take that in </s> <s> The close-u <smiley> are just punctuation </s> <s> Okay there are exceptions </s> <s> How about 'Rear Window 'where Grace Kelly <weirdcaps> is or <weirdcaps> is of music photos video etc At <weirdcaps> we 've been testing Nginx with Pa <smiley> enger and have mostly had good results </s> <s> There are two i <smiley> ues that have come up hopefully only one of which may broadly affect others </s> <s> The first i <smiley> ue which likely affects anyone using this is that it a <smiley> ears that if you combine and cache <weirdcaps> or <weirdcaps> via tags like this in Rail <smiley> lt stylesheet_link_tag <smiley> tandard cache istandar <smiley> ' gt lt javascript_include_tag jquery cache 'jquery_all ' gt The ' <smiley> tandar <smiley> 'an <smiley> ' jquery isymbols are e <smiley> ansion symbols for multiple <weirdcaps> <weirdcaps> files defined in a Rails initializer </s> <s> On the first request Rails gets it is su <smiley> osed to combine all the files as per the e <smiley> ansion symbol definition and then produce a 'cache 'file so you have a single file that is included in your <weirdcaps> </s> <s> This worked fine for us under Mongrel but it didn 't seem to regenerate under Pa <smiley> enger after doing a deploy even with a restart to Pa <smiley> enger </s> <s> We had to do a second restart of Pa <smiley> enger and then hit the server at least twice if not more to see it get picked up </s> <s> Thanks to a tip from Engine Yard one solution can be found on the overstimulate blog where they what I was going to install on my server </s> <s> Lastly I didn 't really want to have yet another gem dependency for something pretty straight forward like this <weirdcaps> </s> <s> So get on with it you say what is the solution Two pieces </s> <s> First I create a crontab directory within my Rails a <smiley> is config directory </s> <s> In that I store crontab files named by the hostname of the server - the same thing you 'd get by doing a hostname on the server </s> <s> You could a ' an extension or whatever you want but the hostname is what makes this work easily so you want that somewhere in your file naming convention </s> <s> We only have a couple servers and I know them well so I just went with pure hostname for now </s> <s> The contents of each file are exactly what you 'd see in the crontab file on the server for the user you set it up under </s> <s> Second a simple Capistrano task to affect the given crontab file on the server with an after hook to run it task write_crontab roles a <smiley> do put <smiley> 'Installing server- <smiley> ecific crontab 'run <smiley> 'cd deploy_to current config crontab crontab hostname ' end after 'deploy restart ' 'write_crontab 'That is it </s> <s> You can obviously tweek this for your own setup for example maybe you need to run it on all roles or different roles or what not </s> <s> Your run command might need to be more robust or run a shell script or rake task for example if not all servers have crontabs or you have something more dynamic </s> <s> But as you can tell setting this kind of thing up is pretty straight forward and it is great to keep your crontab setu <smiley> in version control </s> <s> Thanks to you guys that stimulated the idea in the first place </s> <s> Recently we ran into an interesting performance i </s> till we meet again Historelli This past weekend Nik Social and I with several other <smiley> aided in the eventual release of a gargoyle </s> <s> We were guided by master carver Franco Minervini who showed us how to work limestone on a model of a humanoid griffin </s> <s> The actual gargoyle sits atop the National Cathedral in Washington where Master Minervini worked during the late <date> s </s> <s> Stone carving is the reverse of molding because instead of putting material together to create a figure you must take bits and pieces away to free a form </s> <s> Besides the difference in technique working stone is much more profound and permanent compared to clay or even paint </s> <s> Not only in the sense that the finished piece will most likely outlast the artist by centuries but also for the reason that the actual activity of shaping stone is primeval and ancient </s> <s> Even a beginner with any sense of geology can understand the connection </s> <s> Stone is eternal working it forces you to contemplate millennia </s> <s> Furthermore stone is rough and until coaxed properly unyielding </s> <s> A novice will swell his han <smiley> scrape his knuckles and breathe in dust before continuing </s> <s> And yet the finished product can be as refined and polished as the finest impre <smiley> ionist painting </s> <s> I wasn 't sure what I would find before taking this stone carving workshop I did know that I wanted to better comprehend the craft and how it relates to my own roots </s> <s> Master Minervini stems from the city of Molfetta where my parents were also born and were <math> of my known ancestors come from </s> <s> Minervini is teacher at the National Cathedral was the late great carver Vincent Palumbo a fifth generation master whose family also ran sho <smiley> in Molfetta </s> <s> Anyone whose been to Molfetta or even seen a picture of the place would not be surprised by the genesis of stone carvers the city initiates </s> <s> Comprised of sun-scorched limestone buildings Molfetta shines with a brightne <smiley> that beautifully contrasts with the deep blue Adriatic and the surrounding olive groves </s> <s> Years ago its inhabitants fished the sea farmed the land or worked the stone </s> <s> All of my ancestors survived via these trades and I believe it is e <smiley> ential to e <smiley> erience these fundamentals in order to be 'It is the trade of lawyers to question everything yield nothing and to talk by the hour '- Thomas Jefferson Over the past couple of weeks I 've been reading Opinionistas a blog written by a young female lawyer in <weirdcaps> </s> <s> In a 'ition to her describing life as an indentured billable hour servant replete with grueling hours and impo <smiley> ible workloa <smiley> she also describes colleagues sloughing off their youthful idealism as they struggle inside the pre <smiley> ure cooker environment of a major law firm </s> <s> I particularly liked this entry - Casting That Stone </s> <s> It is about how some women seem to abandon their hard earned profe <smiley> ional lives in pursuit of safe boring marriageable men </s> <s> Opinionista wonders if women have evolved if at all during the past sixty years of feminist awarene <smiley> </s> <s> But what I really like about this blog is that you get the sense the author is in the mi <smiley> t of a <smiley> ychological struggle of her own </s> <s> In her world of high priced graduate schools e <smiley> ensed lunches and status hungry sycophants everyone is constantly comparing themselves to everybody else </s> <s> Do I make enough money Am I more succe <smiley> ful Why is she married and not me Who is got a corner office Why did that a <smiley> ociate get the deal It can be a toxic soul eroding lan <smiley> cape that not everyone survives with decency intact </s> <s> Its obvious Opinionista has second thoughts about being a lawyer </s> <s> Her ambivalence permeates the entire blog and you wonder what she 'll end up doing </s> <s> Will she chuck her e <smiley> ensive law school degree Or will she make whatever accommodations she nee <smiley> to make within herself to remain a lawyer It is a proce <smiley> all profe <smiley> ionals struggle with when they realize the career they 've dreamed about since high school isn 't all it is cracked up to be </s> <s> Well written and humorous - I recommend you check Opinionista out </s> <s> The author doe <smiley> 'question everything 'but yiel <smiley> insights into a slice of life we might otherwise have never known about </s> <s> Go read My Name is Clark Kent into computer monitors and working in low lighting have taken their toll </s> <s> At least the gla <smiley> es lend me a profe <smiley> orial air </s> <s> I 'm constantly taking the gla <smiley> es on and off </s> <s> I 'm always reading something a dupe pad the <weirdcaps> monitor or an order form </s> <s> Sometimes I 'm wearing them tableside </s> <s> Sometimes I 'm not </s> <s> This occasionally
