<s> The word 'permanent ' a <smiley> ears on many different art products but it is a confusing term </s> <s> On many graphic art products such as inks or felt-ti <smiley> ed markers it really means 'waterproof ' rather than 'lightfast ' Many calligraphy or fountain pen inks such as the brown inks in the drawing above are not waterproof but they 're reasonably lightfast considering that most handwriting isn 't usually subjected to light for long perio <smiley> </s> <s> The sketches are for sky galleys part of the planning for Waterfall City from Dinotopia A Land Apart from Time </s> <s> Here is what the Calvin Theater looked like in <date> </s> <s> The sketch is in pencil and marker </s> <s> First let is have a look at a video </s> <s> What you 'll see is a visualization of three different color schemes as <weirdcaps> shapes floating within the <weirdcaps> color <smiley> ace </s> If this embe 'ed video doesn 't play try this link to <weirdcaps> </s> <s> Each painting will be followed by an irregular shape that represents the range of colors used within that composition </s> <s> If you 've read this blog for a while or dug back in the archives you may remember seeing how we can chart a color scheme as a shape or gamut that takes up part of a color wheel </s> <s> Everything outside the gamut is left out of the composition </s> <s> The painting Palace in the Clou <smiley> above has a gamut limited to intense blue o <smiley> osed by fairly dull re <smiley> and yellows and some fairly dull dark greens </s> <s> To the right of that is a computer-generated image made by sampling all the pixels and charting them on a color wheel </s> <s> The software was created by Phillipe Colantoni and is available for Windows users at couleur org </s> <s> We can also combine the value or lightne <smiley> data to see the color scheme as a <weirdcaps> representation inside an <weirdcaps> cube </s> <s> The <weirdcaps> color <smiley> ace is created by graphing red green and blue as three separate vectors in <weirdcaps> <smiley> ace </s> <smiley> he green vector above is hi 'en by the gamut Where the vectors intersect is pure black </s> <s> At the o <smiley> osite corner is pure white </s> <s> In this configuration the secondaries are cyan magenta and yellow which would lie on the plane between each of the two vectors </s> <s> A pure yellow for example would be on the plane formed by red and green the horizontal plane in this view </s> <s> By comparing each of the paintings with its gamut in <weirdcaps> color <smiley> ace and then comparing the gamuts to each other you can see how the gamuts vary </s> <s> The gamut for Crocodile Swamp is narrower because the color scheme is more limited </s> <s> There are hardly any blues </s> <s> The yellow windows in this scene show up as a scattering of yellow dots at the bottom of the gamut </s> <math> Software by P </s> <s> Colantoni at couleur org </s> <s> Animation by Lester Yocum at lesteryocum com Previously on <weirdcaps> Color Wheel Masking <smiley> ate We take for granted that our e <smiley> erience of vision results from the interaction of light with objects </s> <s> It is obvious isn 't it Light shines on objects bounces off them and then it stimulates our eyes </s> <s> But for thousan <smiley> of years that basic concept was not understood </s> <s> People only knew was that there was some sort of connection between the eyes and the objects seen </s> <s> During the time of Aristotle in the fourth century <weirdcaps> one school of thought held that the eyes emitted a visual fire that traveled to the object and somehow ma <smiley> aged it </s> <s> Others believed that objects gave off a substance that flew toward the eye </s> <s> These notions persisted until the time of Leonardo who objected to the idea of fire from the eyes </s> <s> He said there wouldn 't be time after opening the eyes for the fire to leave the eyes and travel all the way to a distant object and return </s> <s> Others reasoned that if the objects gave off a flaming substance why can 't we see at night The breakthrough came from an Arab physicist Alhazen around <date> <weirdcaps> who noticed that light traveled into the eye and caused it pain </s> <s> He also noticed that we e <smiley> erience afterimages after looking at bright light </s> <s> Light not just our eyes and not the objects themselves was the agent of vision </s> <s> What I wonder as I reflect on these ideas is what was the ancient conception of light It is mentioned often in the Hebrew bible of course </s> <s> Surely the ancients were sensitive of the action of light around them </s> <s> How they regard it differently if they didn 't understand its role in vision <math> Based on material from Vision and Art The Biology of Seeing by Margaret Livingstone </s> <s> Image from Discover </s> <s> Here is a rare glim <smiley> e of official art from North Korea with e <smiley> lanations by B </s> <s> R </s> <s> Myers a contributor to Foreign Policy magazine </s> 'Kim Jong Il comforts a distraught nation after his father is death on July 8 <date> </s> <s> In the background is the <math> foot bronze statue of the Great Leader that was erected on Mansu Hill in Pyongyang in <date> </s> <s> Dark skies in depictions of this period symbolize the growing threat from without ' 'The Dear Leader stan <smiley> guard as the waves of a hostile world crash ineffectually against the rocks ' Say what you want about the grandiose personality cult and the bizarre geopolitical posturing </s> <s> I 'm intrigued by the paintings themselves </s> <s> That is some darn good water painting in the second piece e <smiley> ecially in the recoil of the foamy wave on the left </s> <s> The strong silhouette and Kim is resolute defiance remind me of N </s> <s> C </s> <s> Wyeth is Billy Bones </s> <s> Just swap the <smiley> ygla <smiley> for tinted <smiley> ecs </s> <s> Look at the far red flag in the second painting </s> <s> It sits back in <smiley> ace because of the muted color and the softened top edge </s> <s> All the figures are well studied though the value organization is a little busy </s> <s> The grouping of figures remin <smiley> me of 19th century Ru <smiley> ian history painters like Vasily Surikov <math> </s> <s> Official art in east Asia took much of its early in <smiley> iration from the Ru <smiley> ian painters </s> <s> Back in the late 70s I used to go to Chinatown in L </s> <s> A </s> to collect Mao posters which were impre <smiley> ive paintings on a lot of levels </s> <s> They 're a piece of history now </s> <s> I 've had the privilege of meeting many of the artists who painted them and their stories are fascinating </s> <s> See more examples and read political commentary B </s> <s> R </s> <s> Myers on Foreign Policy Thanks Bryn </s> <s> The great color theorist Albert Munsell observed that a given color reaches its greatest chroma at one particular value called the home value or the peak saturation value </s> <s> That peak value varies from color to color </s> <s> An orange-yellow for example is most intense at a very light value while blue is strongest when it is very dark </s> <s> Red reaches maximum chroma at a mi 'le value </s> <s> The hand-painted chart takes the three hues through all po <smiley> ible degrees of chroma and value </s> <s> Yellow becomes a brown when it darkens and you just can 't get a strong chroma from a dark yellow </s> <s> In the chart chroma is meant to be constant along a vertical line while value is constant on a horizontal line </s> <s> It is good color mixing practice to make these charts and Munsell-schooled artists benefit greatly from the e <smiley> erience </s> <s> For these charts I have arbitrarily limited the chroma range to six ste <smiley> </s> <s> But in Munsell is system there can be many more ste <smiley> and theoretically there is no u <smiley> er limit to the measurement of chroma </s> <s> New pigments keep pushing the range farther out </s> <s> This digital chart from David Brigg <smiley> is excellent website huevaluechroma shows a range of hues taken through the paces </s> <s> Follow that link to his discu <smiley> ion of the same topic </s> <s> Tom Lopez of <weirdcaps> Productions created a full-length audio adaptation of Dinotopia The World Beneath using actors sound effects and music by Tim <date> </s> <s> Now this is more like it A little while ago when I reviewed the first volume of the collected Buffy the Vampire Slayer Season 8 series from Dark Horse I was kind of disa <smiley> ointed </s> <s> I felt the story telling was cho <smiley> y and jumbled and that it lacked a lot of the real character development strengths of the original <weirdcaps> series </s> <s> Well the next three volumes of the series are a huge improvement </s> <s> They are Volume 2 No Future For You volume 3 Wolves at the Gate and volume 4 Time of Your Life </s> <s> The main V2 arc is a Faith story wherein Giles employs Faith to do some Council-type wetwork stuff he wouldn 't want to get Buffy involved in </s> <s> It is a good compelling read getting two somewhat le <smiley> involved characters in V1 back into the main line of Season 8 </s> <s> V3 Brings Dracula back this time on Buffy is side battling against some rogue Japanese vampires </s> <s> V4 brings the futuristic Fray back into the mix as Buffy travels into the future </s> <s> V4 also brings Willow back into the main stream of the Season 8 arc </s> <s> Each volume also has a shorter stand-alone story which is basically used for some character development which often gets a bit of short shrift in the main volume arc </s> <s> Over all I am pleased with how the S8 arc is developing -- just like more season arcs developed </s> <s> Slowly during the first part of the season setting up the big push later on </s> <s> And the Twilight Big Bad arc for S8 is still pretty mysterious so I 'm looking forward to seeing how it develo <smiley> </s> <s> I still have a few quibbles of course and I think the biggest is how a lot of the character stuff if peripheral to the main story arc </s> <s> In the tv series the character development and the story arc were always very tightly bound basically one growing out of the other </s> <s> Buffy and the other characters grew and changed because of what was ha <smiley> ening to them and even by S6 what was ha <smiley> ening to them became the main story arc </s> <s> In the comic series so far they 've much more tended to seal off the plot from the characterization </s> <s> And I think it is a mistake </s> <s> We really need to get back into the hearts and min <smiley> of the characters by the end of the arc that is what nee <smiley> to drive everything else </s> <s> And if it doesn 't ha <smiley> en it 'll be hard to judge S8 as a succe <smiley> </s> <s> Andrew Fo <smiley> is first two novels Fat White Vampire Blues and Bride of the Fat White Vampire were entertaining and over-the-top a couple of innovative entries into the vampire cannon </s> <s> Cinematic and funny touching and absurd they were terrific rea <smiley> if not quite great literature </s> <s> Now comes The Good Humor Man </s> <s> It is a lot of the same things as the earlier book <smiley> obse <smiley> ed with pop culture very cinematic funny and absurd although not quite as touching and romantic </s> <s> On the other hand it is also a lot more thought-provoking with a satirical edge that is a lot more upfront than the earlier work </s> <s> What is it about Think of it as Fahrenheit <date> for the diet industry </s> <s> Imagine a future <weirdcaps> where high calorie foo <smiley> are illegal and a gang of government- <smiley> onsored thugs will raid any high-cal party they find </s> <s> Imagine if one of the founders of the movement su 'enly thinks it is all going too far and that people should really be free to make their own choices in life </s> <s> Furthermore it is also not hard to imagine that Big Food has come up with a few secrets of it is own </s> <s> Our newly converted hero then nee <smiley> to save the day </s> <s> What results is an amazing road trip into the heart of American food culture Fat Elvis </s> <s> Yes Fat Elvis is the driving force but not character remember it is the future and in <smiley> iration for the book </s> <s> More than that I cannot reveal </s> <s> Anyways it is all kinda indescribable anyways </s> <s> Liposuction for example is also a strangely important driving force in the novel </s> <s> Read it </s> <s> It is fun and thoughtful and way <weirdcaps> </s> <s> In fact every time you think Fox can 't po <smiley> ibly go more <weirdcaps> he pulls another fried peanut butter and banana sandwich out of his hat </s> <s> Seamus Cooper is The Mall of Cthulhu is a seriously strange and funny book </s> <s> Okay here goes </s> <s> A decade before the main action Ted a regular college kid saves his lesbian best friend Laura from a horde of vampires trying to initiate her into their sorority he is traumatized by having to ma <smiley> acre the whole nest of vampires including a recently turned frat frien <smiley> </s> <s> Ten years later she is joined the <weirdcaps> as an analyst while he is unable to overcome his past and is following her from city to city as her career progre <smiley> es all the while working a series of <weirdcaps> </s> <s> Now he stumbles on a Lovecraftian con <smiley> iracy </s> <s> A bunch of white supremacists are working to bring the Great Old Ones back from their dimension </s> <s> Ultimately Ted and Laura work together along with a shadowy yet underfunded government agency to fight them back </s> <s> Light-hearted yet still a bit scary this is a fantastic first novel </s> <s> Good adventure engaging characters some self-deprecating insights into slacker nerd culture more-or-le <smiley> tight plotting tons of Lovecraft and other pop culture in-jokes not to mention a whole lot of winking and nudging this is an entertaining melange </s> <s> I certainly hope Cooper will bring Ted and Laura back for more supernatural adventures </s> <s> If the vampire novel is sli <smiley> ing down into the realm of the bodice ri <smiley> er it seems to me that zombies are the new vampire able to actually embody horror without romance or any kind of soft and fuzzy feelings </s> <s> Zombies mostly evoke fear and terror and a almost fatalistic wonder at the randomne <smiley> of the universe </s> <s> In the han <smiley> of a great up-and-coming horror novelist zombies can be gold </s> <s> Jonathan Maberry is just such a writer the award-winning author of the Ghost Road Blues series of horror novels </s> <s> Patient Zero is another real winner from Maberry if anything even better than his earlier trilogy </s> <s> It is a combination zombie horror and medical thriller a very good example of the kind of hybrid science fiction horror genre that is bound to become more and more popular </s> <s> Basically the idea is that a Baltimore cop is recruited by a secretive government agency to help stop what seems to be a Mi 'le Eastern terrorist plot to flood the world with a plague of zombies that <smiley> read quite easily via victims being bitten </s> <s> The action is non-stop the main character Jack Ledger is quite well drawn the plot points are a bit
